reviews.review_title: "Boogie Nights" Remains An Enlightening Masterpiece Of '90s Film-making, While Viciously Exposing The Other Side Of The Film Industry
reviews.content: Boogie Nights charts the story of infamous porn star Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg), a young man striving to become something in the wide world. He is not the sharpest tool in the shed, but he has a talent on one side of the life spectre and quickly becomes a media icon. Boogie Nights shows the rise and fall of Dirk Diggler and the close-knitted friends he works with. Generally speaking, the film is based around the real facts, capturing the needed essence and realism of the porn world. The core of Boogie Nights is that it is a reflective character study that entertains, amuses, shocks, thrills and educates the viewer.Boogie Nights is a film where you become part of a journey, this journey is one that shows you just how exploitive and derogatory the porn industry is Think "Goodfellas", but instead of gangsters you have pornographers. You can tell Paul Thomas Anderson has been influenced by Martin Scorsese's '90s cinema because there is an edge of Scorsese-flair direction hanging over Boogie Nights. At first look I thought Boogie Nights would just be a highly entertaining study telling the story of the porn industry, however Boogie Nights holds a message and rather than just being a film, it becomes a deeply insightful study.Boogie Nights pulls the viewer inside a world fuelled by casual sex and drug abuse. At heart, Boogie Nights is extremely anti certain elements of the porn industry. Boogie Nights slowly changes from being a highly enjoyable drama to becoming a demeaning study of wasted life and a lesson in social history. The film depicts everything, it does not hesitate to show the truth and reveal to the viewer the fascinating warped lifestyle that some people live.Everything is so fast, a plunge into a new lifestyle, a new culture, a new group of people, who at heart are a new family and the people who represent the confidence that Dirk Diggler never had from his parents. You are supposed to pity Dirk Diggler because he never had the love and care that he needed. There was not enough hope for Dirk Diggler before his success in the overpowering porn industry. But porn was his freedom and his route away from his mundane life. Yet, does it make him a better person? The answer is a simple, no, because he soon becomes a nasty person, controlled by his self-indulgence and loss of respect. You see, Boogie Nights is not about sex, it is not meant to turn us on because what it is about is a business that has shattered many people's lives.Boogie Nights is not a sleazy film, nor is it not a lurid film; however it is an extremely honest film that is not afraid to educate the viewer on what the porn industry does to the people. Boogie Nights made me think that porn is not just "fun and games", but it is actually exploiting people who have very few options in life. Another sad fact was that the actors and filmmakers consider what they were doing to be excellent and they truly felt they were making good films; it saddened and amused me to see them considering their work to be "well made". It made me sad to see just how ignorant they all were, what at heart is nearly as bad as an Ed Wood film.Paul Thomas Anderon's talent bursts onto screen with a vivid and colourful spectrum of material. He gives a script that pulses with hysterical humour, quotable dialogue, brilliantly structured narrative and a raw edge. The story layout is glorious and has many twists and turns, showing every little effect. One of the film's most memorable film-making characteristics is the use of tracking shots, arguably the finest to ever be put on film. Boogie Nights has that authentic vibe that captures '70s and '80s pop culture with a delicate force. The use of tracking shots gives the film a needed documentary effect. It is a visionary experience and one where Paul Thomas Anderson loves his wonderfully flawed characters which he has carefully crafted. The film also sums up the contrast of how violence becomes a trial for the lives of the characters, it is a perfected transition. Paul Thomas Anderson captures the pop culture with excellence and hilarity, by using a variety of '70s and '80s iconic songs you feel pumped inside the era. The editing is amazingly clean-cut and with the use of quick shots, close-ups and a variety of unique techniques we become plummeted into the world and introduced to many characters through incredibly '90s film-making.The ensemble cast is awe-inspiring, it adds to the mixture of quirky comedy and emotional driving force. There are so many talented actors and actresses who deliver career defining performances, which are some of the finest in modern cinema history. The entire cast light up the screen and create amusingly likable characters, who you manage to feel sympathy for. The actors and actresses control the viewer and help draw you inside the underworld of the porn industry, shedding light on what really happens and the unpleasantly genuine effects.I would consider Boogie Nights a depressing film, yet one that also has an element of hope and edge of inspiring attitude because it shows that some people are able to change the nastiness they have dug themselves into. It works as a brilliant comedy, an insightful drama, a detailed study and an entertaining work of art. It has everything a true masterpiece needs. Many aspects of Boogie Nights are unpleasant One of the best films ever made, there is no questioning the sheer force and wonderful charm of wit which Boogie Nights holds. I guess Dirk's motto is true to Boogie Nights, and much more, "everyone is blessed with one special thing".

reviews.review_title: The greatest movie of the last fifty years!
reviews.content: I am not kidding, this movie is perfection. So well written, so well acted. It is a disgrace that it was overlooked by the academy for best picture because of the subject matter.  This movie is not profane or vulgar, it simply shows the every day goings on of an adult film maker and his cast and friends. The subject matter is dealt with professionally, just like in the real world. The real message of the film is one of hope and acceptance. Everybody in the picture is seeking some kind of acceptance and they eventually achieve it by working together in the adult film business. Keep in mind, that during the 1970's, adult films were seeking to compete with mainstream movies as a viable form of entertainment. Keep an eye out for the character Todd Parker, his performance was especially great. Also Mark Wahlberg and John C. Reilly were great as Chest and Brock (a.k.a. Reed and Dirk). Fantastic movie. Don't be a prude, see it.

Boogie Nights, 8/10, 6th best movie of 1997, 158th best movie of all time.I suppose most of the people that are going to see this movie have seen it already, but I'll review it anyway. This movie manages to be simultaneously brilliant and very fun. I'm sure its under drama at the video stores but you could just as easily put it under comedy (especailly John C. Reily's character). Although it is extremely sad to see Mark Whalbergs character go from an extremely nice if somewhat stupid young man into a total asshole jerk, but at the same time I'm sure that transition is what made the movie so fun to watch, and I suppose that is the most likely thing to happen in this situation. Well I realize this movie came out nearly a decade ago, but you know what that means... you can rent it for about dollar.... go get it!

P.T. Anderson successfully pulls off the gigantic tale of a young porn star clearly modeled on Long Dong Silver, but aptly named Dirk Diggler for this film.  Lots of fancy music and gorgeous women provide a fun gloss to a story that is essentially sad.  Anderson manages to be almost too sentimental while at the same time not flinching from all the grotesque aspects of Diggler's twisted life.  Reynolds is great in his part, although the script expects him to carry a lot of weight on his shoulders -- he's sort of the father figure for all his "stars" and for the movie itself as well.  Good acting overall, talky script.

Boogie nights was another very strong film from paul thomas anderson and he proved in his early days even after making hard eight that he has a lot of knowladge and talent in him,script and dialogue is written very smart and it engage me in almost every scene,characters are also very different from each other and they showed how they blend in porn industry,wahlberg give one of his best performances,only beated by departed,moore was brilliant and burt reynolds masterful,boogie nights is great watch and showcase how porn industry works and how in 70s and early 80s porn actors dealed with a lot of problems even in the staff they were the best in

reviews.review_title: Brilliant acting, almost the best movie ever.
reviews.content:
I watched this movie not knowing a single thing about it, and that's the way I like to see movies.  I feel this comment contains spoilers.A.K.A., "How an Idiot Becomes Dirk Diggler". If you have no interest in a movie about porn, this movie deserves to be seen anyway merely on the basis of the acting. Like in "Magnolia", P.T. Anderson gathered some great actors and said 'GO' (pretty much the same actors, too).We follow the life of Eddie Adams as he is discovered by a porn director, through his porn career, and through the aftermath as things careen out of control. Also like 'Magnolia', this movie has several subplots with some of the other porn stars, but even the subplots pretty much stay focused on Eddie/Dirk. I was real dissappointed to see yet another "how drugs can make things bad" theme show up in yet another movie, but at least some of the drug material is shown at a fresh angle.  I was really happy when the drug part turned into just another part of the movie instead of the main focus.
The "drug" lifestyle contains inherent drama, and it is almost cheating for a writer to fall back on this tired old theme just to create drama where he doesn't feel like thinking it up on his own.  (See "Requiem for a Dream", the best and hopefully the last "how drugs can make things bad" movie).
I was quite pleased to see real porn stars in the movie, and I'm not sure why (Nina Hartley, Veronica Hart, there were probably more). The 'giveaway' at the end leads you to think about the entire movie, and how this guy's entire life was merely because of one "special" thing. The fact that he does not realize his one special thing is very stupid is what makes him so tragic.

Finally saw this on IFC. Ten minutes in and I knew that Paul Thomas Anderson knows squat about the porn industry. The power is wielded not by the male performers, who are a dime a dozen, but by the female performers, who approve their on-screen partners.Anderson couldn't be bothered to do any character development, either. Why is the mother a harpie and the father a wuss? Why would Little Bill (another wuss) marry a nymphomaniac (another harpie), and assume that she'll be faithful? Why would she marry him? There is no hint of anything remotely like love between them, and his "solution" to his woes comes out of absolutely nowhere.How The Colonel's dalliances with underage girls is more repugnant than Jack recruiting an underage boy to have on-camera sex is beyond me, but when The Colonel is thrown into the poke, Jack suddenly gets a moral compass? Give me a break!How does the banker know that Buck does porn unless he was stupid enough to put that on his application? The donut shop scene was so silly and incredulous, I couldn't stop laughing!Amber wants her kid back, but does zip to show why she should regain custody! But not to worry, to Jack, she is still "the foxiest bitch in the whole world". How sweet!Rollergirl drops out of school because some bozo makes a crude gesture, then proves why she is unworthy of the respect she thinks she deserves. To add "insult" to "injury", she gets no "foxiest bitch" kudos from Jack. One other thing: why do wee see Dirk do white girls (and only white girls), but Anderson oh-so-modestly cuts away from Reed and his "Chocolate Love" just before they get their freak on?

'Boogie Nights' is my favourite movie of the 1990s, beating out some beauties by Scorsese, Ferrara, Lynch, Tarantino and Wes Anderson. I was absolutely knocked out the first time I saw it on the big screen (and this really does need to be seen at a cinema to be fully appreciated!), and still find it to be a wonderfully satisfying experience every time I re-watch it. Paul Thomas Anderson's complex script and sensational direction can hardly be faulted. The guy is a real one of a kind talent, and will hopefully continue at this high standard for many years to come. If he can keep it up, and 'Magnolia' certainly supports it, he will one day be recognized as one of the greats. The central performances of Mark Wahlberg and 70s veteran Burt Reynolds are both revelatory. Up to this point Wahlberg had movies like the enjoyable b-grade thriller under his belt, and Reynolds was long considered a washed up has-been, but both actors are more than impressive here, and help carry the movie. Wahlberg has went on to the excellent 'Three Kings' but hasn't yet really fulfilled his potential, and as for Reynolds, this is easily his greatest role to date, and one he isn't likely to top. Both are backed up by a flawless supporting cast - Julianne Moore, William H Macy, John C. Reilly, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Robert Ridgely, Heather Graham, et al. All are outstanding. This is a brilliant movie that manages to take the much ridiculed 1970s seriously, and does so with wit, humour and heart. A multi-faceted, superb example of contemporary film making. 'Boogie Nights' is a masterpiece.

Basically the GOODFELLAS of the 1970's porn industry, Paul Thomas Anderson's BOOGIE NIGHTS mirrors Martin Scorsese's mob classic from similarities such as wall-to-wall groovy tunes to deliberate homages like an end-of-the-second-act death (Joe Pesci to William H. Macy) that leads to a morbidly cascading downfall of all remaining characters, suddenly thrust and exposed into the bright-lit 1980's...Of course NIGHTS is a classic all its own - both the celebration of a porn star's life and a cautionary tale of the decadent lifestyle to get and remain there: with budding star Mark Wahlberg as porn climber Dirk Diggler...Based on John Holmes with a giant... schlong, Dirk weaves in and out of parties, drugs, family and friends, including shrieking mother Joanna Gleason, faithful sidekick-actor John C. Reilly and female co-stars Julianne Moore as the older, wiser starlet and younger Heather Graham as the deliciously cute Rollergirl...While all the performances are pretty fantastic, including Wahlberg's cocaine highs to meth-induced meltdowns (yet still neatly downplaying the central pawn role), it's Moore that really shines... not only her actual acting for the part but her character Amber Waves' bad porno acting...And last but not least the comeback of Burt Reynolds, who actually ruled this glittery decade as a mainstream superstar, finally able to push himself into a worthy character role (without trying too hard) - as the director corralling both cast and crew he remains a kind of fatherly mentor (also surrounded by hopeless black guy Don Cheadle, nightclub owner Luis Guzman, quirky boom operator Seymour Phillip Hoffman while answering to main boss Robert Ridgely)...Burt's Jack Horner wields both power and patience... yet it's his ultimately futile determination to keep shooting on film rather than settling for video that fuels both the performance and the movie's overall tribute to maverick, super-low-budget film-making - and somehow without looking or feeling either cheap or exploitative.

This is without a doubt one of my all time favourite movies. While Paul Thomas Anderson has arguably matured as a director (and many would say his later films like There Will Be Blood and The Master are better), I don't think any will replace Boogie Nights as my personal favourite from him.I first watched this back in 2012, when I was maybe just old enough to watch it, at the still pretty young age of 17. I loved (and honestly still do love) Tarantino, Scorsese, and De Palma, and you can clearly see that these directors were a big influence on Paul Thomas Anderson for this film. Some may see that as a detriment, but I don't think it's too derivative of anything else (though the opening shot does flirt with being very comparable to a similarly lengthy one-shot early on in Goodfellas).Anyway, the first time I watched this, I remember loving the movie so much that at about the halfway point, I felt that it was going by too quickly. So I paused the movie, did some other stuff for about half an hour, and then came back, because the movie felt too good to finish; I didn't want it to be over. Since then, I've never done this (admittedly odd behaviour) with any other film. Not even with the ones I've loved on the same level as Boogie Nights.What we have here is an ensemble cast- one of the best ever assembled- all operating at the top of their game, working with a young but incredibly talented director, and with an excellent screenplay and fantastic soundtrack carrying the whole thing along. Everything moves at a great pace, every actor and actress gets at least one extremely memorable scene to shine, and the film seamlessly flips around between being funny, sad, introspective, uncomfortable, and tense.I think I could give this close to a perfect score for the Alfred Molina scene alone. Without saying what happens, it's just 10 minutes of filmed perfection- so funny, so intense, so insane, and incredibly edited and scored with several 80s hits to boot. Most filmmakers won't make a scene that good in their entire career, and Paul Thomas Anderson did it in just his second feature, and managed to put said scene in a movie filled with countless other scenes that are almost all just as good.Boogie Nights is a must watch, for its great acting, stylish direction, memorable soundtrack, fantastic depiction of both the 70s AND 80s, and for its taboo yet always interesting subject matter. The fact that movies this good exist gives me an odd sense of hope, as if we can't be living in the darkest timeline if this timeline has blessed us with Paul Thomas Anderson, and he himself has subsequently blessed us with Boogie Nights.Watch it and rewatch it and rewatch it again. It never gets old, and it almost feels as though it hasn't aged a day. Boogie Nights is absolute perfection on celluloid.

Check me if I'm wrong, but isn't this movie supposed to be a loosely-based biography on the life of John Holmes and at the same time, an in-depth view of the sleaziness of the porn industry itself? Perhaps I missed something but the parallels to the character Dirk Digler are unmistakable: Holmes was discovered working as a carpenter in Ohio by a low budget filmmaker (if I'm not mistaken). He began his career in photos and worked his way into the film industry. He was later involved in the Laurel Canyon murders (scene where Digler is in the producers home), his massive use of cocaine and alcohol, abuse of his girlfriends, his detective porn series, etc. Aren't these all somewhat portrayed in this movie to some degree as it ventures through 2 decades of this industry? I gave this movie 2 stars only because of its originality in tackling a very difficult topic. However, the acting for the most part , is absolutely unconvincing. Perhaps I just associate Burt Reynolds too much with the Smokey & The Bandit movies and The Longest Yard to take him seriously as an adult film producer. Mark Wahlberg just doesn't impress me as an actor at all so it's difficult for me to accept him as a porn king. The supporting cast is OK but I must agree with those IMDb reviewers that believe this storyline simply does not move along and is in fact, a bit boring. And the grand finale: Mark Wahlberg's narration as he reveals himself from the chest down is just plain stupid. My summary of this film: a sleazy account of a sleazy industry.

This is the first movie of Mr. Anderson's that I became acquainted with. The second was "Magnolia" Obvious parallels can be drawn between the two in terms of style and presentation."Boogie Nights" is an awesome achievement and is the first movie you come to realize just how good an actor Mark Wahlberg really is. This movie elevated him from more than just another pretty face to a true actor courtesy of a magnificent performance. It was actually heartbreaking to watch at times. Of course, the fact that he was surrounded by a stellar cast certainly contributed to such an impressive performance.This is a biting look at the porn industry of the 70s and is supposedly loosely based on the life of real-life porn king, John Holmes. Nonetheless, the performances are positively phenomenal. With a cast including Don Cheadle, Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Burt Reynolds, John C. Reily, the often overlooked Luis Guzman, Heather Graham; need I say more? It is an unflinching look at the industry and a rather disturbing one to be sure. There is also no real or structured "plot" per say, but the focus is on the impact this particular lifestyle had on the personal lives of the participants and those closest to them.This is an excellent exercise in character study and is most worthy of any movie collection. Do yourself a favor and pick it up. You will NOT be disappointed.

Boogie Nights (1997) is a pretty famous film. It received a lot of praise, including many positive reviews and major award recognition like the golden globes and the Oscars. This is also the film that credited with jump starting Mark Wahlberg's Hollywood career. The film stars Mark Wahlberg, Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman, and Don Cheadle. The acting from every one of the cast members is spot on, great performances all around. I especially liked Moore, Wahlberg, and Reynolds. Don't get me wrong, everyone else is still very good, but those three just really shined in their individual roles, enough so for Moore and Reynolds to get academy award nominations and Wahlberg to be thrust into a very successful Hollywood acting career. Boogie Nights is all about the pornography industry, well actually its more about these specifics people in the pornography industry, and how it affects their lives. I liked how the movie handled the individual lives of each character, they really gave ample amount of time to every persons storyline. The dialogue is written in a way that pulls you in and keeps you engaged. I wouldn't say that Boogie Nights is a 10/10 or that it's absolutely perfect, but it is a very well made film that deserves a watch. 8/10.

There's sex, drugs, and rock n' roll aplenty in P.T. Anderson's "Boogie Nights," but what makes this film stick with its audience long after the credits roll is the strong sense of family. OK, they're a family that makes the Louds look like the Brady Bunch (obligatory '70s ref there), but they are a real family, with a father figure, a mother figure, a distracted daughter, a rebel son, and a ton of aunt, uncle, and cousin-figures that each bring their unique issues to the mix.This is a recipe for overload in any fictional medium, but particularly a movie, where tight is usually right. Any other director would have trimmed away Little Bill and Becky Barnett faster than a disco downbeat, but P.T. Anderson does a very rare and brave thing. He not only puts these characters in, but allows his camera and script to linger on each of them, way past the point of no return in anyone else's movie. But rather than boring you, the result here is a depth of detail and lived-in feeling that brings you aboard for the whole run. It's what makes P.T. Anderson a great director. Yet it may also render him incapable of making a great movie. Discipline is not his strength."Boogie Nights" is close, though. It's a very good film, a high 8 in my book, and a movie I can get lost in over and over again. Maybe it's because I came of age in the late 1970s, and see it recaptured here in a way it has never otherwise been, in all its confused, giddy, over-the-top glory. The pace of the first half of the film is languid and measured, never rushed, yet as a whole it chugs along with an assurance that makes it hard to accept the filmmaker was only making his second major picture.People talk about the opening scene, and it's very good, but there's other highlights. The pool party at Jack's, for example, is a marvel of storytelling economy, moving through several episodes without ever feeling like any are being shortchanged. We get an earful of Reed and Eddie's first meeting, awkward pauses and all, then get introduced to the Colonel and his coke-happy date, to Scotty Jay and his crush on Eddie, then Eddie rechristening himself (in a hot tub no less, how SoCal) "Dirk Diggler." All that plot is thrown at us, but the biggest takeaway for us is a sense of the characters, because P.T. Anderson is the kind of director who makes character-driven films first.There's a lot of great detail on the porn industry subculture that feels very real and lived in, and the humor is outrageous at times (Dirk's audition with Amber, Scotty Jay's obvious gawkiness around his dream boy, Buck's image issues) without ever feeling pushed or artificial. You get a lot of depth here, the kind that rewards repeat viewings.The second half of the film loses me a little. I understand the story changes with the new decade, but it suddenly becomes so oppressively dire that the viewer, once swept into the story, has to pull away from misery overload. It's hard to pick a single excessive moment, maybe its just the way all of them come together to create a perfect storm of melodrama.That said, the Raheed Jackson sequence is the standout of the movie; a brilliant way of wrapping up Dirk's odyssey and bringing us back home. The suspense build up is incredible, and it's the one time that the film's main co-star, its soundtrack, is allowed center stage, transforming banal pop smashes like "Jessie's Girl" and "Sister Christian" into something operatic, even anthemic. We know Dirk's going nuts because the guitar break in "Jessie's Girl" tells us so.P.T. Anderson is a director I will always watch, but he does let his characters' emotions carry him away (more in "Magnolia" than here, but here, too). It's a tribute to his underlying genius that even at his most baroque, he manages to draw you into his world and hold you there like nobody else in the business. He's the kind of talent that will only improve with time, and it will be a pleasure keeping tabs on his development.

Not sure what to say about this film. It's just so much fun, sometimes it's serious, it shows the problems of 70s porn industry, it wasn't the cleanest business, but it's also a very funny film. You can watch it either for fun or historical importance.

This movie is wonderful. It contains so much joy, and so much despair. The unbroken shot at the pool party is technically brilliant. Scene after scene it just gets better, and the last scene.....well, if you haven't seen it, I won't spoil it for you.

"Boogie Nights" is a lot of talking, a lot of dialogue that goes nowhere. Not much happens, and if something does happen, it is of little or no consequence for the rest of the movie. A woman overdoses on cocaine at a party - she gets carted away to a hospital and is never seen or heard of again. One character shoots two people and then himself, and that's that. There are two other shootings later, but the survivors just walk away. No police ever show up. One character does land in prison, but for something else that isn't even part of the movie.While the movie focuses on the Mark Wahlberg character, it does not exclusively follow his rise and fall as a porn actor. It occasionally follows other characters' lives (such as "Buck"'s) for no good reason, and it could have easily been an hour shorter if it hadn't digressed so many times. There are also scenes at the beginning which I suppose are meant to motivate the main character's actions - like his mother yelling at him. But he seemed to have already made up his mind anyway, so the glimpse into his home life doesn't really add much information, and since his parents are never seen again, it is yet another loose thread in a movie that has a lot of them.There is a lot of drug use and some of the main characters spend quite a lot of time acting drugged out. But except in the case of that one overdose, which is treated as no big deal and not followed up on, the drug use seems to be of little consequence.At best, this movie feels like a somewhat boring and rather tedious pseudo-documentary of the porn industry in the late 70's and early 80's. It even contains the making of a (pseudo-)documentary of the main character's career! Since a few other reviewers have commented that the documentary aspect of the movie is not very good (i.e. it is far from a true representation of the porn industry), I don't really know what's left of this movie that one might recommend.

reviews.review_title: A movie about the sex industry that tells a solid tale
reviews.content: Boogie Nights was for me a spectacular movie. What I was expecting and what I got were very far apart, but I liked what I saw better than the preconceived notions I had before seeing the film. Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore, Burt Reynolds, Heather Graham, John C. Reilly, and the rest of the ensemble cast put on a great performance for this movie, and I liked how it told a cohesive story from the good beginnings to the tragic middle to the sort of redemptive ending. I liked the whole main narrative, but of particular interest to me was the subplot that surrounded the character played by Don Cheadle. I think that one could've been a story of its own. For a movie about the 70's sex industry, there was surprisingly, a lesser amount of sex than you might have thought there would be. I think the decision to do the movie that way paid off in more than avoiding an NC-17 rating. With the sex not as explicit, there was more time to focus on character development and plot. I remember thinking to myself that although not exactly the two parents, 2.2 kids, picket fence and garage stereotype, that the characters were a family, with all the good and bad events that happen in a time frame, and they for the most part managed to survive all that was thrown at them.

reviews.review_title: Leave it in the 70's with flared trousers, afro haircuts and Starsky and Hutch.
reviews.content: Paul Thomas Anderson's tale of the 1970's porn industry in America is probably okay if you were around at the time, personally I thought it was rubbish. For the first 40 minutes or so I was actually quite intrigued with the story of a young bus boy (Mark Wahlberg) who meets a top porn film director (Burt Reynolds) who sets out to make him a star in the seedy world of pornography, drugs and disco. The problem is that after 40 minutes the story takes a nose dive and the result is a total mess. From then on you have to sit through over 2 hours of total mishmash as Wahlberg and Reynolds get more irritating by the minute.  Not even the presence of screen beauties Julianne Moore and Heather Graham make you care what happens as the script plods along through the years. All in all another film which is very over rated. Anderson's first feature HARD EIGHT is far better value for money, and is there really a need for that final scene?

reviews.review_title: The Shortest Three Hours of My Life
reviews.content: In a nutshell, "Boogie Nights" is a rare movie in that steps out of the lines in terms of categorization. The movie surfaces around the pornography business. Even though there is a fair amount of steaming seductive scenes, it's content is not overly gratuitous. There is a lot of humour delivered here, it's mostly dark and at times a bit hard to swallow at times. A plethora of the settings and situations were not intended to be entertaining, but one couldn't help but to be intrigued by the scenes as they were very entertaining in spite of it almost three hour duration.The structure of the film is not very perpendicular that makes this movie stand up above the rest. There is no spoon-feeding in terms of delivery by director/writer Paul Thomas Anderson, instead it's customized to play with your mind which is obscure in the film business. Can anyone name me a moment in a movie where they install a very lustful sex scene and turn it into one very mundane effort that continues on for so long? "Boogie Nights" succeeds in its attempt to show how unglamourous the sex industry really is as it's nothing more than all in a day's work.Set in the 1970's and 1980's, principal characters in the movie include Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg who was very dominant in his role), who is taken by awe by a porno guru Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds who was also quite impressive) as he transforms Adams into a porn star and goes as far as to change his name to Dirk Diggler.Diggler's rise in the porn star business is weaved by other performers that share the world he's gotten himself into. There's the doped up porn queen Amber Waves (Julianne Moore), who's like a mentor to Dirk because she is off limits from seeing her own biological child. John C. Reilly was a standout as Dirk's best pat Reed Rothschild. Heather Graham was brilliant and beautiful as Rollergirl and feels her comfort zone is when she performs using her roller-skates. Then there's Buck Swope (Don Cheadle), who likes to dress like Gene Autry and has further ambitions to open up a video store. And finally there's Little Man, (William H. Macy) who has bottled up anger because his wife constantly commits infidelity on a regular basis and shows absolute no remorse for her actions. Director Anderson follows his narration much to the tradition of Robert Altman by executing his story in a vignette approach.The constant rags-to-riches story as a whole is both funny, terrifying, melancholy, but still succeeds in lifting your hearts at the the right time. One of the more engaging scenes is when Dirk cuts a deal with a druggie. The problem is the crack he's selling is superficial and the dealer's pad is filled with goons while this is happening, firecrackers are being lit all to the song of Night Ranger's "Sister Christian". This scene was perfectly executed that the fear and tension comes to life and while you're watching the scene the fear takes charge into the rooms you're sitting at. If thats not top notch directing, than what is? The performances were brilliant, but it was Reynolds and Moore that had the strongest performances. The feeling of the 1970's and 1980's looks very authentic (even the poster of Cheryl Tiegs on Dirk's wall looks groovy), and the music is truly far out. It definitely is one of the best films of the 1990's and though Anderson may have patted himself on the back a little too much, all the flaws can be forgiven easily due to the vibrant energy and the engaging performances.

reviews.review_title: Great movie about hard to touch subjects
reviews.content: I knew about BOOGIE NIGHTS for years because of the subjects it discusses and also because it's considered some sort of cult movie. Last March I finally saw it and I had to say that I was very impressed and it stood to my expectations.It begins in 1977 with Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg) that lives with his abusive mother and works as a dish-washer in a night club when is noticed by porn movies director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) who auditions him instantly. After the upteenth discussion with his mother, Adams leaves home and moves in with Horner in his mansion. Adams soon changes name in Dirk Diggler and becomes an overnight sensation because of his charisma, good looks and big sausage. With the money he manages to buy a new house, a huge new wardrobe and a Corvette. With his friend Reed Rothchild (John Reilly), Dirk stars in a series of action-themed porn films and use cocaine on a regular basis. Because of this, Dirk fails to having boners, has frequent mood swings and becomes irritated with a new adult actor Jack has assumed. After lots of disaventures in 1984 Dirk will return to his work.The direction by Paul Thomas Anderson is great not surprisingly, and the cast is full of great names in outstanding performances: Mark Wahlberg as the young porn star that goes from rags to riches thanks to his cocaine addiction but will end it in an unexpected way, Burt Reynolds as a adult movie mogul and a father figure to Wahlberg, John Reilly as Wahlberg's best friend who becomes a magician after the end of his cocaine addiction, Julianne Moore as a smoldering porn actress, Alfred Molina as an irritable drug dealer, William Macy as an assistant director always cheated by his wife, Don Cheadle as a black porn star that survives a shootout and escapes with some money... where do you find such a cast? Only in your best dreams. The soundtrack was also great, full of great songs of the years the movie is set (from 1977 to 1984) and the cinematography was kinetic and crisp. The script was very smart with lots of clever dialogue translated well to film.In substance, this is some sort of exploration of the adult entertainment industry and the American Dream that has never been seen before 1997. Not to be missed if you are real movie fans that sometimes watch movies about daring subjects.

reviews.review_title: I'm a star, I'm a star, I'm a star
reviews.content: "Boogie Nights" is one of those rare movies that manages to find the perfect balance between comedy and drama. I mean, there are a lot of laughs throughout, but you always laugh with a lump in your throat. This movie just bathes in a general feeling of false optimism: occasionally it looks like everyone's having the time of their life, but it's all just an illusion. Particularly the ending, which I can't go into too much detail about, captures that idea perfectly. At first it's pretty fulfilling, but the ending gets less happy with every second you think about it. Apart from being a great, bittersweet character study, the movie also creates tremendous amounts of tension when it needs to. The scene with the drug deal that goes awry might just be the most bone-chilling scene I've ever watched. Everything about it is just perfect, right down to the use of silly 80s pop songs as the soundtrack. I was drenched in sweat after watching that part, magnificent how it gradually builds up to its unexpected climax. The only bad thing I can really say about this movie is that the practical effect in the last shot is laughably unconvincing, but even that's not really a criticism given that I can imagine them doing it on purpose. Awesome movie, one of the best movies the 1990s had to offer.

reviews.review_title: best film of the past 25 years
reviews.content: After Pulp Fiction, it seemed that no one could top Tarantino, but along comes Paul Thomas Anderson with Boogie Nights. Not since Orson Welles made Citizen Kane has a young director shown such a command of the film-making medium.Like Citizen Kane, Boogie Nights is a thinly-veiled biopic of a famous figure, in Kane's case, William Randolph Hearst, in Boogie Night's case, John Holmes. Both films mock particular film-making styles, in Kane with News On The March, in Boogie Nights porno films. There is even the revelation of the heart of the character in the final "money" shot -- Rosebud is revealed in Kane, Dirk is exposed in Boogie. Both films feature sit-down interviews with other characters discussing the main character. Both Kane and Diggler come from broken homes, and both destroy themselves chasing their respective dreams. Diggler even has his version of Xanadu. Neither attains happiness despite the monetary success.Kane's political aspirations are blown to Hell by his passion for Susan and her impossible opera career, while Dirk is destroyed by his passion for coke.

"Boogie Nights" takes us back to the late seventies where we trace the path of a rising star on the porn scene. We are treated to an intimate look at the ins and outs of the porno industry as we follow Dirk Diggler from overnight success to inevitable decline.The first thing that must be said about this film is that the cast is outstanding. It's character actor heaven with the likes of John C. Reilly, William H. Macy, Luis Guzman, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Philip Baker Hall and more. Not only that, there are others (like Mark Wahlberg) who deliver the best performances of their careers.However, all of this acting talent would have gone to waste if the screenplay wasn't up to snuff. Luckily, Anderson's script was good enough to snag an Oscar nomination. It contains plenty of humour although the tone of the film gradually darkens until the characters hit rock bottom. Overall, the story is nicely balanced and presents a fascinating view of this 'family' of pornographers.Anderson's direction is well handled though some might feel that he was just a little flashier than necessary. On the audio front, the soundtrack is yet another component of the film that deserves high praise. Vintage songs are featured prominently and the selections show a keen sense of taste and aptness.All in all, I'd rank this as one of my favorite films of the 90's. However, I can see that the subject matter and approach may not appeal to all. Nevertheless, I think that this is Anderson's best film (so far).

reviews.review_title: Is this what the fuss was all about?
reviews.content: This film is awful. I cannot believe that so many people thought it was wonderful. Trite and ponderous with few likable characters it seems to me to be floundering in its attempt to portray the 70's. Mark Wahlberg is an OK actor but does not convince in this and as as for it being a glimpse of Burt Reynolds best work I will stick with Deliverance for that. A good cast has been tragically wasted in a movie which should have been better written and edited. The constant music soundtrack of 70's hits does not make it any more authentic- feeling. It really just goes to show that actors are only really as good as the scripts they are given to work with and the direction they are given.

I really enjoyed Boogie Nights. I would normally think twice about giving such movie an 8, but I think it was well deserved. One of Wahlbergs early performances that put him on the map. He kind of played the young dumb stupid up and comer. The rest of the cast was funny. It was a pretty deep movie. I enjoyed it a lot.Highly recommend8 stars

Definitely an overrated and over hyped movie that was slightly disappointing. It suffers from no central plot line and just several somewhat meaningless people having their own little side stories. It could have been better and easier to follow. The best part is all of the notable actors being together so early in their career.

Good direction and acting is wasted on a deceptively witty script. Lurking behind some well-written dialogue is a mess of a movie that tries to go in too many directions.A hypnotic and continuous camera can't make up for a muddled story. I don't understand the choices the director made on the final cut. This movie is too long and lacks focus. It's a mood piece, full of dramatic irony without any real drama for balance. When SOMETHING finally happens to make things interesting there is no basis for it - no setup, no motivation. Just a plot point that is supposed to happen to move things along. Director Anderson knows how to handle a camera, but he should let someone else write the script.

reviews.review_title: It's my big d*ck and I say when we roll.
reviews.content: Burt Reynolds immediately grounds us within the 70s world of pornography that seems to be at first all glitz and glamour. He is the most assured of this wild, sweeping cast - a porno king played straight. He takes his porn serious, thinks of it as an art-form, and aspires to elevate the medium to new levels even as the technological shift threatens to move from big screens to small. Not only is he the overseeing director, but he is the daddy of this f*cked up family, and even as his kingdom falls around him his arms will be wide open welcoming back his children and telling them to clean their rooms. But of course, this is not about him, but about Wahlberg's Eddie who strives to make it big after years of emotional abuse from a stunted upbringing. Anderson makes the porn star life as frenetic and glamorous as possible - from the opening take that sweeps around and unveils the crowded bar, to the whip pans and frantic zooms and camera light- bulbs flashing from all directions in the frenzied montage that says "you've made it". Of course, it's nothing that Scorsese hasn't already done before. And it seems that Anderson likes to pick and choose his tragedies as he pleases in order to serve the narrative; early on there is a hilarious encounter with a washed-up star that has just seen his second OD in just two days, and although this is foreshadowing, Anderson can't help but show this through a comedic lens because of the hazy, orgasmic high from Dirk Diggler's rise to stardom. Later, when the script calls for his fall from grace, drug addiction is again the vice, but it doesn't unfold in any real capacity. It's like Anderson needed a stereotypical plot device to engineer the darker moments and just throws cocaine at the screen without actually engaging with it at any deeper level. And that goes also for Macy's character, who exits with the most self-indulgent little nod you might see from a suicide scene. The rest of the 'family' have their own f*cked up problems, although the theory that leaving the family results in tragedy doesn't seem to hold up when you point the camera at Julianne Moore. Her own storyline is tragic enough; having lost out on custody of her actual kid, she spends her days codling and mothering Dirk as a way of compensating for her previous loss. But Anderson feels the need to condescend these heart-wrenching emotions by focusing on her sobbing after another failed attempt to win back visitation rights. How can we pity someone when we do not know the whole story, but are merely pushed into the act of sympathy because pornography is somehow being demonised? It works a little better for Don Cheadle's Buck, where we see the visible frustration at being not taken seriously because he acted in a few pornos.It seems that Anderson grows the story from these characters, the live-wire humour, the zany, half believable situations they find themselves in. There are smaller moments of characterisation that are allowed to stand for themselves. The sweet little "ki-yaa" that Buck and Jessie share in the car, both having somehow escaped from the toxicity of the family and made a life for themselves (although even then Anderson has to shove the most inexplicably coincidental bit of violence to kickstart it). And Heather Graham's Rollergirl, a bundle of sexual energy that glides around everywhere in her skates and almost makes us forget she is just a kid still in school. But if you pull away for the bigger picture it seems all too inconsequential. Philip Seymour Hoffman has a heartbreaking moment, and then just sort of disappears. Wahlberg's rise and fall seems completely determined by the script rather than actual cause and effect in the narrative - when he can no longer get hard, the cause is because of his drug addiction, but this hasn't been expanded on, but merely presented as a symptom of burn out in the high stakes porno industry. And Anderson adds dissolves to the crucial scene, instead of letting the built-up frustration from Wahlberg take its natural toll (this might be because Wahlberg has never really been a great actor, but at the time he seemed fresh). Why not let the film roll, like he does in that tense cooker-pot situation where the fireworks keep making the group jump and they slowly realise this is a bad idea? Wahlberg sits there frozen for a good 45 seconds as he comes to the realisation. It's also one of the only scenes where Anderson's use of 80s pop hits doesn't seem like an ironic touch (although that just might be because of Molina's fantastically unhinged performance - "He's Chinese...). These are the worn out tracks from the jukebox, the tunes that everyone knows even if they didn't experience that era. It's phony.

Paul Thomas Anderson makes another hit! BOOGIE NIGHTS is exciting, sexy, dramatic and comedic. It has every aspect of American film in it. Anderson is a great writer and director and BOOGIE NIGHTS deserved an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture and Best Actor - Mark Wahlberg, and should have won Best Supporting Actress - Julianne Moore.BOOGIE NIGHTS is filled with many different types of characters. Mark Wahlberg turns star in this picture with twelve inches to his name. As Dirk Diggler, he becomes a great porn star with the help of Jack Horner - Burt Reynolds, Rollergirl - Heather Graham, Amber Waves - Julianne Moore and many more. BOOGIE NIGHTS is centred around all these characters and the hardships they go through to be porn stars and what happens to them when their stardom and lives collapse.With drugs, nudity, and violence, BOOGIE NIGHTS is an all right movie. Of course it's not for children, but it is an interesting sight to see. Even if you take away the sex, if you think about it BOOGIE NIGHTS has an interesting story line. Thumbs up to PAUL THOMAS ANDERSON. I hope the best for him. MAGNOLIA and HARD EIGHT are interesting and I believe that Anderson, by the end of his career will have a couple of Academy Awards. I know that if he asked me to be in one of his pictures, I know I would accept, not even looking at the script. GO P.T. ANDERSON!!!

This movie is so enjoyeble from beginning to end, you have seen the "casual person gets famous and gets eruppted by all money and drugs"-story before but none quite like this one.What makes this movie perfect is first of all the characters, you care about the maincharacters aswell as the sidecharacters, and they are all portrayted phenomenal (this is whalbergs best performence).Second of all comes the involving drama, the storytelling. Its all very well put together, it makes you feel disturbed at the right times, it makes you laugh at the right times and it makes you feel good at the right times.

An excellent movie! I really enjoyed it. It was a bit disturbing at parts, but still very good. You'll notices great performances given by Burt Renyolds, Julianne Moore, Don Cheadle , John C. Reilly, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Robert Ridgley and Alfred Molina (considering he had a very tiny role, he really did alot with it). I wasn't too thrilled about Mark Wahlberg's performance. In my opinion I don't think he is a very good actor. He always plays the same part in every film he stars in. The directing and writing in the film are absolutley outstanding. I was especially taken by the direction of the donut shop shoot out that appears about 2 hours into the movie. If you are looking for an interesting movie to watch, rent or buy Boogie Nights. Be sure to get the New Line Platinum Series. Grade: A

reviews.review_title: Forget Titanic! This is the Best Picture of '97!
reviews.content: Paul Thomas Anderson's Boogie Nights is my second favorite film of all time. It is just such a cool and great movie that I can't help but watch it all the time!I first saw it a year ago last summer. I recorded it because I knew it was gonna be cool. And sure enough, I got a great film!I hate when people say, "Oh, Boogie Nights is that movie about porn that everyone's talking about." Sure, Boogie Nights is about porn, but it is not a porno itself. It follows a colorful group of porn makers: the stars (Dirk Diggler, Reed Rothchild, Amber Waves, Jessie St. Vincent, e.t.c) and the filmmakers (Jack Horner, Little Bill, Kurt) through six very colorful years: '77 to '83. There we see their heyday when an unknown teen, Eddie (Mark Whalberg) is transformed into Dirk Diggler. Then we see their fall (Dirk is almost replaced by his director, Jack [Burt Reynolds]). I would tell you more, but...well, you just have to see it for yourself.This is my and my best friend, Tony's favorite film. We've both seen it a million times and know it by heart: from "Jackie, Jack, Jack" to "I'm a star of a star of a star".With colorful characters like Rollergirl (sexy Heather Graham), Dirk Diggler, Rahad Jackson, e.t.c and great performances from Graham, Reynolds (I'm shocked), Whalberg, Moore, and Macy added to writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson's pure artwork, forget Titanic! This is the best picture of 1997 and I believe one of the best films of all time.GO SEE BOOGIE NIGHTS!

reviews.review_title: A Brilliant, funny , bitter sweet movie.A Classic.
reviews.content: Boogie Nights is one of those movies that you can watch over and over again.In the Vain of Goodfellas and Casino.It is a movie that will stand the test of time . The Film is about a young man ,Dirk Digler(Mark Wahlberg) who finds himself being recruted into the pornography buisiness by a film maker,Jack Horner(Burt Reynolds) because of his huge talent,and i'm not talking about his acting ability!. The movie takes us through his innocent beginings into porn and how it goes very wrong. For me this film is not so much about the story but it is about the acting,Mark Wahlberg,Burt Reynolds ,Julianne Moore,Heather Graham and William H Macey are all magnificent. At the start of the film you cant help but really like the people, they all have there own personalities. They all start of as a sexy group of people and after the drugs kick in they become inwardly ugly. In a way the film does take a down turn when their personalities change simply because you dont quite like them as much as before and that says a lot for the cast. The way the film takes us through the seventies and early eighties by bombarding us with a fantastic soundtrack can only be applauded. 9 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: I Can't Believe it's Not Scorsese !
reviews.content: I gave this movie a eight because I later discovered that certain shots and dialogue were plagiarized from other films. That's not saying though that this wasn't a kick-ass, well-executed film! I heard so many opinions (a lot of them negating) over the years. And it never occurred to me ever to write a review about the most profound film that rocked my world since the original "Star Wars" did when I was six. I read numerous reviews on this site that were both good and bad, but they ALL said that this was a powerful film.To this day, I always feel as if I'm in a sudden time-warp when viewing this, and that this is actually happening within the years of 1977-1984. There is so much attention to detail and dialogue in this movie, and there are never gags or contrived period-piece references for the sake of telling the audience "hey, this is in fact 1977! Look at the hair! Look at the disco ball! Listen to the music!..." Films like "The Wedding Singer" are just loaded with them! The film is about the rise and the fall of Dirk Diggler/Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg)- a high school dropout working a dead-end job with a care-free attitude that helps him glide into the porno industry with ease. Discovered at a nightclub by Jack Horner (played by the charismatic Burt Reynolds), he quickly meets and associates with other actors at Jack's house, who are in fact damaged goods with porn as their guise. They have been outcasted from society at one point in time, and really hold on to their dignity through this and drugs. It's not long before Dirk makes it big because of the size of his tool, and his notoriety continues throughout the first half of the film. William H. Macy's actions on New Year's Eve of 1979 set a darker tone for the bottom-half of the movie, and each main and supporting character is systematically "punished" in some way. Beginning with the slow, pudgy grip/gopher Scotty (Phillip Seymour Hoffmann), who makes an unsuccessful homosexual pass at Dirk; the beforehand mentioned assistant director, Little Bill (William H. Macy) suicides; their producer/distributor, the Colonel James (the late Robert Ridgely) is jailed for statutory rape; Dirk himself gets subsequently fired (for exploding into a volatile, verbal, drug-induced outburst with Reynolds); Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly) is punished by accompanying Dirk in his downward spiral with cocaine and bad luck; Buck (Don Cheadle) is turned down for a loan because of his involvement with porn; Jack is subjugated to making movies on videotape instead of film, thus the films seem to lose their zest and become numb and banal. Amber (Julianne Moore) loses a custody battle with her son; Rollergirl (Heather Graham) is raped and degraded by a former classmate; Dirk is beaten up (another honorable mention); and Todd Parker (Thomas Jane) is shot and killed.The film has numerous subplots, long takes and long-shots, a phenomenal music score (where they play almost the whole song in every scene), day-glo dialogue from everyone (you feel as if the actors aren't acting), and it is all an infinitely a sad story. After Dirk's expulsion, he crawls back to Jack and is forever enslaved back into the porno industry. The film also echoes pieces of John Holmes's life (not to mention pieces from his films), Martin Scorsese's movies along with Jonathan Demme.This is the only picture from P.T. Anderson I really like. To me, I thought "Magnolia" and "Punch-Drunk Love" were just bores. He has an affinity with good dialogue, but I notice that he brings in the same team (both cast and crew) to each film. It's good and bad, but when a director is comfortable (which he seems to be with his little gang), they're not good directors. Those movies seem to be proof of it. Nevertheless, "Boogie Nights" is a powerful and important film that both filmmakers and critics should use as a template to continue with their careers."Ever see that movie 'Star Wars'? People tell me I look like Han Solo."I laugh every time I hear that !

reviews.review_title: Another masterpiece from Paul Thomas Anderson
reviews.content: After being stunned by the subtle artistry of Hard Eight everyone knew that Paul Thomas Anderson's sophomoric directorial effort would have to push cinema limits. And boy did it ever. It not only pushed aesthetic limits, but the limits of what you can actually get away with in movies. Boogie Nights is a film set in the 1970's adult film industry. Dirk Diggler wants to be somebody and he gets his chance after finding his way into the porn industry via a director named Jack Horner. Jack is a director with vision and he wants to elevate pornography into an art form rather than just, well... what porn is intended for. The film spans about ten years, chronicling the rise and fall of Dirk Diggler and the various characters he meets along the way. It's a fanatical ensemble piece with all sorts of spunk and nuance to it that sets it apart anything we've ever witnessed.The IMDb page for Boogie Nights wrongly categorizes it as a drama. This film is absolutely a comedy that poses as a drama at times, and it knows it is doing so. You have to face facts. The characters we are involved with here are all sorts of shady people. They are a bunch of sex crazed, coked up, short tempered sociopaths, and thats what makes it all so much fun. There is nothing like watching a coked up Alfred Molina run around in his underwear shooting at Mark Wahlberg and John C. Reily. The film does get dramatic at times, but there is that constant subtle undertone that says, "None of this is really supposed to be taken seriously. It's all for the pure insanity and the fun." Anderson has really done something ingenious with his script here. Jack Horner wants to create pornography with a story in order to draw in his audience in a different kind of way. He wants to enthrall his audience in the story and then entertain them with the porn side. But the result of his aspirations is the most hysterically awful plot lines and characters that you would expect from a porno. And what is even more hilarious is how the talented actors in the film pull off God awful porn acting perfectly. And the great irony of it all is that everyone else in the film is blown away by it and they treat it like master class material. There is a scene at the Adult Film Awards where Dirk Diggler wins multiple awards for his work, while we have just been witnessing how hilariously awful the acting is. The satirical levels on which this story works are just brilliant.But not only does Anderson show off his script writing and story telling abilities in Boogie Nights, he also proves that a great script can be raised to all new heights when it is directed so incredibly well. Anderson's eye for long tracking shots and aesthetically fantastic pans is displayed here in every fashion. The film's opening shot, which starts outside of a night club, follows Jack Horner and his wife in, then proceeds to show many of the main characters in the night club is almost three minutes long. But he doesn't use all of his talent up there. We are treated to plenty more of these brilliant shots throughout the entire two and a half hour film which never gets dull and never lets up on the crazed hilarity.Boogie Nights is a film that is driven so steadfastly well by everything in the film. Anderson's script is fantastic and it tells a wildly entertaining story. His direction moves the film along at a brisk yet deliberate pace which develops every subplot just as fully as the main plot. And he also directs his fantastic actors with the same level of keen poignancy. Every performance in this film is incredible, even the brief cameos from huge names like Phillip Baker Hall or the great Alfred Molina. There's never a dull moment in Boogie Nights, probably due to the fact that every last bit of the film is unlike anything you've ever seen before. Paul Thomas Anderson took some major risks making a film about porn, yet he does it with so much satirical class and hilarious playfulness that it is difficult to dislike the film whether you find the subject matter offensive or not.

reviews.review_title: Much To Admire, But Didn't Move Me
reviews.content: This is one of those films that I was ridiculously overdue in seeing; finally getting to it, it made me laugh, it gripped me and as with all PTA's films it was technically flawless with excellent performances. I wasn't expecting it to be quite such an effective tragicomedy about a bunch of ludicrously self-obsessed people; and perhaps because it was that, it didn't move me the way a film like The Phantom Thread did. I have no doubt it has rewatch value, and there are lots in it pointing toward his even better films to come.

reviews.review_title: It Ain't Called Boogie Nights for Nothing
reviews.content: For more than 20 years, Paul Thomas Anderson has proven to be quite the unique filmmaker for his themes of alienation and loneliness, flawed characters, and distinct visual styles. So it's no surprise that I'd be discussing the film that helped kickstart his claim to fame, Boogie Nights. Although the title might suggest a film about disco, do not be fooled, for this is more about the pornography industry. In spite of such a crazy idea for a film, it actually works well in its favor, because a film like this could not have worked well enough without a little bit of craziness.The movie centers around a teenage busboy named Eddie Adams, who gets discovered by porn director Jack Horner and becomes a world famous adult-film star, Dirk Diggler. Despite succeeding in flying colors, Dirk begins to develop a severe ego and drug problem, which results in his downfall. Admittedly, the story itself is the typical underdog turned superstar plot where a nobody is turned into a somebody overnight but then enters a decline due to certain issues, making the viewing experience a little predictable. However, what elevates the film from its premise is how it depicts the porn business. As the film is set in the late 70s and early 80s, it displays a certain nostalgic representation of how the industry was when it came to classic exotic features. By depicting the business side of these movies, the viewing experience is set more in the shadows than the spotlight, and it's admirable to see the behind the scenes debacles of porno filmmaking.In terms of characters, Eddie is a pretty good representation of aspiring low-key actors who let their career get the best of them, and Mark Wahlberg carries enough charisma to make him charmingly energized in spite of his shortcomings. However, the character who steals the show is Jack Horner. Played wonderfully by Burt Reynolds (may he rest in peace), the man presents himself as sort of a father figure for a bizarre family of porn stars, yet he often seems more subdued with the idea of it, down to never shown having sex himself. In addition, Amber Waves is a former housewife turned porn star who is in desperate need of seeing her child again, and Julianne Moore is able to carry as much sympathy towards her character as she does with her seductive presence. Whenever Amber is with Eddie, she practically becomes a mother figure towards him, even becoming generally concerned for him during their sex scenes.Despite being about adult features, Anderson cleverly limits the nudity in the film, making the reveal of Eddie's dynamite dong all the more surprising. It's often funnier when you approach things like that subtly without revealing much, and the film takes full advantage of that, including a particular scene at a pool party where Dirk shows the financer of the features his thing offscreen for only a few seconds. My only main complaint with the film is the few subplots revolving around the supporting cast. I understand the influence of Nashville and Pulp Fiction with the variety of characters displaying differentiating human qualities in a louche world, but I personally found them to be a tad distracting and rather fluctuating in pace. Then again, at the end of the day, this film is about the fluctuating unpredictabilities that life can offer in such an infamous industry, so I suppose it fits within the context of the story.We'll probably never get another movie like this again, and we don't need to. Overall, Boogie Nights is a great commentary on the adult-film business that paints itself with a bizarre story about the crazy ups and downs of making a living, a cast of highly flawed albeit understanding characters, and a wonderful tribute to the glory days of porno. If you're into films that beautifully explore and comment on a particular subject of art and film, then this is just for you. Although given its subject matter and dark content, just be warned that this is not a movie for the sensitive viewers. If there's one thing you will get out of this movie though, it's that those who live by the sword also die by it, because people like Dirk Diggler may end up selling their dignity for the right and wrong reasons.

reviews.review_title: No effects nor action, but still pretty good
reviews.content:
This is one of the few movies, that succeed in entertaining without having to fall back on monstrous effects or a lot of shooting and I really admire all the people who worked on this film for that. Nowadays that is hard to come by I mean look at the most successful movie of that year 1997 and what do you get Titanic (effects), JP:2 (effects), MIB (effects), Tomorrow Never Dies (action), Air Force One (effects) and then comes the first one that does not have effects nor a lot of action and that's As Good as it Gets. You see my point here either there is a lot of action, effects or comedy in a film, otherwise it is not good (at least at the box  office) and that is why this one did not get huge sums into the cash register. OK this is maybe not as good as Titanic and some of the others, but I think you can watch movies like this more often than for example MIB or Air Force One, which are enjoyable at the cinema and then become boring fast. Still this is not a great film, but who am I to be the judge of that ? See for yourselves, but I know not many 155 minute films with so few action scenes are this good. Not a giant, not a small, but a deserved
7 out of 10

Paul Thomas Anderson is without a doubt the greatest screenwriter/director tat has ever made a movie. This movie isn't even about the porno. It is about these great characters that move through the hardest times in american history. When bad things are happening to them, the adience feels bad with them.
