reviews.review_title: How did they manage to make this film so boring?
reviews.content: Most people have a view on pornography... except it would seem Paul Thomas Anderson. This film fails to tackle it's subject matter with any depth, it is neither funny, moving or shocking. It could and should have been all three. Instead it looks like PTA spent too long in film school instead of the real world. I kept waiting for the film to start... it eventually seemed to get going an hour and a half into the film. But by then it was too late... I didn't care about any of the characters and it descended into formulaic pap about divorced mum misses kids, good time girl wanting an education, arrogant stud turning cheap tricks, arrogant film maker having to face up to reality. A slice of violence and a happy ending. This is pure vomitsville...

reviews.review_title: summarizing the overview of 70's & 80's adult films
reviews.content: Boogie Nights deals with the adult movies of 70's and 80's.Some may take it as rather iconoclastic because of its topic,but what I conclude is that the movie demands mature audience,one who loves true cinema.Director Paul Anderson has kept the content quite straight and tried to explain the ups and downs of adult films & characters related with it in 70's & 80's.What really significance is as the storyline progresses we tends to observe the change that director has tried to show in the pornographic industry with growing days..............The story is about 17 year old Eddie(Mark Wahlberg)who rocks the adult film industry in late 70's.Latter emphasis is given on how his life changes and his relations with characters around him.The film has other big casts too.Julianne Moore is quite effective as veteran pornstar.Heather Graham too fits in her role.The running time of movie is around 160 minutes,but its being effectively managed which has prevented the audience to get bored. Overall the movie is being quite successful to analyze this topic,and by far I don't remember any movie handling this subject quite effectively as done by Boogie Nights .

reviews.review_title: One of the 10 best movies of the '90s.
reviews.content: This film is a masterpiece.  It was exhilarating from beginning to end. Writer-director Paul Thomas Anderson's story about a porn star is told with style, grace, humor, even poignancy.  The actors and the characters they play are all first-rate, including Mark Wahlberg in the lead, who proves himself a solid actor and can carry a film.  Burt Reynolds gives perhaps his best performance ever as a porno director who discovers Wahlberg.  The film recreates the late 70s and early 80s with dead-on accuracy, from the disco scene that begins the film to Wahlberg's Don Johnson "Miami Vice" outfit that he wears in the final scene.  Most regular moviegoers who see this film will no doubt compare it to PULP FICTION, but it really has much more in common with the films of Robert Altman and Martin Scorsese.  The film is a triumph in style.  The opening tracking shot that begins the film is just as impressive as the ones in THE PLAYER and ABSOLUTE BEGINNERS.  The editing by Dylan Tichenor is simply phenomenal.  I couldn't believe the editing didn't receive an Oscar nomination (GOOD WILL HUNTING was a better edited film?!). The best scene in the film has to be the one with the firecrackers.  I had butterflies in my stomach because the scene is incredibly intense.  When I saw the film a second time, I had the exact same reaction to the scene. Unfortunately, it may not have the same impact on TV as it did in a theater with good stereo sound.  It's a shame that many people didn't see this movie during its theatrical run, because it is the best way to watch it. Anderson's use of widescreen will suffer on TV (so get the DVD or a letterbox tape).  It is amazing how easy Anderson makes it all look, because this is only his second film.  The music, sets, costumes, photography, offbeat characters, sex, violence, happiness and heartbreak are captured by a guy who is clearly in love with filmmaking.

reviews.review_title: A wild ride of a movie!
reviews.content: It's hard to know where to begin with writing thoughts about Boogie Nights. It's epic in so many ways and crams a lot into its 2.5 hour runtime - most of which is awesome.You can't help but get caught up in the infectious party atmosphere of the late 70s setting. The fashion, the lifestyles, the music, the sex, the drugs. It's all here in large amounts. The soundtrack for Boogie Nights is one of the best you'll come across.It features so many big name actors delivering some of their best performances at once. The characters are unique, real and often quite likeable. Drugs, guns, sex, violence, darkness, humour - there's really a bit of everything here for everyone.Burt Reynolds was perfectly cast in his role as Jack Horner. Mark Wahlberg delivered his best career performance and made his character surprisingly likeable. I think I fell in love with Julianne Moore in this - her intimate scenes with Wahlberg were standouts. William H Macy, Don Cheadle and Philip Seymour Hoffman through in ample doses of hilarity whenever they were on screen too.Many memorable moments, and at the same time a complete blur too - which is fitting for the time and place it's set. Recommend. It was a good time and wild ride!

Attention, this contains spoilersPaul Thomas Anderson has constructed a wonderful social commentary on life in the 70s and early 80s, an intricate look at family life and values, a story of hope, innocence, self destruction, and redemption, containing some of the most original sub plots and sub stories all through the eyes of a PORN STAR! The fact that this movie is about the porn industry and one of its most famous stars leads many people to reject it, or not look deeper into what the film is really about. It starts off with sheer energy, the music, the dancing, the fabulous opening sequence filmed without any cuts by a very under rated director. the movie rolls on, introducing the viewers to many characters and their own personal problems. This is where the many interesting subplots occur. William H. Macy's character, little bill is struggling through life as his wife is constantly cheating on him without remorse, this story is sad, but funny and very ironic. Other characters such as Buck played bashfully by Don Chedale is trying to start his own business, you have Jack Horner, a man wanting to make a "film" a man who rejects moving to videotape, and many more. The most fascinating sub plot, is not really a subplot, and some might argue with me, but it keeps your interest one way or another. i am talking about how everybody in the movie is so fascinated with Dirk Diggler's special friend. all throughout the movie you have people seeing it and the look on their face is always priceless. for this very reason, the viewers want to see it as well. it seems to be always just out of the frame, i found this to be a very odd way of keeping the viewers alert. it is not revealed until the end.The acting is superb, this one of the best casts since the godfather, everyone in the picture plays his or her roles perfectly. PT Anderson's script is funny, intelligent, and most importantly...real. his direction is good, i enjoy his many long shots, it gives the film a sense of authenticity, allowing the viewers to completely enter this shocking world.it is fun to watch, great music, great acting, great direction, 100 percent original, fascinating sub plots and sub stories, great film.

reviews.review_title: A period piece that's fun, atmospheric and expertly made
reviews.content: Paul Thomas Anderson is a director I have a lot of praise for. I thought Phantom Thread was great and I really loved Punch-Drunk Love. Boogie Nights is one of his best.Boogie Nights focuses on the porn industry during the late 70s to 80s and takes us through a range of characters involved the line of work.Paul Thomas Anderson's examination of this industry and the period it's set in is a winner all the way. There's so much to appreciate and so much fun to be had with Boogie Nights. The opening scene alone had me hooked and transported me to its flashy and glamourous world. The use of long takes during some scenes tell me so much about the time period and the lifestyle these people lived. Despite this being Anderson's second feature, he displays a lot of confidence behind the camera by capturing the spirit of the 70s and 80s in great detail. This is a very atmospheric film where you soak in the beauty of the scenery. The soundtrack is easily one of my favourite aspects. Not only did it sound great but it contributed so much to the mood of each scene. The song choices fit extremely well for the time period and the variety of them kept me entertained and engrossed throughout. The camerawork is slick and stylish. There are incorporations of various long takes with action taking place at every corner which is not only impressive but also purposeful in terms of developing its characters and worldbuilding.For its subject matter, Paul Thomas Anderson manages to handle it in a very smart and mature manner. For a film about the porn industry, the film wasn't as sexual as I thought it was going to be. The second half of the film takes a much more dark turn which I didn't expect. The script is fantastic in every way. Dialogue plays a large role in the film and some of them are really funny. Anderson introduces us to memorable characters with interesting personalities. We learn more and more about them as the film goes on. The darker second half plays a great contrast to the first as it peels back the glamour and shows us how troubled these people really are. The acting by everyone involved and Anderson's direction helps us identify with these people during their highs and lows.Mark Wahlberg in his breakout role delivers one of his performances here. His character goes through a range of emotions and Wahlberg proves himself to be a worthy actor by conveying that range brilliantly. There is one scene however where Wahlberg argues with his mum and the acting seemed a tad off then but he did really well during the rest of the film. Burt Reynolds is amazing here and is one of the standout performers in the film. Julianne Moore and Heather Graham are also terrific. John C. Reilly surprised me by how good he was. I've gotten used to seeing him as more of a comedic actor but there are a handful of serious scenes where he shines. I loved Philip Seymour Hoffman here. He's consistently impressed me and once again he shows how good of an actor he is. Don Cheadle is also great here. The entire ensemble cast bring their A game here.I cannot wait to see Boogie Nights again. It's a very entertaining period piece that captures the industry and time period with immense detail. There are many memorable scenes and characters that are fun to watch and go through a rollercoaster of emotions. Paul Thomas Anderson demonstrates his skill and talent as writer and director once again and I hope he continues making great films like this.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic picture that delves deep into porn
reviews.content: Porn...what do you think of when you say porn? sex? money? drugs? Well this movie captured all off this and even added a few things to spice things up. Dirk Diggler's life was crazy, beginning with being a fresh face in a fresh industry. Well as the 70's ended and the 80's began, he suddenly got a big head to match his big "tool". He got really into drugs and even started prostituting himself. This movie is so impressive because it is so true! This is exactly what happened to porn actors of the 70's and 80's. Just take John Holmes for example. His life was like a carbon copy of Dirk Diggler's life. Start off good, do dope, start prostituting yourself, get wrapped up in murder, and have a good career again. It really is great when they switch to VHS like many porn companies did during the early 80's. I thought that was a very subtle but important part of the ever-changing porn industry. I loved this movie for its accurate look at the porn industry.

reviews.review_title: A fascinating film with the best Burt Reynolds role ever
reviews.content: This is really an outstanding movie. I saw this film before I stopped watching "R" rated films. This film has so many layers and so much texture and so many amazing things about it that you can watch it over and over and over again and see amazing, new things each time. The scenes are so beautifully developed that you forget you are watching a movie about pornography. What I like about this film is that it takes it's own sweet time to develop a scene. Sequences that are like a dance almost because they work so well together. Mark Wahlberg gives a great performance, one that really should have been an Oscar contender. You know who really deserved a nomination, right along with Burt Reynolds? Robert Ridgely as the Colonel. He was awesome. Does anyone else agree with that? Also, the biggest snub in Oscar history. Why didn't he win? What was up with that? I can't even think of who was nominated that year but he was awesome! Phillip Seymour Hoffman? Great as well. William H. Macy? Alfred Molina? Amazing. Another thing in this film I really like is the music. It fits the story so well - anyway - it's a great film.

reviews.review_title: A Fine Film, Not His Best
reviews.content: BOOGIE NIGHTS is a good movie about the adult film industry in the 1970's. It's portrayal of those films is fairly realistic. Some people will love this movie and some will hate it based on the subject matter alone.I thought it was very well done, as I've come to expect from director Paul Thomas Anderson. It's not his best work, but it is certainly good and intriguing. Even at more than two and a half hours it doesn't seem a bit too long. The story and the acting are wonderful. Burt Reynolds gives a terrific performance. Recommend to all but those who would be offended by the topic.

reviews.review_title: Excellent film about industry I don't care for
reviews.content: I've only seen one or two porn films, enough to make me know I don't want to see another one, and yet I enjoyed this movie quite a bit.  Although it's set in the porn film industry, in a surprising way it's more about the extended family that develops among all these people who work together, and how things like drugs, fame, and money may have stretched those bonds, but not broken them completely (except for William H. Macy's character).  Another nice thing is how much affection Anderson has for these people, even when he acknowledges some of the bad things they may do (like how Dirk acts like a jerk because of his ego).  And the use of period music was inventive, like the 80's songs during the scene with Alfred Molina, which add to the tension of the scene.I wasn't a fan at all of Mark Wahlberg until he turned to acting, and then he started to show some talent, especially in this movie.  He acts on everything he feels as if it just occurred to him.  I'm also not a fan of Burt Reynolds, but he comes through here, because he doesn't condescend to the movie.  But of all the cast (who are really good), it's Julianne Moore who stands out, playing, in effect, the den mother, who is looked up to by her co-stars, but can't get custody of her own children.  She also pulls off the difficult trick of playing a bad actress, and she's the most convincing at it.

reviews.review_title: Let's get one thing out of the way before discussing Boogie Nights. Yes, it is a prosthetic device. Ah, the wonders of make-up.
reviews.content: Mark Wahlberg plays Eddie, a well-endowed teenage busboy in a San Fernando Valley nightclub. One night he is discovered by blue-movie director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds). Jack takes one look at Eddie's unwrapped package and, presto, a huge star is born. Eddie assumes a nom de porn, Dirk Diggler, and the "acting" jobs start coming his way. His own family life is far from ideal, so Eddie/Dirk is more than happy to move in with his surrogate parents, Jack and Amber (Julianne Moore). Amber, as in Amber Waves, is a porn star and the mother figure little Dirkie needs. He even gets to sleep with her. Soon the '70s become the '80s and the heavy drugs start taking their toll. Video has changed the porn business forever and Dirk's enormous, uh, ego has become even more engorged. Bad times are a-coming. Ambitious young studs are being groomed to take the star's place. Must he resort to hustling? Can he keep performing on cue? By 1983, poor Diggler's just one more limp Dirk. All of this sounds pretty lurid, but young director Paul Thomas Anderson keeps the heady material from dragging us down with the characters. It is all surprisingly buoyant and, at times, even affecting. Boogie Nights does take an awfully long time (152 minutes) to reach a climax. Some serious issues get the skin-deep treatment, but a more diverting R-rated fairy tale would be hard to find. The cast is near perfect. Reynolds has never been better and former underwear pinup Wahlberg shows that there is plenty to life after Calvin. Moore scores the most emotional moments, while sterling support is provided by Don Cheadle, Heather "Rollergirl" Graham, William H. Macy, Phillip Seymour Hoffman and Alfred Molina. The disco-heavy soundtrack is a treasure trove that will have you shaking your own groove thing, prosthetic or real.

reviews.review_title: Among the worst movies I've seen
reviews.content: Friends in Portland, Ore., told me they'd walked out of this movie halfway through, and urged me not to go.  I went -- a mistake of the first order.  I also ended up walking out halfway through it!So much is wrong with this movie (at least the half I sat through) that it's hard to summarize.  It might be enough to say that it tries to parody pornography, but fails -- instead it faithfully replicates that genre's banal plot development and terrible acting.  And I've never seen a movie that could make 70's popular music sound faded, even depressing.  (In fact the whole movie has a faded look.)  It is incomprehensible to me that it garnered some positive reviews when released.

reviews.review_title: Incredible photography!!! Interesting view into the past!
reviews.content: Boogie Nights **** out of **** ...is one of my personal favorites. It is an excellent film with an extraordinary cast. In this movie, it isn't just 2 or 3 characters, Paul Thomas Anderson introduces us to so many (Jack Horner, Dirk Diggler, Amber Waves, Rollergirl, Reed Rothcild....to name a few). The story by Anderson is amazing and is held together by his great directing job, and outstanding acting by the entire cast and is topped off by a great score that takes you back to the 70s. Oh and I remember a lot of the music from that time!!! I was a child of the 70's with 8tracks and Disco! Excellent movie!!

Boogie Nights is the second feature length film written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, and it just might be my favorite of his. The film follows a young man who becomes involved with the adult film industry. While a lesser filmmaker could have used this film as an excuse to be shallow and vulgar, PTA approaches this subject matter with maturity and he includes lots of depth for the amount of characters in his movie.Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore, and Burt Reynolds all give fantastic performances, with the supporting characters being just as good and memorable. PTA is really talented at giving his actors lots to chew on; I am constantly amazed at the high-quality of acting in all his movies. Another key feature of PTA which is highly present in this film is the fantastic camera work.There are many scenes in this film that involve long, swinging shots where the camera follows character after character for a very long time. Although some may find the camera work self-indulgent, I find that the long, unbroken takes help the viewer fit into the world. It makes it easier to relate to the characters because we feel as if we are in the situation with them.Boogie Nights is a blast from start to finish. It is a very dynamic film: we experience the characters at their highest highs and lowest lows. We root for our characters and we hate them at certain points. And although it is easy to see the Martin Scorsese influence this film takes, Boogie Nights still stands on its own and offers an experience like no other film

A technical masterpiece, the camera is the tool which the director uses to near perfection. A film shot in anamorphic widescreen, which means if you view this film in full frame, you are missing out on 43% of the picture. You've only seen this film if you've viewed it in widescreen. It's pointless in full frame.The technical mastery amazed me; The 3 minute tracking sequence is beautifully worked, it brings out all the main characters of the picture. This is the introduction to the picture. From there on, the film is not a letdown.The picture is about the porn industry and what happens to people who indulge in it. It's not pretty, it's evil, a downward spiral. The film depicts the harsh 70s to the early 80s. Each of the characters are very interesting, the changes each of them go through is nicely done. As people get famous, this when their downward spiral begins. The film deals with many issues of the porn industry and why people think it's art when all it is about is sex and nothing more.The performances are superb, I love everyone's work on this, all of them believed that the material was good and had the support of the director.Technically, as I've said before is amazing, a treat for new film-makers. The photography is beautiful, the colours pop up very nicely.One of the best 90s pictures from Hollywood.

As we know from `Striptease', Burt Reynolds enjoys  the randy roles, and it's a pleasure to see him act  his face, very funny.This movie is an actor's film, even more than Paul T. Anderson's next masterpiece Magnolia`. Although the story is told over a couple of years, Mark Wahlberg is as convincing with 17 as with 25. Julianne Moore does a great job as a porn actress, and then there are Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy, etc.  all of them not stars at that time but always brilliant actors.Boogie Nights` is a film about the seventies and the eighties, about the porn industry and it includes various fictitious biographies. It's a great project and on the whole it manages to cover all of these. At some points there are flaws: exaggerations, boring phases, but the actors make up for that. A fine movie.

Porn stars and wrestlers are the ultimate actors for different reasons. Wrestlers never step out of character for a moment, never turn around say .... sure it is all faked. While the best porn stars live the life of their films in real life. Roller girl never removes her roller skates for anything.Boogie nights tells the story of Dirk Diggler, a man with few talents other than his rather large organ (you know the one I mean) and his ability in the act of coitus.Boogie night is a good fun movie that loves the characters enough to also expose their flaws and delusions. We see them rise to success and fall to their knees. We see the hypocrisies (the porn star film maker who is upset that his porn star wife is having sex with other men).It has a lot of weaknesses, but enough strengths to rise it up above many other movies. Most importantly it loves the idea of good pornography. It doesn't get bogged down with much of exploitation that occurs now and before in the porn industry. BOOGIE NIGHTS (dir. Paul Thomas Anderson) This is an unquestionable film classic that concerns a most unusual subject, 'The American Adult Film Industry'. Anderson has directed and written a film of great emotional depth, and the subject of porn is an area where most people would assume that emotions and human feelings are far less important than clothing at a photoshoot. The film boasts a cross section of America's finest character actors, and Anderson took an extremely big chance on a couple of actors who must have seemed like very questionable choices. By the mid 90's when BOOGIE NIGHTS was released, Burt Reynolds tabloid personal life exemplified the most lurid aspects of The Seventies, and his inclusion in the film might have detracted from Anderson's nuanced presentation of the film industry's impact upon sexual liberation. But, Reynolds delivers a perfect characterization of an American businessman who is only satisfying the public's nascent hunger for cinematic knowledge of the country's changing sexual mores.And, casting Mark Wahlberg in the lead role of Dirk Diggler was risky at best. At the time, Wahlberg was primarily known as a member of a boy band and an underwear model, but who really knew that he could be such a convincing actor? The film is very long, but never lags, and there are really far too many fine performances to note. MUST SEE

reviews.review_title: This is my FAVORITE movie- hands down!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: You will laugh and cry with both enjoyment and sadness. This movie really grows on you.

reviews.review_title: One of the best of the 90s
reviews.content: 90s was a great decade for films. We saw uprising of this whole new breed of young talent most of whom learned about film-making through movies and books. Linklater, Tarantino, Rodrigues and of course the best of the lot Paul Thomas Anderson. They brought a sense of freshness to scripts and screenplays as suppose to the zombie film schools technical writing that we were being dished out With his second venture Boogie Nights, Anderson sought to go back to his first amateur film "The Dirk Diggler" story.For a young director, this was a tough film to make for several reasons. Can he make a film about Porn stars and the industry with nudity but without alienating the audience? Can he make a film that makes the audience connect to these characters who are more or less alien to these world? Can he make a film compassionate, emphatic and non judge-mental of these actors? Can he retain the audience interest and the pace of the film when it deals with so many characters with different sub plots? Can he re create the magic of swinging 70s? Of course will the prosthetic penis work? In many ways P.T.Anderson's task was just as daunting as that of Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) who had the ambition of keeping the audiences in the theater with an enticing story even after they "get off" on it.The movie essentially centers around Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg) who is an aspiring actor, gets discovered by Jack Horner, a porn director who considers his job an art form. Eddie then changes his name to Dirk Diggler and gets sucked in the lifestyle and relationships of the pornography industry of the late-1970s. The movie is an exercise in evolution of Porn Industry through the 70s and the 80s, the highs and lows of the characters especially Dirk. It reminds a lot of the great works of Robert Altman in its "ensemble" nature and also of Martin Scorsese in some of the camera work. Anderson is not shy and shows of every trick in his book, even the shot of camera following the girl into the pool from Soy Cuba.The movie is fast paced, extremely funny in places, insightful in others with some of the most jaw dropping sequences one would hope to see. The sequence with Chinese crackers is out of this planet, early indications of the phenomenal talent of the man. But most of all, I feel the film is not judge-mental about any of the characters be it Rollergirl (Heather Graham, I never take my skates off), Little Bill (William H. Macy, My is wife is the back with a "cock" in her "ass"), Buck Swope (Don Cheadle), Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly), Amber Waves (Julianne Moore), Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) and many others who have taken this film to a new level.Arguably one the greatest movies of my lifetime, it is a must watch for one and all.

There is something very special with Paul Thomas Anderson films. Each one of them I don't want to end. This film is wonderful in many respects. It reminds me a lot of Goodfellas regarding the rise and fall of a certain individual. But it's very different. First off, I have to praise everyone in the film for the acting. Especially Julianne Moore. This movie takes you on a ride and you never want to get off it. I enjoyed it and I would recommend it. 👍🏽👍🏽

Man, what a great flick!  It was a crime that this film didn't win Best Picture and that Mark Wahlberg wasn't nominated for Best Actor.  Paul Thomas Anderson is a filmmaking genius.  One of the things I loved most about the film was PTA's use of music.  I thought I was the only one who loved the Andrew Gold song "Lonely Boy"!  But as brilliant as PTA is you can tell a lot of his "style" is lifted straight out of Scorsese.  He's a badass Scorsese doppelganger to be sure, but so much of his visual style is a shot by shot ripoff of shots from Goodfellas.I felt SO much for the character of Dirk Diggler, my heart ached for the poor guy.  We even both live in the same town, beautiful downtown Torrance! I loved the little touches of this film.  Like the title card that read "Long Way Down (one last thing)".  And the long take of Dirk's face when he's on the couch at the drug dealers house.  The little look of madness, of coke fiendishness, and of how far down he had sunk from being a wide eyed innocent were all brilliantly summed up in just a minute or so of facial expressions.  Fan-frigging-tastic, daddy-o!PTA has made a classic American film.  And he's still got a helluva long way to go!  Life will be good and so will the future of filmmaking as long as PTA is walking this Earth, Jack.  As an aspiring screenwriter I kinda hate him for being so talented but it's a cross I'm willing to bear, baby.  And in the words of Dirk Diggler, "Let's Keep Rockin' And Rollin'."

reviews.review_title: How can a film about porn be so boring?
reviews.content: It took me literally months to get through Boogie Nights. I could only stand to watch a few minutes at a time. In the first half of the film, absolutely nothing happens except increasing financial success.There isn't a single likable character! I just couldn't care less what happens to any of these sleazy, arrogant, deluded dips**ts. The only somewhat sympathetic (thought not likable) character blows his brains out half way through.The only positive thing I can say is that at least the director had the courage to let us see the d**k at the end, unlike The Full Monty. Though that certainly doesn't justify two and a half hours of painful boredom.

reviews.review_title: Get down and boogie! (That's me trying to be funny... ahem...)
reviews.content: A young seventeen year old sets out to become the next BIG thing (um yeah, that was me being funny again...). Mark Wahlberg (The Big Hit, Planet of the Apes) plays Eddie Adams a.k.a Dirk Diggler who longs to be famous in the late 1970's. His wish comes true when a top-class porn-film director discovers the young talent with the 13-inch penis and before long, Dirk becomes the lead in many adult-orientated films.Wahlberg throws in a performance worthy of a Golden Globe nomination - he's a charismatic lead that can hold humour and tragedy with one hand, and is backed up by awesome performances by Julianne Moore (The Lost Word, Hannibal), William H. Macy, Burt Reynolds, John C. Rielly (Never Been Kissed) and Dan Cheadle (Ocean's Eleven). One of the more memorable characters is that of Rollergirl, portrayed by the uninhibited and highly under-rated Heather Graham.As the film progresses, you get caught up in all the characters and wonder how each one will end up (at 2½ hours there's definetely enough time to change your mind). The club scenes where Wahlberg, Moore and Graham get down with their bad selves and "boogie" are particularly entertaining, and whether you like porn or not (there's plenty of it here) there is something undeniably attracting about "Boogie Nights" - something even the most prudish can't deny. 9/10

It is obvious that Anderson has looked deep into a lot of Scorsese-films before he made this one. Like Scorsese, he has shown himself able of doing something that's truly rare in american films: he has made a movie, where everyone is a bad guy, and still you watch it. From the beginning it is clear, that it is going to be a "rise and fall"-type of film, and I think the biggest fault of the film is, that the "rise"-part is too long. Sure it captures a lot of seventies-atmosphere, but at length it gets boring, until the last part of the film finally saves the day. The anarchistic end of the movie is in many ways a parallel to that of Raging Bull - the star who - no longer a star - refuses to realize, that he's finished. Overall, this is a god movie, that could have been great, if it had been about half an hour shorter. 7/10

Superb acting. Tremendous direction. reviews.content: What has to change in today's attitude towards films like Boogie Nights is the approach. The approach is awful! "Boogie Nights" is that remarkable achievement, a depiction of particularly ugly goings on made singularly watchable through vibrant direction and the sheer likability of an endearing cast. It's a sort of secular "Pilgrim's Progress" in which we follow the journey of Eddie, a high school dropout and dish-washing nobody to the heights of porn film acting by virtue of his super well-endowed cock, then to the depths as both he and his associates mess their lives up during a period of decline in their industry to a finale that gives just a little peek at their recovery. Clearly influenced by Scorsese (all those exhilarating tracking shots in and out of rooms in single takes) and Altman (the skillful manoeuvring of a large cast), Paul Thomas Anderson has fashioned a great ensemble piece that cleverly balances comedy and violence in a way that is genuinely funny in spite of the often shocking happenings. Burt Reynolds brilliantly plays Jack Horner the porn king who gathers into his entourage a troupe of grotesques that continuously delight. Particularly lovable are Rollergirl who never takes her skates off even when having sex, Julianne Moore who plays the motherly dope addict actress Amber and a remarkably young Philip Seymour Hoffman as the cuddly queer cameraman Scotty who has a crush on Eddie. When Eddie eventually f***s things up by rounding on benefactor Jack, our eyes are cleverly drawn away from the two main foreground protagonists to a distraught Scotty in a background group of onlookers. It's a wonderfully perceptive moment in a film full of small wonders and sometimes greater ones as when Eddie drinking with Jack and another friend, all half immersed in a vat of water at a party declares his chosen stage name to be Dirk Diggler. "I think heaven has sent you here, Dirk Diggler. I think the angels have blessed us all because of you" declares Jack. It is an almost spiritual cry of joy, the climax of what is for Anderson clearly a creative labour of love.

I will try and break down why this film is in the top 5 of the decade.1. Ensemble. It's rare that a picture with so many support actors that you actually feel you know them all well - even if they only appear briefly.2. The acting is top notch and most have gone on to make many films. Burt Reynolds is the veteran in arguably his greatest role.The infusion of music. This is where PTA can boast. Probably the greatest example of perfection in creating the time and place. Think of Mark Wahlberg room scene with the posters, sister Christian at Alfred Molinas house , the nightclub scenes and so on.Great, long scenes. If you wanted to teach students how to make a film this is what you would show them. Think of the 20 minute pool party and the scene with w h macy entering a party have already entered the realms of legendary scenes.Realism- you don't gave to like the characters. In fact most are despicable. But you feel for all of them. They are real. PTA is not pandering to the audience here- he takes no sides. He shows the "success " and also the short comings of the characters.If you can leave your inhibitions about the industry/ lifestyle you will witness One of the greatest movies of the 90s.

One can admire the writer/director's ambition in wanting to encapsulate the entire "golden age of porn" in one sweep and, while this film has many things to commend it, some interesting characters, imaginative direction and some memorable scenes, it lacks focus and could probably do with at least an hour's worth of pruning.Too many story threads vie for attention and several get lost in the mix. Among a number of potentially interesting sidelines which go nowhere are a paedophilia strand and a male co-worker who drunkenly kisses Dirk Diggler. A lot of fairly famous faces appear but are underused.Some scenes are not convincing such as the very contrived confrontation between Diggler and Jack (excellently played by Reynolds) leads to Diggler's prolonged bout of ostracism from the porn family. And there is a strange vacillation between comedy and brutal reality. For instance, the graphic William Macy shooting scene is followed not long after by a video tape sequence in which Diggler refers to Napoleon as king of the Roman Empire, an example of stupidity which Diggler does not exhibit elsewhere. These scenes seem to come from two different films. The scene in which Don Cheatle is the sole survivor in a bizarre robbery and ends up with the cash also strikes me as implausible at least in this contest. Boogie Nights does manage to capture some of the mood of the times in these video tape sequence, but certain details elsewhere do not ring true, such as the presence of silicon implants (too early in 1980 surely?).

reviews.review_title: A fresh, brazenly original finger in the face of the Moral Majority!
reviews.content: This completely original depiction of the porno movie industry in the 1970-'80s is some ride, indeed. It's such a fresh finger in the face of any Moral Majority who seriously still think nudity and sex are worse threats to humanity than violence! P.T. Anderson earns at least one star in my book, solely for his sheer brazenly choice of story topics. But also handling it so vividly, funny AND moving is quite an achievement- I really care and feel for these characters! Peppered with a big-name cast that really delivers is another treat. And seriously, Mark Wahlberg IS a "f***ing star" here- simply sensational! Quibbles? Just a bit overlong, and so is the non-stop music soundtrack; blessed silence would have helped some scenes more.7 out of 10 from Ozjeppe.

reviews.review_title: The life of a porn family.
reviews.content: At first it might look like it is all about the young porn superstar Dirk Diggler, but it moves away from only focusing on him and instead focuses on many different characters not really going too deep into why, how and when. Just gives you a glimpse of it is to be a part of the porn industry and how can you branch out into doing other things after that.It is not a great film, just because it is about the porn industry, as a matter of fact it contains far less nudity than one might expect from a film like this. This movie achieves its goal of showing the careless lives of these people. It does not stress you with many problems, fights and whatever, it just gives a careless vibe of the reckless 70's and 80's.The story might look quite blatant and not really that grasping, but the vibe this film has makes you not care about the story or how good or bad it actually is, it feels different. The first half of the film is more centered around the porn industry and Dirk's success doing what he loves, but the other half is all about character development and barely touches on the porn industry. So all those people who pass up watching this movie just because they dislike porn or porn industry, should know it is not all about porn and is a lot more likable than you might think. Has many likable characters, i even enjoyed Mark Wahlberg, who i am not a fan of. Worth checking out!

I really didn't want to see this movie with my friend, but he made me watch it. I'm glad he did. This movie is great. It has everything that makes a movie great. Sex, drugs, action, and pornagraphy. It's about a guy named Eddie who is working at a night club in the kitchen. A local porn director finds him and is astonished with his special thing. I AM A STAR.

This film, much in the same way as "Jackie Brown" gets better with each viewing. Hands down my favorite film because of its impeccable sense of humor and ability to shape characters in a short amount of time. P.T. Anderson grabs pop culture and jams it down the throat of reality, all the while using the porn industry as a backdrop for a very dysfunctional "family" of different people. It's hard not to feel sorry for Little Bill when his wife sleeps with other men, or for poor Scotty, whose confusion and lustfulness has been felt by every human being at some point in time. But the real star performances come from Burt Reynolds and Don Cheadle. I'm not a Reynolds fan, but he is stellar in a very complex role. He's a porno visionary who loves the people he works with but also is driven by his desire to make great movies. Cheadle is the oft-rejected Buck Swope, whose shady past limits his ultimate dream to open a record store. It's pointless to name all the funny little exchanges, but there are enough to keep the film on an off-kilter journey towards oblivion (a.k.a. the 1980s). Some of the best lines come from the secondary characters such as Luis Guzman, Philip Baker Hall ("I like simple things...) and Todd (Thomas Jane) who turns in a great performance as a frustrated, cocaine-driven small-time criminal. Forget Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch for five minutes, and you'll also realize Mark Wahlberg as a strong actor. Same goes for John C. Reilly, who is underrated and brilliant as a less-attractive porno star and Dirk Diggler sidekick. The film is simply great on every level, and the originality cannot be disputed.

reviews.review_title: Why it is cool and not cool to like Boogie Nights...
reviews.content: I remember seeing Boogie nights when it first hit the theaters. I was blown away and absolutely fell in love with this movie. To begin, we all have reasons why we like and dislike movies. For that respective reason i will not criticize anyone's review since they all tend to of a personal nature. Much like the reasons i like Boogie Nights is due to the personal way it hit home with my childhood memories and how effectively it registered as truthful and vivid recollections of my youth. Having grown up as an adolescent in the late 70's and early 80's I can relate to Boogie nights that would be hard for me to explain to those who didn't experience them in my eyes. Boogie Nights is a masterpiece. Not only does it represent the desperate human nature of people yearning to be accepted, loved and appreciated, but it also captures the wasteful time of American history where some people actually earned a living without ever doing anything of any value. The 70's for young adults was when some people abandoned any sense of social responsibility. Being a morally upstanding person was disrespected and regarded as uncool, because being risqué, daring and promiscuous was en vogue. As decadent as Anderson presents his characters and the sleazy lives these people lead it is apparent that he shows his characters as people who believe in themselves and their self delusion. Anderson doesn't judge his characters, but rather makes them very real.Boogie Nights is fun and exciting to watch. The story never lags. Anderson uses great angles, jump-cuts and effective usage of popular songs of that era for ambiance. It looks kitschy, slick and vibrantly paced. At 2.5 hours it seems to fly by.Why is it cool to like this movie? For those who can appreciate the period and setting that the story takes place is enough to draw your attention. The characters are also oddly interesting if even completely despicable. The humor is also good when it is harsh as well as uncomfortable. it's also a historical representation of the 70's that beautifully depicts the mentality of people in that time. People were far less socially aware of their faults, hangups and personal flaws back then. Today, we still have decadence and immorality in all of its numerous forms, but at least social media has kept us in check. The younger generation of today is far more informed and reminded on a daily basis the consequences of their actions. In the 70's, being promiscuous and drug addicted was upheld in pop-culture and used to separate the hip from the square by means of peer pressure. In post Y2K America we have learned the ills and setbacks of such a lifestyle and how that leads to self destruction, STD and pain.Why is it not cool to like Boogie Nights? All the characters in this movie are sad and damaged people. They are the losers of society who have chosen a soulless and hideous lifestyle devoid of any positive or meaningful aspirations. Their goals are short-term and have repulsively unsatisfying outcomes. They are all bottom-feeders who have clung together under the patriarch, Jack Horner. Exploitation, moral decay, human desperation, addiction and promiscuity are themes explored in Boogie Nights. This movie serves as a human and historical lesson. Don't watch this movie thinking you want to emulate any of these people, because you should react on the contrary. Yes, the movie does a great job with acting, plot development and authenticity. The purpose it should serve is that what a parable or Biblical story does.

Paul Thomas Anderson's period porn odyssey Boogie Nights leans heavily on the cinematic styles of other directors (like Scorsese and Altman) but more than holds its own.  The rise-and-fall plot is typical, and the search for father and mother psychodrama is obvious, but the delivery makes all the difference.  Armed with dozens of well-chosen songs and wonderfully garish costumes that perfectly complement the production design, Anderson deftly balances the huge cast, giving each of the excellent performers their chance to shine.  Ensemble casting often shortchanges the supporting characters, but nearly every person in orbit around Dirk Diggler gets a defining moment or series of moments.  Boogie Nights is a terrific film that gets better with multiple viewings.

reviews.review_title: An ode to porn stars of the 70s
reviews.content: This movie is not an adult title. It's really an homage to the late John Holmes. Boogie Nights takes place at the start of the 70s disco craze, where polyester, sequence and coke ruled the night scene. We meet Eddy Adams, played by Wahlberg a young kid working in the back of a night club with big dreams of being a star. Eddy gets his chance when he meets Jack Horner, played by Reynolds, and adult film producer who's very interested in Eddy's "gift". Jack lead's Eddy away from his dysfunctional home by luring him with the promise of money, fun times and lots and lots of sex. As the movie progresses, we meet many other characters, all with their own quirks and short comings. Eventually the party must end and the characters are left to face their vices with ought the support and business of their past employment choices. If you've ever wondered about what takes place behind the scenes of adult videos, more precisely those of the 70s, then this is a movie for you. I find this to be a very interesting subject as I don't think it's been done before this movie, also because one never stops to think about what the people in this kind business are like once the cameras stop rolling. This movie is a study in character development and relies heavily on the acting by all parties involved, who succeed admirably. Although this movie was not a big blockbuster hit, mostly due to the subject nature, I assume, this is a great movie none the less on a subject we don't often think about. Many have copied this movie, but few have managed to capture the feel of it.

First, I think one has to have seen a number of porn films to appreciate what a great take off Boogie Nights is.  It captures just how tawdry and explotive these films were with many of the porn cast sincerely believing that they were "actors," and no just porn machines. Next, how many appreciate how what I think is a marvelously effective score the movie has?  Many scores in movies are superfluous, even unwanted, but not this one.  It adds to the actions displayed in a way that heightens that superbly heightens them.  For example, the bells in one of the later sequences of scenes starting with Dirk getting in to a car to pitifully earn a few bucks.  Or the penultimate scene in the house where the boys go to sell some talcum powder as cocaine. The rock music, although not really a part of a superimposed score, blasts at us to the point where we want to scream, "Turn that damned stuff off."  When it finally is shut off, what a great relief.  This technique I found in some Spike Lee movies, particularily Jungle Fever, although I'm sure other have noticed it in different films too.

...of golden age in porn industry in 70's and 80's. Boogie nights is one of these enjoyable, partly documentary, partly "well build story" type of movie, where you can just sit back and really get a feel of the era representing it. The biggest credit goes to director (P.T. Anderson), who has picked the right actors. Always sexy Heather Graham, surprisingly talented Mark Wahlberg and all the others. Well done. Beside that, there is a great music theme that really gets you in (funky) 70's mood. In it's genre is certainly classic and a movie you'll most probably like to return to. 7 out of 10...well almost 8:)

Perhaps the greatest story about the porn industry ever committed to a motion picture? Probably. In Boogie Nights, a movie filled with outstanding performances and pop culture for days, Paul Thomas Anderson shows us a movie in which he is truly and utterly in control of. Every single shot in this 2 and a half hour celebration of excess exists for a purpose and Anderson shows us his skill as a director. Like I said, it is a film filled with great performances, but really outstanding work from Mark Wahlberg in a truly committed performance. The movie delivers in a great use of music, filled with popular songs of the 70s and 80s and an amazing use of volume in the music (when to make it louder, quieter).All of this brings me to the ultimate flaw of Boogie Nights. There is a fine line between paying homage to a certain movie or a director and for a while, Boogie Nights rides this line with Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas. But after about the first half of the film, Anderson bluntly just rips off Scorsese. The story in itself is essentially a Goodfellas remake. A story about a young man joining a frowned upon business, starting from nothing, the film explores the inner workings of this business and we see it through the eyes of our main character (fish out of water) and we see his rise and ultimate fall through addiction and excess caused by the very business he started out in. In Goodfellas, it's organized crime. In Boogie Nights, it is the porn industry. Of course, there have been several movies to use the cookie cutter provided by Scorsese's seminal film (including two by Scorsese in Casino and more recently The Wolf of Wall Street), but Anderson also copies many of the shots used by Scorsese: Many tracking shots, the snorting of the coke then rapidly zooming in on the character's face, etc. The use of music (not the songs, but its use in the film) is nearly identical. But the similarities do not stop there. Anderson goes further in copying Scorsese's technique in using almost the same film shots used in Mean Streets. And the one that was just too much for me, personally, were the parts where Mark Wahlberg talks to himself in his dressing room, then by the end of the film it's the same thing but he is now a much different person and he starts shadow boxing (right after showing his giant c**k to the audience, of course). It is literally the exact same camera positioning (or nearly identical) as in Raging Bull. Like I said, this may be purely seen as homage to many, but for me it took it a bit too far.But overall, I can't really not like this film. Sure, Scorsese's framework is used in Boogie Nights, but as its own story it is truly gripping and compelling. It's not only a movie about the porn industry in the late 70s and early 80s, but a movie about addiction, the troubles of life and overcoming them. I have to confess, even after all of the similarities, I really like Boogie Nights and it is definitely worth a watch. The movie is two and a half hours long, but it flies by because it is insanely entertaining to watch. This is a sign of a pretty good film.

reviews.review_title: Utterly Fascinating Look at the Porn Industry, Warts and All
reviews.content: 1997 was not Oscar's best year, particularly in the Best Picture category, which consisted of three lousy movies (TITANIC, GOOD WILL HUNTING, and AS GOOD AS IT GETS) and two that were mediocre at best (THE FULL MONTY and LA CONFIDENTIAL). As it turns out one of the lousy ones won, while one of the best pictures made that year unaccountably failed to even make the nominees list. I am referring to Paul Thomas Anderson's brilliant, no-holds-barred, and unflinchingly frank look at a "family" of pornographers (everyone from the producer to the stars to the film crew gets face time here) from the days when "adult films" were made with actual film and often financed by organized crime to the legal but undoubtedly cheesier days of direct-to-video movies.While this is mostly an ensemble piece, the central figure is Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg, sensational here), a slightly dim-witted young man with a huge "endowment" who attracts the attention of porn producer Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds in perhaps his best performance since DELIVERANCE) and is soon a member of Horner's company, renamed "Dirk Diggler" and bearing more than a passing resemblance to the late John Holmes.Anderson makes big movies, and they tend to run long; this one takes a little over two-and-a-half hours to tell its story, but there isn't a frame of wasted film here; this is an exciting, involving, and utterly fascinating film from start to finish. Even if you find the subject matter objectionable, you will not be able to deny the power Anderson brings to every moment of this film.The ensemble deserves mention here as well, because this is a film loaded with some of the best character actors in the business and every performance has greatness in it. One of my particular favorite scenes is a cocaine-fueled stream-of-consciousness dialogue between porn actresses Amber Waves (Julianne Moore) and Rollergirl (Heather Graham) that is as harrowing as a train wreck and quite as impossible to avoid looking at.There is a lot of other great talent on hand here: Luis Guzmán as an aspiring producer; Don Cheadle as an aspiring porn actor with the peculiar quirk of dressing in cowboy outfits that make him look more like BLAZING SADDLES material than a porn star; William H Macy as a member of the crew whose wife (Nina Hartley) enjoys "doing it" with every available male whether or not the cameras are turning, and a slightly stereotypical but nonetheless compelling turn by Phillip Seymour Hoffman as a gofer with a major crush on both Dirk and his "sidekick" and frequent costar Reed Rothchild (John C Reilly); and two brilliant cameos: Joanna Gleason as Eddie/Dirk's hateful mother, and Alfred Molina as a highly-placed drug dealer whom Dirk and Reed make an abortive attempt to rob, nearly losing their lives in the process.This is a great film, rich in both form and content. There isn't a bad performance or a single scene that fails to hit the mark in the entire movie, and if you haven't seen it yet, I urge you to get it. It is proof that great movies are still possible even in this day and age when we are drowning in remakes and silly action pictures.Final note: the most interesting and compelling thing about this film is that Anderson makes no judgment calls about his characters. He shows them for who they are, the good, the bad, and the in-between, giving the film a depth that is rare in Hollywood.A work of genius.

reviews.review_title: Burt's good but the movie isn't
reviews.content: I never understood what people see in "Boogie Nights". Today I watched it for the fourth time. It's a long, often brutal, watch. The first half is okay, at best, but the last half is a true cinema endurance test. Sure, there are a few well done moments but, overall, it's an unfunny, self-serious waste of time. I'm a big fan of Burt Reynolds. He does a nice job in this movie. It's a good performance that I don't want to see again. Life's too short.

Mmmmm-hmmmm.For starting and re-starting so many worthwhile careers, and for entertainment value alone.  Nothing in the '90's that I can think of at the moment was more fun to watch than this.  Everything a good movie should be and then some.

reviews.review_title: The best film related to porn ever
reviews.content: This movie is so different than any movie that exploits pornography simply because it doesn't exploit the industry with sex and pornography, but rather treat as an industry, and that Jack Horner's company is like a family.  This is an epic of a movie, and is ten times better than 'Titanic' in terms of the overall picture.Every actor, actress, editor, cinematographer, screenwriter does their job, and does it extremely well.  Paul Thomas Andersen shows his creativity and subtle genius on his first movie.  This was one of the only movies made in the last five years that I had found an attachment to all the characters. William H. Macy, Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore, Burt Reynolds and all the other characters everyone portrayed were well rounded.  The cinematography, the soundtrack.  This is a must-see movie.  Enough brown nosing from me, just go rent it.  Look for the wide-screen.

There are only two reasons why a movie like "Boogie Nights" would draw anyone:  for the pleasure of seeing people having sex (of which there is--strangely-- very little) or of garnering some insight about the people who work in the porn industry.  Paul Thomas Anderson fails on both counts.  The movie opens with a very long panning sequence, but besides getting us acquainted with some of the characters, the camera's movement lacks any deeper meaning than that Anderson wanted to see if he could do it.  This would be fine, if the rest of the movie had this same gliding, spinning spirit about it, but Anderson has chosen a darker, more cynical approach.  He doesn't judge the people he creates, but he doesn't really know how to tell a story about them, either.  He is reaching for new insights about the porn industry, but the only times he avoids its banality is when he catches the humor in the situation.  And this doesn't happen too often.  Only the marginal characters have any freshness to them; John C. Reilly, Don Cheadle, and Philip Seymour Hoffman shine.  The principals--Mark Wahlberg, Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, and Heather Graham--are dim, and porn stars that I've ever seen in interviews have a sharpness and resilience that they lack.  The women in this business are tough and clever.  If they ever are maternal like Moore is, it's not evident on camera, and only the pretentious ones harbor thoughts of being filmmakers.  For this movie to touch anything close to greatness, it would need to be more comic in tone or go all the way with its sights on the dark side. Instead it chooses to remain somewhere in between, and the sensual promise of "Spill The Wine" overflows in vain.  What a waste!

This movie is fantastic. It contains so much joy, and so much despair. The unbroken shot at the pool party is technically brilliant. Scene after scene it just gets better, and the last scene.....well, if you haven't seen it, I won't spoil it for you.
This film was incredible. The casting was masterful and the rollercoaster ending was breathtaking. I loved every minute.

This movie is so awesome! Every actor does a wonderful job, in it. I think the funniest part of this movie is the way that all the characters in it are complete idiots, yet take themselves completly seriously. Rollergirl is hot as all get-out. The soundtrack is so great that they've made two already, and still havn't gotten all the songs on it. This movie is one of the greatest of the 90's and that's saying a lot.

reviews.review_title: Simply one of the best films ever made...
reviews.content: Boogie Nights is a modern classic and, quite frankly, one for the ages. This is a bold statement to make, but this will surely be a movie that will be studied and remembered for years to come.  Some people I have spoken with regarding "Nights" consider it appalling and unwatchable.  They cannot be further from the truth.  It is probably the subject matter they find awful, hence, they trash the movie.  You must watch the film with an objective attitude towards pornography, or miss one of the most truthful, realistic films ever presented on-screen.  Brutal, perceptive, sad, hilarious, tempting...it's all here!Dirk Diggler is the epitome of misled youth, as well as a prime example of taking advantage of a situation that presents itself to you.  The film's tag-line rings very true, saying everyone has something useful.  Diggler's something happened to be very marketable back in the late-'70's madness that was the porn industry.  Aside from this, the film must be looked at as a slice-of-life, historical document because of how sex is portrayed and thought of then and now.  Porn, of course, is still booming.  I don't think as many people are being hurt.  Boogie Nights shows both sides of this world where love is hard to come by and you can lose it all in the blink of an eye, yet, it is an extremely tempting lifestyle to so many.

Yesterday I made the mistake of watching Heather Graham 'comedy' Say It Isn't So' for a second time, having forgotten that I had already seen it in back in 2007 (boy, is that film a stinker—no wonder I blocked it from my memory); today I decided to wash the bad taste out of my mouth by seeing a Heather Graham film that actually holds up to repeat viewing: Boogie Nights, a film so good that even a starring role for Mark Wahlberg cannot spoil it for me.Graham, looking as hot as she ever has, plays roller-skating sexpot Rollergirl, one of a band of L.A. pornographers led by charismatic adult film-maker Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds), who is always on the lookout for the next big thing in porn. And they don't come much bigger than Eddie Adams (Wahlberg), discovered by Horner working in a nightclub: with his massive schlong and enviable sexual prowess, he is a natural. As Dirk Diggler, Eddie quickly becomes an industry legend, but with success comes excess, which leads to the young porn-star making some dangerous choices that almost cost him his life.A thoroughly engrossing tale of decadence and corruption, Boogie Nights is a superbly crafted film in virtually every area: the script is gritty, witty, poignant and shocking, brimming with unforgettable characters and sparkling dialogue; the superb period detail and wonderful soundtrack effortlessly transport the viewer to the carefree pre-AIDS days of the late '70s/early '80s; the stellar supporting cast—which includes William H. Macy, Don Cheadle, John C. Reilly, Julianne Moore, Luis Guzman, Alfred Molina and Philip Seymour Hoffman—can do no wrong; and with director Paul Thomas Anderson conducting proceedings with oodles of style, taking a leaf or two out of the books of Scorsese and Tarantino along the way, the film looks and feels fantastic throughout.9.5/10, rounded up to full marks for the hilarious disco dancing sequence and Heather Graham's full-frontal scene (what she lacks in acting talent, she definitely makes up for in va-va-voom!).

I saw Boogie Nights for the first time on HBO a few nights ago and it's left me deeply thoughtful and overwhelmingly, unexpectedly, entertained. The cast is perfect, they "nailed" their roles. The cinematography is seamless, fresh, and immensely creative. Very well written script conveying the characters' complex personalities and emotions. The soundtrack invokes moods I didn't even know I had. All elements of this film are superb and I plan on purchasing the DVD. Boogie Nights is a very pleasurable and stimulating experience and I would recommend it to anybody.-Nicole Tuscaloosa, Alabama

P.T. Anderson's epic following the lives of porn filmmakers from the 70s to the 80s in one of the most un-Hollywood Hollywood movies since "Raging Bull" or "Schindler's List".  Beautiful shot in long takes with superb cinematography.  Mark Wahlberg, playing a porn star who rises to fame, and Burt Reynolds, playing the director of the films, deliver their best performances before or since - but everybody in this ensemble cast is stellar.  Full of unique and colorful characters - yet the movie feels honest and real all the way through, with lots of emotional power.  One of the few movies of that last few years that qualifies as a real must see.

This is a great sprawling movie woth a plethora of fantastic characters. Totally detached from it's sexual subject matter. Great cinematography - with some self confessed rip off's - I am Cuba being the most obvious (in the DVD commentary PTA says "we came back out of the water for some dialogue!" - he's one hell of a show off) Anyway - great dialogue, wonderful performances etc etc. One of the great movies. Period.

reviews.review_title: An impressive trip through the 70s and 80s
reviews.content: Boogie Nights is one of those movies that you never expect to be good.  The previews look OK, perhaps even funny, the cast seems attractive, but overall you simply cannot imagine a movie about pornography will be very good. Well, you would be wrong.  Boogie Nights is quite simply one of the best films of the 90s, and definitely one of the best period pieces I have ever seen.  Given the 70s and 80s were not that long ago, but writers and director really demonstrate a reasonable understanding of not only the porn industry, but the societal changes that turned it into a profitable business.While Boogie Nights does not seem to glorify pornography in any way, it also does not fall into moralizing mode and become an indictment of the people of the industry.  Most of characters managed to expand beyond their conventions and become living, breathing creatures.  Wahlberg is phenomenal in this film, surprisingly so, he really brings a sense of pathos to an otherwise stupid and unsympathetic character.  The scene where his mother is taunting him and ripping his posters down is genuinely moving in a wierd sort of way (although she is not ultimately wrong).Most of the characters are equally as complex and engaging and the plot is beautifully done and ends on a rather strange kind of upbeat.  Overall, I would advise this film to anyone who was genuinely interested in the 70s or 80s, and to people who have sort of an off-beat sense of art.  Boogie Nights transcends the conventions of the biopic drama and brings something very interesting to the mix.

This is such a good movie. P. T. (Paul Thomas) Anderson's first attempt was with the 1996, Hard Eight, starring Samuel L. Jackson and Gwyneth Paltrow. This was a good attempt at an Inde movie but Boogie Nights blew my mind!! The character study was amazing! The most interesting part was during the 80's when they go to make the coke deal. Anyway see it for yourself!! 10 times better than Titanic!!

reviews.review_title: An interesting story made incredibly boring
reviews.content:
It seems very interesting at the beginning, but gets boring as the story progresses.Some scenes just make no sense and seem completely out of place.The movie about porn should be made to entertain people with food for thought. In this case it's all the way the food for thought. Maybe it was the director's point, but the movie didn't entertain me at all.5/10 for good acting, 70s atmosphere, music etc
It wasn't a bad movie, but overrated imo & definitely not worth 2h 30 min of watching it.

Wow! Not only has director Paul Thomas Anderson coaxed career-best performances out of the likes of Burt Reynolds and Julianne Moore, but he has created an inviting 70's ambience that you won't want to leave. Costuming and sets are perfect, and even the most minor of bit parts is executed impeccably. It's hard to imagine that anyone could make a better film than this .

reviews.review_title: Absolutely the worst piece of rubbish in film history! A total monstrosity with bad acting, terrible dialogue, bad direction to make this film better than any sleeping pill!
reviews.content: I saw boogie nights with 4 friends on its initial release in 1998. Never before have we all seen such a pointless film. The film concerns the 1970's porn industry and a young guy named dirk diggler (must have took half a brain cell to think of that name) and his struggles to make some money from it. The film at about 2 1/2 hours is far too long and bores you to tears (1 friend fell asleep and started snoring) at the end of the film and this proves how universally hated by the cinema audience this film was when one person shouted "thank f--- its over!" and got universal applause.This film is amazingly bad with dreadful acting (even from heather graham, burt reynolds and mark whalberg) and the most boring script in the world ever and I know several other people have slated it too (most of them on this site).The film is that bad that even Burt Reynolds apparently has distanced himself from it which I don't blame him for. If an actor does that then that means even he thinks its s---. This is total utter trash and I cant even think of any saving graces which is unusual as even with some of the worst films i've seen I can find at least one. Ahh got 1, yes it does have a saving grace and thats that eventually after all the tedium it finishes and thank F--- for that!

A richly told, compelling, fictional look at the porn industry in the late 1970's/early 1980's.  Somewhat surprisingly, the film isn't particularly glamorous or sexy  in fact, at times it's incredibly sad and depressing. The overall story deals with the successes that the characters enjoy within their own secluded little world of adult films . . . and the failures they encounter when they dare to reach for more.  The rest of the world views them as perverts, as criminals . . . or, worst of all, as pathetic jokes, which probably hurts most of all.The ensemble cast of `Boogie Nights' is nothing short of awesome.  Mark Wahlberg is Dirk Diggler (loosely based on the real adult film star John Holmes), a man endowed with a rather large gift  unfortunately, it isn't a brain.  He puts in a great performance as a very earnest, self-deluded guy who hasn't the faintest idea how to deal with his own success.  Frankly, I'm amazed he wasn't nominated for an Oscar for this role, and I never thought I'd ever say that about a guy who used to call himself Marky Mark.  Julianne Moore is terrific as Amber Waves, the porn starlet who acts as a mother figure to the other people (particularly the men) in her films.  William H. Macy is pathetically funny and tragic as Little Bill, and Phillip Seymour Hoffman is excellent as Scotty, the production guy who hangs out with these porn stars as his sad little way of being close to fame.  Don Cheadle, John C. Reilly, Heather Graham, (even Nina Hartley, an actual porn actress!). . . the list of knockout performances goes on and on.  I'd also be remiss if I failed to mention Burt Reynolds' turn as Jack Horner, the porn producer who likes to think he's making quality films for the masses.  Watching Reynolds in this film put in a quiet, understated performance without his typical mugging or hamming it up for the camera was a real treat, a remind of why Reynolds was once considered a truly great actor.Director P.T. Anderson is clearly a fan of Robert Altman and Martin Scorsese  their influences show up not only in how Anderson deals with an ensemble cast, but in his choices of sweeping camera shots, of music, and how he often chooses to unfold his story.  That's okay, because he also manages to take those influences and make something quite original  and very gut-wrenching. `Boogie Nights' is a marvelous tale.  Watch it.  A

reviews.review_title: this is cinema at it's finest
reviews.content: Paul Thomas Anderson is possibly the only good thing that has come from the 90's. Along with David Fincher and Danny Boyle, he's most certainly the best director to immerge from that hard decade for film. Pardon the cliché but `this is a must see for film lovers', the script is amazing, the performances are stunning, a plot to die for, excellent soundtrack, editing and the cinematography is mind blowing. Throughout the film Anderson puts a whole new meaning to the word steady cam, he uses it to great effect and again and again, meanwhile we sit there and go "wow". And the main thing is that he's not trying to over stylise the film just for the hell of it, like Guy Richie or even David Fincher with Fight Club. Each shot is meticulously planned with the audience in mind as well as the films narrative, enabling us to dig deeper into the characters in the film that struggle to find dignity in their lives. One particular shot in the film that I favour is when the camera holds close up on Mark Wahlberg's character for about a minute, intensifying the situation and enabling us to relate with his character. Ultimately this is a film about humans, people being people, something that we can all relate to, watch and enjoy. Of course there is the language, violence and sex scenes, so it wouldn't be suitable for younger viewers but I don't see any other reason why anyone should miss out on a marvellous piece of cinema. And if you enjoy this then check out his other films Hard Eight and the three hours masterpiece Magnolia, which he should have, without a doubt, won best director for. But as for Boogie Nights 10/10.

All I can say about Boogie Nights is that perfection has its price.For people that are not looking for a typical plot, typical timing or a typical camera work, this is your choice; I say this because I know people that didn`t like this film and I really wonder why?. Let me comment on the genius behind all of this: Paul Thomas Anderson, who first surprised critics and audiences with his first film Sydney a.k.a. Hard Eight, he is simply the most intelligent film maker that appeared in Hollywood in the last 10 years ( in my personal opinion ) and he keeps surprising people around with Magnolia ( a genius masterpiece ) and his music videos. I`m just looking forward for his next film.

reviews.review_title: It could so easily have been ruined!
reviews.content: Here I am ten years later writing about what a good movie BOOGIE NIGHTS was; of course I'd heard about it, but...It's a movie about the porno industry for God's sake. And they didn't go overboard like BRYOND THE VALLEY OF THE DOLLS, or maudlin like STRIPTEASE or for that piece-of-garbage look that that thing with Kyle MacLachlan In it (SHOWGIRLS) went for and achieved.Brilliant casting makes for a pretty good show. My favoutite casting job was MILLER'S CROSSING, but there were also LORD OF THE RINGS, GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS and many more. BOOGIE NIGHTS raised the bar for predictive casting. Let me see ... who did I know before I saw them in this movie? Okay, Burt Reynolds. I knew Ron Ridgely was in PHILADELPHIA and William Macy starred in HOMICIDE. I had heard of a few of the rest but Burt Reynolds was the only household name; Now reflect on how early in the careers of these great actors was BOOGIE NIGHTS: Macy, Don Cheadle, Julianne Moore, John C. Reiley, Mark Wahlberg, Alfred Molina, Phillip Seymore Hoffman, Heather Graham. One last comment: I have never seen a movie with Philip Baker Hall or Rickey Jay that I didn't enjoy a lot.

reviews.review_title: excellent push out of my comfort zone!
reviews.content: This film honestly made me reevaluate what kind of media was within my comfort zone.I would say that by nature I am someone who tends to be discerning in choosing what I watch. I tend to stay with media within my comfort zone, on topics which I am comfortable with. However, this movie really has been making me question that view.It took me a moment to get drawn in by the plot but once I was I got drawn in and wasn't let go. By the mid-point of the film I was so emotionally tied up in the characters that I wasn't ready for things to change for them ( to the point where I left the room to relax ), but when I came back and finished the movie I was rewarded.The movie is just so, raw and real that I have to give it credit for how much it moved me.

reviews.review_title: More "feelgood" or "coming of age" than porno-type film
reviews.content: The first time I saw this film, I didn't really watch it deeply. All I saw was a story of sex, drugs, and unusual people.However, I finally saw it again last year, and I fell in love with it. This film, in some sense, follows the same very basic story as Hard Eight, Magnolia, and Punch-Drunk Love:Person (or people) begins in normal life, but something unusual happens triggering either a change, or at least deviation from normal behavior. There is this buildup of good events; it looks like things could only get better and better, but there is something obviously wrong going on. Something bad happens, and then begins the descent into hell. But, suddenly, there is an event that causes things to suddenly become perfect. And the hero goes back to life, but not as it was; he still has his experiences.Dirk Diggler's speech-to-the-mirror in the end really seals this sort of plot pattern in the end. It also, in my opinion, cements in a coming-of-age theme.Look beyond the surface of pornography, sex, etc. Realize that these characters (if they were real) are people, each with their own oddities, dreams, and soforth.

I heard that Mark Walhberg had some regret playing in the film but I'd say except for the last scene that he should be proud of it since it's a very interesting story with a great set of actors. Crazy times I guess and it's more a sociologic movie than any kind of movie for voyeurs if you see what I mean...

Boogie Nights isn't really an incisive look into the world of pornography. Instead it's more of a point and laugh comedy. Look at these idiots, the film seems to be saying. Look at what losers they are. You knock one out to these people. Therefore the film has kind of a smug tone to it, one that eschews real depth.The reason why I don't really feel for the characters in Boogie Nights isn't because they're messed up or because they're in porn, but because they're all so overwhelmingly stupid. Not one has a brain in their head. The best example is Reed Rothchild (he's even stupider than the monumentally brainless Dirk Diggler). He talks about bodybuilding, he does inane magic tricks, he recites awful poetry and his attempts at acting are cringe worthy. In fact, I'm convinced that John C. Reilly is having a laugh. Have a look at the way he makes a Bruce Forsyth pose when he's in the background in a restaurant scene in a Brock Landers film. And just look at him dancing when Dirk is strangling the cat in the music studio. It's a performance that is fun (it cracks me up) but it's not one that is grounded in reality.
