Consequently I can't feel anything for the character.And the same is true with Dirk Diggler. I can enjoy the performance and I can enjoy his story, but not for one second do I sympathise with him. He's just too dumb.Dirk's colossal stupidity is well established from the beginning. His mother rightly tells her half-wit son that he's stupid. Dirk, though, wrongly states that he isn't. Right from the start he's deluded. But his delusion continues to progress as the film develops. First he wants a name so sharp that neon signs will explode. Then he wants to make porn films with a story. And by the end he wants to make music. You can't feel for a man this thick. You can only squirm and laugh as he's reduced to whacking off in car parks. He's a loser.But the rise and fall (and rise again?) is fun to watch. One of my favourite scenes has to be his first porn shoot. There's a lot of funny stuff in there ("How long has it been since you've had a woman?" "A long time." "That's terrible.") but nothing can quite supplant the atrocity that is Dirk's come face. It looks like he's got an itch in his brain that he's trying to scratch by rhythmically scrunching his eyes. And then you've got Dirk as Brock Landers. Every frame in his film is comedy gold. You've got his mullet, his cap gun, him slipping before he does some karate moves, the badly choreographed fight and the actual dialogue in the film itself:"I could die of starvation." "Still hungry?" "Starving." "Why don't you feast on that?" "Okay." (Pause.) "Oh it's true." "What's that?" "You are Brock Landers." (Chug.)But I also like it when Dirk becomes a drug-addled mess. Suddenly he thinks he's an artist. He's talking about helping marriages and he's taking sole credit for the films. And then later on he's dictating terms to the director. The man's a fool. His meltdown elicits nothing but cackles  I particularly like the way he tries to karate chop the boss at the record studio.However, Dirk and Reed aren't the only imbeciles. There are plenty to go around. There's Scotty, the gay crew member who has a crush on donkey boy. There's Amber, the junkie who's lost her family. There's Little Bill, the pathetic cuckold. And there's Buck, the black country and western fan. But I do have to say, of the characters in the film, these four, as dense as they are, do garner a little bit of sympathy  they're slightly more well-rounded than Dirk. I certainly feel somewhat for Buck who wants to escape his porn past and start a legitimate business. He actually comes across as something of a human being. Ditto for Amber. And although Little Billy is overwhelmingly pathetic  grow a set of balls, man  Macy is a good enough actor to give the character a bit of depth. But the problem that the film has is that most of the time is spent with Dirk, and while its fun watching him mangle a Transformers song, most of the film is mocking in tone. As a result its pleasures are slightly more superficial than they could have been (just because the people are superficial, doesn't mean that the film has to be).And the film also suffers a little because it apes Scorsese (particularly Goodfellas). You've got the long steadicam shots, the whip pans and the heavy reliance on the music of the period. Technically it's near faultless, but it never feels particularly original. Indeed, the scene where Dirk apologises to Jack feels like a carbon copy of the scene in Goodfellas where Henry apologises to Paulie. And Dirk's coked up meltdown (which culminates in the amusing scene with Alfred Molina) feels almost identical to Henry Hill's. But although it's not quite as good as it could have been, it's still a very enjoyable film. And even though the characters are idiots, it says something for the film that the almost universal happy ending leaves you feeling satisfied (only the pederast investor gets an unhappy ending). But having said that, is Dirk going back to porn really a happy ending? Well, considering it's the only thing he's competent at (his come face prevents me from saying that he's good at it), I guess he should be grateful.And one last thing, this is the only film where Heather Graham has been properly cast. With a great rack and non-existent acting talent, she makes a convincing porn star.

Boogie Nights is a surprisingly good drama that deals with one man's rise and fall in the adult film industry. Mark Wahlberg delivers one of the best performances of his career as Eddie Adams, the young man who is spotted at his job as a busboy by porn filmmaker Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds), and who changes his name to Dirk Diggler, the newest and temporarily most popular porn star in the business. Wahlberg even managed to make the screaming, emotional scene very convincing, which is the type of scene that is almost always screwed up (see about 90% of Chasing Amy). Evidently, Horner's dream is to make an adult film that has a good story, and literally sucks the audience into it. Maybe there should have been some debate about whether or not that was possible, or necessary (who goes to see a porno for the story?), but it doesn't matter that there wasn't. The 1970s are very realistically created, in every way from the outfits to the disco soundtrack to the god-awful interior decorating. Heather Graham is also very convincing as Rollergirl, the high school girl who flunks out of school and works in the adult film industry as well. This, by the way, is one of the roles that makes her performance in Lost In Space totally unconvincing and impossible to take seriously. Poor William H. Macy plays one of his traditional, unenviable roles. Why does this guy always get awful parts in his movies?  This poor guy's wife is constantly cheating on him (in some cases, in the middle of a circle of gaping, nearly comatose people), and she clearly has no respect for him. And to make matters worse, being in the porn industry, no one seems to understand what his conflict is.
(spoilers) The majority of the film deals with the business aspect of adult films  everything from the hiring to the shooting to the big money and drugs and the awards ceremonies. While this aspect of the film was very well done, as was Dirk's eventual fall from celebrity status, there were a lot of things about the movie that were either very badly presented or just didn't make any sense. For example, near the end, when the donut shop gets robbed, the robber walks in with a gun and pays all of his attention to the black guy in the nice white suit while he's robbing the store, completely ignoring the rough looking redneck with the hunting magazine that was sitting in a nearby booth. And then, after all of them have ingeniously shot each other to death, Cheadle's character grabs the paper bag full of money off the floor and runs. Evidently, he didn't see the recent film A Lesson Before Dying (in which he starred), which was about a black guy in the 1940s who did that exact same thing and then faced murder charges in a heavily racist society. And then there is the scene where Dirk and a couple of his buddies go out to sell a large quantity of fake drugs to a big time drug dealer with the intent of robbing him (in a scene, by the way, where Sister Christian is playing, which is Marilyn Manson's favorite song). What the hell was going on in that scene?! There was some half naked Chinese kid walking around and casually lighting off dozens of fireworks in the freakin' house! This was one of the things about this movie that made no sense whatsoever and just should not have been there. Overall, despite numerous weaknesses, Boogie Nights is a very good film that is miraculously able to live up to all of the expected notoriety that it developed, given such facts as that Heather Graham gets naked in the movie and, of course, that infamous, groan inducing final scene. Ironically, I think that the film deserves extra praise because they had enough nerve to make a film about a topic that is not generally accepted by society. The thing that really makes Boogie Nights succeed is that it is based on reality. It's not attempting to use the nudity or the subject matter to pull along a weak script. All of the big porn stars eventually fall from stardom, and return to small and unappealing occupations. And the occasional pedophile winds up exactly where he belongs  in prison getting slapped around and treated like a bitch by a huge black man. Paul Thomas Anderson wrote and directed a film about the porn industry, which is one of the most hated industries in the world, and the film that resulted is not only informative about the workings of that industry, but also very entertaining.

Boogie Nights is a very entertaining, yet ultimately very shallow film about the San Fernando Valley porn industry in the late 70s-early 80s. The performances across the board are terrific, with Burt Reynolds and John C. Reilly standing out in particular. The direction by Paul Thomas Anderson is energetic, the writing is alternately funny and touching, and the cinematography is excellent. But, the film is not original and it has little to say. It's obviously modelled on Goodfellas, not to mention Raging Bull. It takes place within the porn film industry, but I didn't learn anything about that industry, and the way the film sugercoats the entire world the characters inhabit is a little ridiculous. That said, the film is well worth seeing, for it IS very entertaining and very well acted. But it's not an important or deep film, nowhere near as deep as the films it models itself on.

Paul Thomas Anderson transports you to the irresistible glamour of the 70s, and anything else quite the opposite. The characters are fascinating, the soundtrack is electrifying, the actors are dazzling, and the scenes are captivating. The best stories are those so crazy yet still grounded in reality - Boogie Nights. Perhaps the film's only fault, or possibly its greatest achievement, is the in your face erotica. Truly a modern masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Perhaps the most touching analysis of the porn industry ever made
reviews.content: In one of this film's most crucial scenes, porn director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) explains that his aim is to make an adult picture with a story that's compelling enough to keep the audience focused on the plot and not just the hardcore sex scenes. He wants to move the viewers, rather than arouse them. That sequence neatly sums up what Paul Thomas Anderson has achieved with his second feature, the stunning, oddly heartbreaking Boogie Nights.Set between 1977 and 1984, the picture tells us how lives can change thanks to the adult film industry: it is the golden years of porn cinema, and Jack Horner is the most successful filmmaker in that sector. He gets particularly lucky when he meets Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg), a 17-year old waiter with an unusually large manhood. After a night of drinks and sex in Jack's house, the young man happily accepts to become his new star, and the results show pretty quickly: Dirk Diggler, as he is now known, is the hottest name in the business, which means he can get whatever he wants, whether it's a fast car, nice clothes, ladies or drugs.Such "happiness", however, is not meant to last: being a porn star might change your life, but "change" does not necessarily mean "improve". The trouble starts when Floyd Gondolli (Philip Baker Hall) tells Jack the future of the industry is videotape, meaning there is no more need for professionals. As is that weren't enough, most of the cast and crew have problems of their own: Jack's leading lady, Amber Waves (Julianne Moore), is in the middle of a bitter custody battle with her ex-husband; Rollergirl (Heather Graham) is uncertain about what to do with her life; occasional collaborator Buck Swope (Don Cheadle) has trouble finding a real job; producer Little Bill (William H. Macy) has to deal with his adulterous wife. But the biggest liability is Dirk: filled with drugs and having an ego the size of his "torpedo" ("It's my big d*ck and I say when we roll!"), he and his partner Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly) make increasingly dangerous "business" deals with the wrong people, slowly making him realize super-stardom isn't that glamorous after all.On a technical level, Anderson gets more ambitious than he was while making his first film, Sydney, and delivers a flawless exercise in style with echoes of Scorsese (the beautiful opening tracking shot, the expert use of music), Altman (the brilliant handling of an ensemble cast, especially in the swimming pool sequence) and Tarantino (some of the characters and the dialogue, plus the off-screen violence). But what impresses the most is how he succeeds in getting a touching story out of an unconventional subject: rather than offering a two-hour montage of explicit sex (there are only two such scenes in the entire film) he focuses on the people involved in the making of this kind of flicks, with particular attention to how their lives are affected by what they do. Those expecting naked bodies are watching the wrong film: this is a chronicle of the experiences of flawed human beings in a peculiar context. Despite the premise, the movie is less interested in hardcore material than it is in the characters: layered, real and affecting, not to mention played by one of the finest ensemble casts in history (the standouts being Reynolds, Moore and Wahlberg), they are the real selling point of Anderson's poignant opus.Sex has always been used as a tool to tell stories. This film's greatness lies in taking that tool, using it to establish the setting, context and characters and then throwing it out of the window: Boogie Nights is not about sex, nor was it ever meant to be. It is a picture about life, loneliness and suffering, and that's what makes it one of the finest movies of 1997.

This film is one of the best films ever made period.It tells the story of the rise and fall and rise again of an adult movie star.I have nothing but love for this film,i always used to doubt it but one day i gave it a chance and its one of the best films ever made.The thing that makes this film so unique is that it is nothing like you have ever seen before,trust me there is no other film like it,if you had to compare it to any film it would probably be goodfellas,because everyone trusts each other,yes imagine goodfellas in the porn business.One of the reasons why I love this film so much is because the acting is so well done and perfectly executed,you really like the characters in this film particularly Mark Wahlberg's character as Dirk Diggler there is something so likable about him and his acting is superb and strangely something humorous.Sadly this film was overshadowed by Titanic at the time of its release but still this is easily the best film of that year and indeed one of the best of all time.I would give this film 6 out of 5 stars if i could.*****

reviews.review_title: First half meh, second half amazing
reviews.content:
Before you go into this movie you have to know that its a long ride. The first half wasnt really that interesting actually but I loved the second half. Mark Wahlberg was pretty good and many other actors.
The movie could have been better if it was only 2 hours long. There were great scenes in the movie and some scenes that could have been cut.
But overall it was a good movie

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of 1997
reviews.content: Briliantly acted, wonderfully told tale of the rise and fall of a porn star in the late 70s early 80s. Mark Wahlberg is great going from sweet boy to arrogant jerk. Burt Reynolds deserved the Oscar for supporting actor, not Robin Williams. The Ensemble cast is also used to amazing affect. Philip Baker Hall, John C. Riely, Don Cheadle, Heather Graham, William H. Macy & Philip S. Hoffman are all perfectly cast as this unconventinal "family". If not for L.A. Confidential, this would have been the best of 97.

reviews.review_title: The best film that has come, no pun intended, in a long while
reviews.content: This picture is better than most people think. It was not just about the porn industry like people that have not seen the movie think. It was about the people that make these movies and about the struggles and good times they saw during this drug infested era. The film also had the best ensemble cast since Short Cuts. They all did a fabulous job of making their characters come to life. The only problem with the film is in the later half Dirk Diggler is suddenly broke and selling fake cocaine to make money. The film did not explain how a big porn star like Dirk Diggler lost all his cash in that short amount of time.  Other than that the film is almost flawless. And I suggest that anyone who has not seen the movie to go see it because you will not be disappointed.

This film IS utterly amazing, their are no faults that are apparent in the viewing of this modern masterpiece. the music is exciting, fun, sometimes sad and fits it appointed scene perfectly, the characters about as prolific and interesting as ones you'd see in Pulp Fiction or American Beauty and the story... from dish boy to porn icon, the story of Dirk Diggler is one that'll stay in the mind of those who care to watch not only because it's so heart breaking, original and crazy but also due to the absolutely extraordinary portrayal by Mark Whalberg whose accompanied by other actors who give their all; Burt Reynolds, John C Reilly, Julianne Moore, Thomas Jane, Alfred Molina. All this is brought together by PT Anderson and his writing and directing that make the film perfect.

From writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson (Magnolia, There Will Be Blood), this might have looked like a really seedy film, focusing on the porn industry, but it is actually a really good portrayal of the times. Basically, in the late 1970's, high school drop out and bar worker Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg) is approached by adult filmmaker Jack Horner (Golden Globe winning, and Oscar and BAFTA nominated Burt Reynolds), who wants him to become his new big star. After running away from home, Edie practises a "scene" first with co-worker Rollergirl (Heather Graham), then he adopts the new name Dirk Diggler, and his "talent" is brought to the screen when he performs with Amber Waves (Oscar and Golden Globe nominated Julianne Moore). After many other "performances", and winning three awards at the 2nd Annual Adult Film Awards, Jack and Dirk, with co-star Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly) create a new sex-filled cop show called Brock Landers: Angels Live In My Town, which gets Horner much more notice. The cast and crew of Jack's celebrate the new year and head into the 1980's, but after seeing his wife with other men, Little Bill (William H. Macy) ends the life of his wife on the night, and then himself. One day though this success is taken away when Dirk loses his temper and flees after Jack is not ready to start filming when he is "ready". The various characters are now separating from Jack's world, he is trying to get a new talent off the street, Buck Swope (Don Cheadle) is trying to make it in the technology centre business with his own shop, and Dirk and Reed are getting involved with drug dealers like Rahad Jackson (Spider-Man 2's Alfred Molina). In the end though, apologies are made between Dirk and Jack, and the other characters all come back to continue the success they have lost and want back, and the film ends with Dirk finally showing us his "big talent". Also starring Philip Seymour Hoffman as Scotty J., Luis Guzmán as Maurice TT Rodriguez, Philip Baker Hall as Floyd Gondolli and Tomorrow Never Dies' Ricky Jay as Kurt Longjohn. It has a really good all star cast, the script makes it not like your typical sex filled film, and the direction is marvellous, a great sex, drugs and disco filled drama. It was nominated the Oscar for Best Writing, Screenplay Written Directly for the Screen, and it was nominated the BAFTA for Best Original Screenplay. It was number 26 on The 100 Greatest Sexy Moments. Very good!

reviews.review_title: Paul Thomas Anderson is a talented director
reviews.content: P.T. Anderson has created a world for us which is hard to look away from. His characters are so good at what they're doing in this film.  Mark Wahlberg gives a great performance as the bus boy in Torrance to the rising porn star Dirk Diggler of L.A.  All the actors were very good but this film really belongs to Burt Reynolds who gave a tour-de-force performance as Jack Horner. For this being Burt's greatest performance, he got royally screwed by the academy.  Like Robin Williams was THAT good in "Good Will Hunting". P.T. Anderson who did the equally good "Hard Eight", has great poise and energy in his writing. How could you every forget a name like Dirk Diggler?  "Boogie Nights" in my book was the best film in 1997 and is near a masterpiece to me.  Others will find it boring, disturbing, gross, whatever, the point is, that this is a film that people are going to remember for years.  P.T. is a breakthrough talent who in more years to come will be giving us more interesting films and this man will win an Oscar some day. Mark my words!

reviews.review_title: A 2h 1/2 gracious limp jumping over 8 years in the porn industry
reviews.content: I've seen 2 other movies by P.T. Anderson, Magnolia and There will be blood. All three are brilliantly crafted but disturbingly empty while the story lingers on and revels in distressing characters. So my opinion is P.T. Anderson should not write and be content with directing movies. As such it feels like a man-who-thinks-he-is-an-artist's work, with a lot of self-indulgence for the subject matter, and very little substance.In Boogie Nights the pornography business is seen as a nice family, with some occasional violence and an increasing drug consumption. Actually it could have been about a rock band or small time drug dealers. The pornography industry may be fascinating from the outside but it is more about people living from day to day and is thus not the least interesting, especially with the un-gritty look and feel P.T. Anderson gives his movie.Poor boy Dirk Diggler and his friends are neither bad nor nice, nor clean, not dirty. What they do has no meaning (sure, they are living from day to day) and they learn nothing, build nothing. OK some just happen to suddenly disappear in the process while one of them eventually gets a wife, a baby and the money to settle a 'real' business. Nobody's saved, nobody's doomed, everybody is just normal people: who cares about a movie like that? It is just episode after episode, starting 1977 and ending 1984, a patchwork of anecdotes making up for a story: style shall never be an excuse.

All the characters are in the porn business. But this movie isn't really about porn, it's about family, and we care about all of the family members. Every single one of them - from the main players down to the supporting ones played by the likes of Don Cheadle, William Macy, John C Reilly and Heather Graham. These are interesting people every moment they are on screen. Since they deal in skin flicks, all they have is each other to lean on as the outside world turns their backs on them.It's a testament to the actors, under the sure hand of Paul Thomas Anderson, that everyone is so compelling. Julianne Moore, one of my favourite actors, is sympathetic and heartbreaking as Amber Waves. Mark Whalberg, former rapper and model, who was ridiculed when he decided to get into acting, successfully shows the long journey of a lost boy desperately trying to matter. Technically, the film is vivid and interesting in its depiction of the 70's and 80's, plus it has consistently inventive camera work.The relationship between the characters, and what they do for a living is explored with patience, subtlety, breadth and depth. There are no saints or sinners but people just trying to get by. As we start in the 70's and move to the 80's (memorably), each character has to adapt to a world and industry that is moving away from what they have always known. Overall this movie just feels so authentic, speaking volumes over many other under-baked films. But despite the praise I've heaped on it, it isn't a classic. I didn't feel restless during the 2 and a 1/2 hour running time but by the end you feel that there are things left unsaid. A little too much is left open. I'm not just talking about a lack of resolution to the characters' story lines but a lack of resolution of the themes that Anderson has been juggling all along. Less is more to be sure, and the future of the characters is clearly in the balance, but they are all so closely linked in situation and destiny that there seems to be a definite way to end the film that wasn't tapped into. This lack of conclusive unity makes the film seem more bloated and over-baked.Put another way, the weaknesses in the film are magnified in Anderson's next film after this one - 'Magnolia.' 'Magnolia' was so long and had so many story lines that its impact was severely muted. It felt Robert Altman (rip) light. Anderson exercises a lot more control in 'Boogie Nights' and its definitely worth seeing if you like meaty and dramatic films that makes sure the little details are taken care of as well as the big ones. There's sex, drugs and violence but its not gratuitous.

reviews.review_title: Good period piece about the pitfalls of the porn industry of the late 70s-early 80s.
reviews.content: Boogie Nights is an excellent period piece of the late 70s and early 80s porn industry, but is really just a fable about the dangers of egotism and self-indulgence. We watch Eddie transform from a simple good-hearted busboy to the biggest star of the adult cinema industry, with all the money, women and drugs that come with that fame. The movie ends with the predictable moral that taking yourself too seriously leads to failure, as we watch all of the actor-characters sink into their own personal hells, as they mistake their fame and money for personal talent and success, only to realize too late that they're being consumed by the business that feeds their instant gratification. Burt Reynolds is excellent as the father figure director who is the center of the group of porn actors he recruits. Bill Macy turns in his usual great performance in a small role as the cinematographer whose wife (played by Nina Hartley, as an inside joke to all the porn fans in the audience!) can't stop having very public sex with other men, every chance she gets.

reviews.review_title: Just like Magnolia, brilliant, and bittersweet.
reviews.content: The movie was a brilliant piece of work. The acting great and the story unique. It all comes together greatly for a bittersweet ending you won't forget. I saw Magnolia first, and LOVED it. And so I rented this and felt the same way. I liked Magnolia better, but this is up there. If you want a great movie to rent. Rent this. If you want a better one to rent. Get Magnolia.You might just even get both. I am 13 and I think that P.T. Anderson is a genious. Some don't like his work, they think it is vulgar and disgusting. But when you think about it. All of these things happen or happened. And Paul just decided to tell them on screen, which I think personally is a great way to explain something with a weird tale. And boy does he layout his stories perfectly.Go Paul! Waiting for yet another one of your directorial masterpieces.

This is a classic that will be able to hold up with drama's to come simply because of the fact that it is shot with a 70's style and it's a story about the 70's.  It is funny, action-filled, entertaining and sad at the same time.  It has the effect to pull you into the lives of these poor folks and the consequences for their actions.  4 STARS!

reviews.review_title: Entertaining film about a 'seedy' subject matter
reviews.content: Interesting film that slipped under the radar on its release in 1997. The premise seems rather unfashionable. The late 1970s adult entertainment industry. The main star is Mark Wahlberg who begins the film in 1977 as teenager Eddie Adams. His life is literally a car crash. Further education is really not his forte rather fornication is! No what I mean is he becomes adult entertainment star Dirk Diggler. Under the direction of Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) he becomes a top porn star.The film isn't a porn fest rather it shoes the rapid rise of Diggler and the equally rapid fall due to drug misuse and age as the film focuses on the 1980s. Featuring an excellent soundtrack of my childhood including the likes of 99 Red Balloons! The cast is quite good including the already mentioned Wahlberg and Reynolds. Julianne Moore, the late Philip Seymour Hoffman and William H. Macy who suffers a shocking end to the 1970s.Directed by young filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson the 155 minute runtime is enjoyable.

reviews.review_title: great film; shows porn is mechanical
reviews.content: anderson's film revolving around dirk diggler and his foray into the porn industry is a gorgeously filmed piece showing the mechanicalness of the actors and actresses involved.  it is about how these people, who have become so revered in an offbeat sort of way by a cultic culture of followers, become numb to their own feelings and the pain that they endure to earn money.  never before was i so moved by a man once dubbed marky mark. and julianne moore and burt reynolds give smashingly realistic performances, it's uncanny.  definite rental material.

reviews.review_title: Didn't know if I liked it or hated it. * * 1/2
reviews.content: It's obvious when I watch a movie,I'll usually enjoy it or not.I had seen some films that I liked while there were others that I weren't so fond of."Boogie Nights" to me is a mixture of both.It's a trip through a time that I myself am familiar with being that I was born in 1972."Boogie Nights" is not the worst film I have ever seen and it certainly is not the best.Throughout the entire 2hrs and 30 min of this entire film,My opinions kept changing from "This film is not bad" to "Is it over yet?" and back again.What can I say about a film that gives me mixed opninions."Boogie Nights" is a film I would show some respect for due to it's cast and storyline.The film is basically about the rise and fall of the porn industry and it's star Dirk Diggler,played with a great performance by Mark Wahlberg.The former Marky Mark rapper sheds his light as a dramatic actor which almost earned him an academy award nomination fot best actor.Dirk Diggler is a young innocent teenager who enters into a world of the porn business.He becomes the porn film industrie's biggest porn star and is soon ahead of the game.Of course,Dirk owes it all to one man.Jack Horner.He is a hot porn filmmaker who in one scene discovers Dirk at a restaurant who immediately notices potential in Dirk.Although Dirk's real name is Eddie Adams. We see the kind of life Eddie lives with his parents.His mother represents the kind of parent that he probably wouldn't like to live with being that their relationship is not so mother and son.The only father Eddie(Dirk Diggler) has is the man who has caused him to be a sensation.Burt Reynolds plays the filmmaker who would rather shoot his films on film rather than video.Burt Reynolds was recognized with an academy award nomination for best supporting actor.From what I heard he was ignored of a nomination for "Deliverance" due to a centerfold he did.I do not know if that's a rumor or not but it was not a rumor when he finally got his respect in the form of an Oscar nomination.Watching this film was like playing with a bag of mixed emotions."Boogie Nights" is also on the goodside due to it's performances by Don Cheadle("Rush Hour2",'Family Man" and "Traffic"),Julianne Morre and Heather Graham.The film had certain points that irritated me.I was never fond of the 70s or early 80s which is why I was blocking my ears on the way home listening to that Rick Springfield song "Jessie's Girl" in my head.That took me back into a time that I did not want to go into.The 70s to me were dull but then I was a kid.But I was old enough to look around and see for myself and watching "Boogie Nights" was like opening a door that was meant to be locked."Boogie Nights" is not a bad film.it has great performances and a decent story but the film gave me to many mixed emotions.What can you say about a film that confuses you like that?Roger Ebert gave this film **** which means that he really enjoyed it.I am not Roger Ebert so my opinion is this:Everone has their own opinions.Only problem with my opinion is it zig zags in different directions because of this film."Boogie Nights" will be remembered as an important film to some people but to me,I had no idea what to think of it.

I was born at the beginning of the seventies and I could appreciate this look back in time. It was well written and I really felt for the characters. I give it ten out of ten. This movie has everything and the soundtrack is a time capsule in its self

Instead of a script with an engaging plot and meaningful theme Boogie Nights presents nothing more than a list of scenes connected only by subject matter.  Some are not really attached to anything, like the wife of one of the film crew fornicating with various partners surrounded by onlookers, all without apparent purpose.  Ostensibly we are supposed to read meaning into this.  Eventually the man shoots her and one of her lovers.  Is this a stab at comedy, tragedy?  Perhaps, we are finally urged to consider, it is metaphorical of the film or the world of Porn.  Ultimately we are left without the real answer.The only thing this distasteful concoction of a film achieves is to push the envelope of probity and civility out a bit further.  Thus, many critics and audiences have shouted, "Brilliant," despite the fact that nothing is brilliant at all here.	Once again, we see the emotionally damaged and others of borderline intelligence trotted out and drawn to Porn, the artificial world of make-believe filmmaking.  This form of filmmaking reduces for us all the quality of life and steps on the triumph of the human spirit.  Indeed, Boogie Nights itself joins Porn and becomes a part of this phenomenon of the declination of the value and meaning of life and the ascendance of barbarism.

reviews.review_title: Mind-blowingly good - just like Anderson's "Hard Eight."
reviews.content: Paul Thomas Anderson is one of the greatest directors to come along in recent years.  He superbly directs this epic film, bringing out most of his casts' best roles to date.  There is not a bad performance in the picture. Great soundtrack, too.  If you loved this, you're sure to like Anderson's first film, "Hard Eight."  It's a small film whereas "Boogie" is a huge film, but both are fabulous.  If there is one minor complaint to be lodged, it's that some shots or scenes could have been slightly trimmed (some reaction shots are held for a LONG time).  But this is nitpicking, as nothing in the film is superfluous.  The audience I saw this film with the first time was completely knocked out.  I've met folks who find this film boring and poorly made - and, believe me, they're not people you want to be discussing film with.

Paul Thomas Anderson has truly created a masterpiece. Boogie Nights is, oddly enough, just as poignant as it is funny. And that's the movie's chief strength -- the story, which is essentially about family, showcases a wide range of themes that covers everything from success and frustration to failure and redemption. The film benefits from a great cast with winning performances from all involved. Mark Wahlberg gives an especially charismatic and commanding turn as the movie's central character, Dirk Diggler, proving himself adept at realizing Anderson's brand of comedy. Burt Reynolds and Julianne Moore, as Wahlberg's surrogate parents in the porn industry, both bring an ironic likability to their parts, making them genuine and human. The rest of the supporting cast is not to be forgotten, but the standout is John C. Reilly as Dirk's friend and fellow actor Reed Rothchild. Reilly is hysterical, simple as that. Make sure to stay tuned for the deleted scenes at the end of the special edition to get a better idea of Reilly's comic genius. Perhaps most amazing is the maturity that writer and director Anderson exhibits at such a young age. He was no more than 26 or 27 when he made this movie, yet the structure of the screenplay and his wildly entertaining style is solid and interestingly complex. He seems perfectly capable of maintaining more than a few storylines and subplots, keeping them all intriguing and spinning them out to satisfying endings. With a perfect track record and a promising film called Magnolia on the way, Anderson is emerging as one of the country's most skilled filmmakers. Hopefully, we'll have many more films from this brilliant young auteur to look forward to.

They should have left the outtake scenes in,especially the one where they're sitting around a glass table snorting coke. Whenever I watch this I kinda sneak in that outtake in between. PTA's tour de force.... The opening crane shot swooping into the Hot Traxx disco with The Emotions blaring so loud gives me goosebumps everytime. It really makes you feel you're inside 1977,and then the progression from that into the early 80's scenes is amazing. If Tarantino is Coppola of the 90s than PTA is Scorsese of the 90s imo. Especially with this film... Like Clockwork Orange though I feel the first half is great,and the second half is where it gets depressing and more serious. Good coke movie along with the likes of Jekyll & Hyde Together Again!!

reviews.review_title: Fantastic look at the porn industry in late 70s/early 80s
reviews.content: This is a remarkably well-made picture depicting life in the porn industry during the late 1970s and into the early 1980s. Fine work displayed by the entire cast,and the music fits perfectly with the mood of each individual scene. Each character is illustrated well,with a small story within each one,from Little Bill's struggles with his sexually unfaithful wife,to Amber Waves' custody battles,to Dirk Diggler's rise in fame only to have it come crashing down because of drugs and arrogance. Excellent camera usage,and brilliant direction by Paul Thomas Anderson. Burt Reynolds' finest work since Deliverance. Highly recommended.     **** out of ****

reviews.review_title: One of the Best Films Ever Made....for real.
reviews.content: This film is absolutely terrific!  It's about a sort of "adoptive family" of people in the porn industry but it isn't about porn and it's far from being one.  Rarely do we get even one 3rd Dimensional character in most movies, let alone an entire cast full of them.  It's one of my favorite films of all time and easily the best film of 1997 and one of the 10 best films of the decade.  I have seen it over a dozen times.  I recommend this picture to EVERYONE over the age of 14 years.  Shouldn't be missed.  If at all possible, watch the widescreen letterbox version of the film, such as the great sounding and looking DVD. I can't wait for Paul Thomas Anderson's next film, Magnolia.

Boogie Nights follows a theme that is extremely familiar to gangster films (although it doesn't fit into that genre itself) - the rise and the fall. We see the rise of several individuals, some of them from complete obscurity, to achieving great heights ... and then falling from grace due to their excesses.I believe that this is the first feature by writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson, and it's a great start!  I saw elements of other directors' influences, such as Robert Altman, but the film holds its own in originality and plot development.Character development is the movie's finest feature.  I really identified with all of the characters and felt their pain and their success with them. All of the performances were brilliant. (It was especially good to see a small part performed by real-life porn veteran, Nina Hartley).Basically this film combines comedy and tragedy with the result being one of the best films of 1997, which was snubbed at the Oscars (probably due to the "racy" - as they would say - subject matter, and the general conservatism of the Academy.

reviews.review_title: Loosely Based on the Life of John C. Holmes
reviews.content: "Eddie Adams" (Mark Wahlberg) is a high school dropout who lives with his mother and step-father and works at a nightclub as a dishwasher. One night while working he is noticed by a man named "Jack Horner" (Burt Reynolds) who is a director of pornographic films and is looking for new talent. So when Jack learns that Eddie is endowed with an extremely large penis he asks Eddie to audition in front of him with an aspiring female actress named "Rollergirl" (Heather Graham). One thing leads to another and not long afterward Eddie has moved in with Jack, changed his name to "Dirk Diggler" and becomes a star in the adult film industry. Unfortunately, like everything else in this particular business, a person can only stay on top for so long and soon Eddie's pride, lack of maturity and his newly acquired cocaine habit begin to take a toll on him--and all of his colleagues as well. Now rather than reveal any more I will just say that Mark Wahlberg's character is largely based on the life of John C. Holmes with a number of other lesser-known individuals and scenarios thrown in for good measure. To that effect, this was a highly acclaimed film with both Burt Reynolds and Julianne Moore (as "Amber Waves") being nominated for several awards for their performances including "Best Supporting Actor" and "Best Supporting Actress" respectively. Having said that, however, although I thought that this was a satisfactory film, I have to admit that it seemed a bit too long and lost its focus along the way. There were just one too many sub-plots. For that reason I have rated it accordingly.

The director and much of the cast are also responsible for Magnolia so it's not surprising this is a great movie. The film follows the film career of Dirk Digler and is apparently loosely based on the life of the porn star John Holmes. Although not quite as disturbing as 8mm this certainly shows the dangers of being sucked into the world of porn. The people that make the money from porn ruthlessly exploit the people that star in the movies. Why Burt Reynolds didn't win an oscar for his performance is a mystery. Other notable performances are turned in by Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, John C Reilly, William H Macy and Mark Wahlberg, but that isn't surprising as these are some of the finest character actors plying their trade in Hollywood. For anybody who just wants to see what all the fuss is about, just watch the last 30 seconds and apparently it's not Mark Wahlberg !

reviews.review_title: Great film. Excellent drama, with great performances.
reviews.content: I remember renting Boogie Nights and my dad was so shocked that i did and he wanted me to take it back, but luckily i kept it and i have to say that this film was great. When you get past all the sex and drug use, you see a story about being on top one minute, and falling back to earth when you become cocky. i don't know much about the porn industry of the 70's and early 80's, but this movie is very detailed. Paul Thomas Anderson captures the very essence of the 70's. The one thing i enjoyed the most about this film was the music. There is a really good dance sequence in this film as well.The acting is good across the board. Mark Wahlberg gives a good performance as Dirk Diggler. He should have been rewarded for his performance because it truly shows he has acting talent. Julianne Moore was the best part of the film. I thought she gave the best performance in the film. Also good is Heather Graham in her first starring role. *** out out of ****

This was the best film of 1998 and one of the best of the 90's. Yes, it is a rip off of Goodfellas. But as the saying goes, good poets borrow, great poets steal. And PTA has stolen brilliantly from some of the best, plus added some genius touches of his own. I gave this a ten (which is very rare for me).The main reason I am commenting on this though (cause i could just rave all night) is all those people who have seen it on VHS standard issue...what are you thinking? This deserves the FULL SCREEN experience. Look at the ratio it was shot in! I saw it 5 times at the cinema and haven't bothered to watch it on video.Nuff said!

reviews.review_title: Simple, but complex at the same time
reviews.content: I was a little blown away by this film the first time I watched it. How couldn't you? This film has so many variant, complex themes to fit variant, complex characters yet it's actually extremely easy to follow. Never once was I the slightest bit confused. Even on my favorite films, I had a bit of confusion in some areas, but not this one. Another thing to note was that this was Paul Thomas Anderson's 2nd film and he was only 27 when this was released (25 when he wrote the script). In spite of that, this film manages to be much better made than some filmmakers twice or thrice his age. I don't really even have a problem with this movie. The only minor complaint is that the first shot might be a little too show-offy, but it's completely forgivable considering the ride that this film took me through. Definite recommend.

reviews.review_title: Porn stars struggle for acceptance and self progression
reviews.content: Boogie Nights is one of the best films I have ever seen.  Director Paul Thomas Anderson does a superb job of putting this film together.  A few things that stand out include the little shots of coffee being poured and film turning, the mix scene of Dirk's beating and Jack's beating of the limo guy, and the characterization elements. Throughout, we see little signs of the people's ambitions outside the porn business.  We see Reed doing magic in the background, Buck talking about stereos, and Amber showing signs of motherhood.  Julianne Moore and Burt Reynold's performances stand out the most in this excellent film.
The movie is 2 hours and 35 minutes. It could've been 1 hour and 30 minutes. Too long.

reviews.review_title: A vivid depiction of life in 70's & 80's California
reviews.content: This is one of the few movies that I would rate 10/10. First of all the peformances are just the best I have seen in a long time. The ensemble cast is great. Julianne Moore gives the peformance of a lifetime and definately deserved to win the best supporting actress Oscar. Burt Reynolds, Heather Graham and Mark Wahlberg all gave excellent peformances too. Credit should go to Paul Thomas Anderson for this great screenplay. Boogie Nights is a film that will go into my top 10 favourite films of all time. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: Great camerawork, great music, great script and the greatest and one of the most underrated pics of the 90`s!
reviews.content: When I first heard about this movie it didn`t appeal to me. But when I saw it (about one year ago) i knew at once that I had missed out on probably the greatest film of the 90`s!! I sat for two and a half hours and I was simply stunned! I cried, I laughed and when the end came I was sad. I really didn`t want it to end. First of all, I was deeply moved and touched by this film and I can`t say it enough, Mark Wahlberg is simply magnificent in this film and portrays Dirk Diggler with passion and skill. It`s really a kind of sad story and you begin to feel sorry for Dirk, but you know that he has himself to thank.The best thing about this pic maybe, is the acting. Academy Award nominee Burt Reynolds in the role of his life! Great and if nothing less, SUPERB!! Don Cheadle, Luis Guzman, Julianne Moore, Melora Walters, John C.Reilly, P.S.Hoffman, William H.Macy, Phillip Baker Hall and Heather Graham!! Every each and one of them delivers blistering performances and makes this movie unforgettable.The director/writer Paul Thomas Anderson is one of my personal favourits and i do believe he will continue to make great films in the future. His excellent style in camerawork and his intense and brilliant scripts are all known qualities. I think and I mean that he really deserved that Oscar for Best Original Screenplay!! I would already categorize P.T.Anderson as one of greatest and most promising director/writers of all time.The best movie of the 90`s and why stop there?! This movie is the best movie I have ever seen and I think it`s one of the all-time top-ten!! I give it 10/10!! So, see this movie and do not miss out on the great soundtrack that is also a strong part of the film."I am a big,bright,shining star"-Dirk Diggler-

reviews.review_title: The first film of the rest of my life
reviews.content: The first time I saw Boogie Nights it was on cable ( I know,...tsk tsk).I had heard it was horrible so I didn't bother to go see it in the theater. The I got to thinking something that provoked that strong of a reaction had to be worth my time. What an understatement that is!Boogie Nights is the first film I saw that was able to combine Comedy and Drama equally and effectively. Within the first 15 minutes of the movie,(the TK421 scene) I knew two things. This wasn't going to be just another T&A flick and that it was going to be a great parody of the porn business in the 70s. When the 80s were ushered in (dramatically), I realized there was more to this film than comedy. As the final notes of what P.T. Anderson referred to as "broken circus music" faded, I wanted to go through the whole journey again because while watching Boogie Nights I go through the whole gamut of emotions. That is why this movie is so much more than just "worth your time". Finally. as kind of a side note another thing about Boogie Nights that makes it such a superior film is that it is able to employ Tarantinoesque style (hip pop culture references etc.) in a very humanistic manner. For example you won't hear Reed Rothchild say " I just shot Dirk in the face." in this movie or any other PT Anderson picture for that matter. That is why I will never be disappointed or feel cheated after seeing a PT Anderson picture.

reviews.review_title: A quality film with its flaws
reviews.content: Given the time and place of the action and the very theme of the film, it is clear that this is a controversial film. Although there was a danger that the film would be cheap or look cheap, thanks to the great work of the director, this did not happen. The combination of genres, different camera angles and a great cast made this a very high-quality work. I'm not one hundred percent sure, but I felt the impact of Pulp Fiction, purely my impression. However it seems to me that the porn industry is the main character here and everyone else is just there to assist. It bothered me because this film seemed to me like a set of good scenes that don't always have to be connected. Almost every character has a problem, it does not have its own special story with the beginning and / or the end but its only purpose is to get an insight into the second half of the seventies and the beginning of the eighties of the last century.

The acting, directing, script--all brilliant. It was graphic but did not exactly glamorize what was being portrayed. The colors, music, settings all showed a lot loneliness and neediness of theses peoples worlds.No story cop-outs (like let's make the porn star become high school valedictorian) in this film. I have only two complaints. The fight scene between Eddie and his mom seemed a little pushed--but still good. And the final scene seemed like an add-on. That was not meant to be a pun when I wrote it, but what the heck. This film reeks of humanness.

reviews.review_title: Overrated but it has it's moments
reviews.content: This movie could have easily been about 45 minutes shorter and still gotten it's point across. PT Anderson takes himself way to seriously, and needs to shorten his movies a bit. Having said that, the recreation of the late '70s/early '80s is pretty great, as are all the performances. Burt Reynolds is a complete tool and so was Marky Mark (in real life) but they definitely bring It in this movie. The best job is done by Julianne Moore, as a coke-addicted porn star fighting a losing battle for custody of her son. If you ever rent this movie and get bored ('cause it is looooong!) hang in there because the drug deal at the end is one of the funniest moments in film history. I actually taped JUST that scene when this came on HBO a few years ago and I still have it on tape ... I can't think of any other scene in film history that's made me want to do that - wait! I taped the opening conversation between the sheriff and the store clerk in the beginning of "From Dusk 'Til Dawn." ANyway, "Boogie Nights" is worth checking out but not as good as some people think it was. "The Basketball Diaries" is still Marky Mark's best film.

I have a bias and that is Burt Reynolds, I have watched Burt since I can remember, he was always on TV when I was very young and loved greatly by my family at that time in the early 80's so when I saw this film being made in honour of that time period it already piqued my interest.The film on first viewing was amazing and quite a ride, I saw it again on multiple viewings in the cinema with friends who all thought it was a great piece of cinema,
first second and third acts of the film all stand out and the entire cast delivers on so many levels, I have since rewatched it over the years and really have come to enjoy the film for what it is, 10/10 its aged well and its a classic.RIP Burt, its been a few years since his passing but he had that much of an impact on me I always dedicate a tribute to him on anything he has stared in, Phillip Seymour Hoffman as well.

When I first heard about this movie, I thought it was gonna be graphic, with no story and very bad acting.  Boy, was i wrong.  The movie was like nothing I had ever seen up until then and I don't think any movie has compared to it since.The story telling was great and the acting was top notch, performed by one of the best all around casts ever put together.  Everyone has one special thing, and thanks to P.T Anderson, we all have this movie to enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful film of a somewhat touchy subject matter...
reviews.content: What can I say but that this is a simply beautiful and amazing film.Right now, let me say that it's NOT a movie my grandma would approve of but hey...I know that the whole subject of the 70's porn industry isn't exactly something that people would admittedly want to outright say that they admire, and I myself am somewhat reserved in recommending this movie to others because everyone will look at it differently.  But still, it's just such a great story!  Eddie's rise to stardom and the life of luxury and then his eminent downward spiral.Another aspect that most people might not notice or admire (although all movie buffs would of course) was Anderson's use of extended shots to capture many different conversations and actions going on in the same scene.  The transitions are really cool.  Sometimes I wonder how many takes it might have taken them to get just what they wanted out of a single shot.Finally the part of the film that really makes it stand out for me is the amazing use and choices of music throughout the movie.  The music really gets you into the groove of that swingin' party life of the 70's.  If nothing else, go get the soundtrack.Overall for me, I would say that this movie is an 8.5/10, but the music just bumps it up to 9.5 or 10/10.  It's just that good.

The best thing about this film is without a doubt the cast: Heather Graham, Julian Moore and Burt Reynolds are great, Don Cheadle brilliant (as he usually is) in his small role as Buck Swope and Mark Wahlberg is fantastic.The movie is also good, even though it seems to go on for maybe half an hour too long. But the characters are interesting, and so is the story and I found that I was very entertained and interested almost all the time. Boogie Nights is a funny, clever, touching, and really rather sad movie about the world of pornography.

P.T Anderson is a genius of situational and character drama, and he works that to perfection in Boogie Nights. Every character is introduced and built in only a way that Anderson can do, so that even the minor characters are relevant to the plot in some way. The scenes in this movie are intense, bittersweet, and at times devastatingly funny, another mark of the quality of director behind the project.  Every actor/actress in the film turns in memorable performances and each have a unique scenerio that all entangle into one humungoid complex plot. i guess the only thing that needs to be said about this is that there is not one area of film that movie lacks in, and everything is done right. This is why i gave it a perfect score...oh yeah and the final scenerio is friggin I N T E N S E

Someone once told me that when looking at old photographs and portraits they could not help but think the people in them were dead and that this was a funny feeling. Well, I'd imagine that looking at porn from the 1970s and early 1980s would give the same feeling. This film is like a long, continuous reel of behind-the-scenes footage from old pornos  there are long-drawn shots, shaky and intimate camera movement and it all presents a very 'objective' view of its subject, eliminating the narrator factor in the product.It's an enjoyable product too, featuring an impressively cast all-star ensemble as the broken, bruised, decaying 'old' porn-stars, snorting coke and not really giving a damn about anything besides the art of film-making. Being a portrayal of an era rather than a plot-driven piece, there is really not much else to the story than that, unless you want to count Dirk Diggler's (Mark Wahlberg) claim to fame in the adult industry. "Boogie Nights" is, in spite of its upbeat title, a harrowing film that navigates the themes of decay and out-of-date values. For example, the once big-shot adult-movie director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) is at the height of his career when the film first zooms in on him, but toward the end he is fatally fading which culminates when a frat-boy screams at him: "Your movies are sh it nowadays." He snaps, beats him up, but returns a broken man.Because the film deals with such a 'fun' subject (sex, and the porn industry) in such a tragical way, it manages funny and heartbreaking at the same time. I do not know of many other movies that accomplish this, but "Boogie Nights" perfects it. The scene in which a fantastically broken, defeated and soft-spoken Julianne Moore sits on the bed with Heather Graham  both high as kites, and snorting  and the latter asks her if wants to be her mom, it is a scene so harrowing and simultaneously funny that it's nearly too much to take.The best description I can give of this film is that it is a 2 and a half hours long orgy of sex, drugs and pornstars walking around in a bubble of out-of-touch values, fading fame and a life that will disappoint them. It's well-acted, occasionally poignant and often funny but ultimately it lacks too much direction and a clear sense of point. It leads me to thinking that if you strip it of its sex factor, then would people enjoy this film? For instance, if director Anderson had zoomed in on the car-selling industry during the 1970s-1980s, would we even give a damn? I doubt it.7 out of 10

I would love to report that Boogie Nights is a great film.  Clearly, many IMDB users believe it is.  Indeed, for the first two hours, it is engrossing, beautifully and originally shot, and contains great performances by Burt Reynolds, Heather Graham, Julianne Moore, and Mark Wahlberg.What happens to Boogie Nights is a bad case of director's overindulgence. As the movie grinds into its third hour, Anderson runs out of ideas and the cracks in the characters begin to show.  Wahlberg goes from tortured to merely whiny.  A botched drug-deal subplot comes out of nowhere and Tarantinos around for awhile before going *back* to nowhere; if it weren't for the characters, you'd think it was from another movie.  My friends kept turning to me and saying "Is it over *now?*  How about *now?*"  Not even the sight of an obvious prosthetic in Wahlberg's fly felt like a payoff.Anderson is a wizard with visuals and excellent with casting, but needs to take a few lessons in storytelling (there is practically no plot to speak of) and work with a judicious editor.  Until then, he's merely good, with gusts up to genius.

This was a film I had no delusions about. one which, despite my policy of entering the screening room with little or no opinion on the film, I had nonetheless decided that this would probably be a cheesy, trifling dud. well, I was VERY pleasantly surprised. this has got to be one of the very best films ever made. It has to be one of the most mature films I have ever seen. The only compliant is that there were times where I wanted to know more about the minor characters, especially at the end. at the same time, that is part of what makes the film work so well. William H. Macy, not Burt Reynolds, as great has he was, gave the films best supporting performance. His was a persona which captured the tone and flavor of this films dark spirit. the other notable performances came from Mark Wahlberg in a break-out role, and Julianne Moore, as heartbreaking figures of self destruction. As I viewed the images before me, I was stunned, moved, captivated as I have rarely been during a modern film. there are scenes in this film which finally show people as people, that life is life, and that the good times perhaps aren't always so good, but they may be all you have. INCREDIBLE.

This film is about some film workers, actors and actresses in the American porn industry in the 1970's.Boogie Nights spends a lot of time being hedonistic. There are endless parties, sex, alcohol and drugs. Yes it could be very authentic, but sometimes it feels as if the plot is interspersed in between the hedonism. Not that there is anything wrong with it, I just feel that the film could have been a lot shorter and achieve the same results.I particularly like the characters played by Mark Wahlberg and Julianne Moore, as their acting skills are great as usual. The Rollergirl (Heather Graham) gets too annoying with her perpetual skating, and I feel a little sorry for Heather Graham because her role is reduced to being an empty vessel who only needs to look pretty.I like the dance sequences in the scene where Dirk leads the dancing on a dance floor with Rollergirl briefly joining. After all the fun, most characters get back to square one, except Dirk because of his "talent". It's an OK film to watch.

Some topics don't really need movies made about them--diarrhea and porno movies are two that come to mind. Porno movies are bad enough in that they capitalize on a prurient fascination with copulation. Plots are optional. Semi-porno movies purporting to be *about* porno movies are nothing more than the movie companies trying to cash in on the porno business without tarnishing their name.I like Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore and Burt Reynolds, but I liked them all better prior to seeing this disgusting mess. Not that they didn't act well; it's just that this is a movie which the world would be a better place had it never been made. I will give credit to Moore, Reynolds and especially Wahlberg for taking roles that could lead to everlasting embarrassment. Maybe they were broke, I don't know. That would make more sense than the notion that they saw artistic merit in this script.Maybe the sequel will be Showgirls Boogy Knights?I rated this a 1 only because there was no zero available.

reviews.review_title: Harbinger of the "Go-Go" eighties told through the porn industry
reviews.content: AIDS was just beginning to surface.  The "moral majority" had not gained sufficient political strength.  The Mafia was making a killing inventing the home video industry.  And the first "superstars" of porn were coming into the mainstream (Linda Lovelace not withstanding).Lots of money, free sex, a changing technology were all that were needed to burst the balloon that was porn.  The characters of boogie nights were riding the wave until it crashed on the beach.  Although I believe the pressure of having to "perform" probably ate up more promising stars than drugs, I believe this film was an excellent allegory of what was to happened later in the finance industry than what happened in the porn industry.

An interesting companion piece to true documentaries of John C. Holmes. Unfortunately, it doesn't deal with what ultimately killed Holmes, and it certainly could have benefited from doing so.  Burt Reynolds and Mark Wahlberg got the most praise for this, but I felt the true stars were Julianne Moore as the cocaine-sniffing mother wannabe, Don Cheadle as a black man struggling with identity as pornstar/stereo-salesman in some wild getups and William H. Macy, who's wife is the ultimate slut.  Not to mention a nearly unrecognizable Alfred Molina.  Macy's new year's eve bash and Cheadle's chance for a better life after a donut shop robbery gone wildly wrong are probably the two best scenes in the movie, or at least the two best shot. What this movie does best is show how power can easily corrupt in its various forms.  However, none of the characters apparently learn anything from their dark downward spiral as they all rebound and return to their normal lives.

Utter garbage! I had high hopes for this movie, and it certainly sounded like it was right up my alley. But alas it is definitely one of the worst I've seen! What a pointless, plodding exercise in self indulgence! How could this be critically acclaimed and Showgirls be lambasted as one of the worst films ever? They are frighteningly similar in a lot of ways, and I think Showgirls was a lot more entertaining. Marky Mark is no more of an actor then Elizabeth Berkely. The second half of the movie is just a long, pointless Tarantino rip-off that is even harder to watch then 2 Days In The Valley. When I think of this movie's success, all I can think about is the story about the Emperor's New Clothes. Once the ball starts rolling with critics ranting and raving about it, most people are already convinced they are going to love it. If they don't then they don't "get it". Rubbish! The same goes for the Blair Witch Project. I am a big horror fan, but hated that. So people tell me I am either a blood and guts addict, or I have no imagination. Huh? It simply wasn't scary, it was a bloated boring version of MTV's Real World getting lost in the woods. Boogie Nights is chock full of loathable characters doing stupid things, what a waste of time! AVOID!

Of all the characters that were tied up neatly at the end, Becky Barnett was left without an fair ending. I would have preferred to see a short scene somewhere in the last 10 minutes where we see Becky's new life -- rather than a mid-film exit after such an important role in the early scenes. She was clearly a part of the "family". A big improvement to an already amazing movie would have been to show us her "new life" -- whatever that turned out to be.I wish it would have shown her in a church, personally, having someone ask her a question about her former life in LA -- then seeing her respond with a lie such as "I was a teacher". The implication would have been that she is going to live the rest of her life trying to hide and repent from her years in porn. It would have been yet another tragic ending as Becky lives in self-exile and constant fear that her shameful secret will somehow be revealed...

If you wanted an example of perfect filmmaking to come from a new director in the 1990s, many would instantly choose Pulp Fiction. It's the most logical option, and certainly higher regarded when compared to Anderson's second feature, Boogie Nights. But what Boogie Nights has that Pulp Fiction doesn't is the deep character details and backstories. In Pulp we jump from character to character with little rhyme or reason whereas in Boogie, we start with Eddie Adams and end up with his new persona, Dirk Diggler. I've always felt a stronger connection with Boogie Nights and when it comes to a rewatch, it's more enjoyable overall.The dynamite 70s soundtrack is a prime example of how the movie creates such a great atmosphere of the era. Of course, set design is a major factor but as a lover of music from that era, it was great to see so many awesome songs crop up. Burt Reynolds' character is my favourite in the movie; it's a real shame he didn't want to ever watch the movie post-release. In my opinion, it's his best role- he got a Golden Globe win and an Oscar nom for his turn as Jack Horner, the calm and cool Movie Director that Dirk finds himself working with.Talk about an ensemble cast! Wahlberg, John C. Reily, Julianne Moore, Don Cheadle, Heather Graham, Luiz Gusman, William H. Macy, Phillip Seymour Hoffman and Alfred Molina. Genius casting across the board, no matter how small or insignificant the role. They each get certain scenes or moments to shine. I have to admit, my favourites were Guzman, Hoffman and Molina. All three give stunning performances that are highly underrated roles, Molina for example, only appears for one scene, but the scene is magnificent and he is magnificent in it.The rise and fall style story structure seen in other legendary movies such as Barry Lyndon or GoodFellas is also seen here, but adapted to fit a different style of filmmaking. Anderson is more similar to Tarantino than he is to Scorsese or Kubrick in the way he directs his films- a very eccentric and humourous style.And this applies to fans of all three directors above- watch Boogie Nights. It is an immense film that does absolutely everything and more.
