reviews.review_title: Boogie Nights tackles a rather bizarre industry, that being pornography.
reviews.content: Can't say I've seen many theatrical released dramas about adult films, so this is new territory. Pornography is, obviously, very popular and this film showcases the rise of said industry in the 70's and its downhill in the 80's. It centres around the fictional Dirk Diggler (that name...it's just beautiful) and how he finds success through a adult film director named Jack Horner. Being in that type of business, Dirk starts becoming susceptible to the lavish lifestyle and the drugs and crime that follow. A fascinating albeit daring subject to tackle, director Paul Thomas Anderson manages to make it a rather compelling story. Slight tonal inconsistencies, particularly in the third act where it just loses steam but overall I found this to be thoroughly entertaining with dark comedic moments. It's another Anderson movie where his direction takes precedent. Super nice long takes that just lets the characters interact. Whether it be having sex, sniffing cocaine or running away from a shotgun wielding psychopath, the characters resembled the 70's. The disco attire looked fantastically authentic and really made me want to get down and boogie in my lounge (was so tempted...). Acting was outstanding all round. Julianne Moore and Burt Reynolds deserved their award nominations. Mark Wahlberg pulled off that sparky confident teenager role well. When it came to filming the pornography, the acting was incredibly cheesy which was sooo good to see. They honestly nailed it. Then seeing how porn progressed to amateur and drive-by within the 80's was interesting. I'm not addicted to porn or anything, but it's a refreshing subject to watch instead of slavery, haunted houses or World War II. So yes, despite the inconsistent tones this was incredibly enjoyable with phenomenal direction.

reviews.review_title: A film of greatness in every way, that really gets down and boogies
reviews.content: Another of these really long films to come out in early 98, the never dull BN is a mesmerizing look into the porn industry, a few sex scenes involving a lot of skin, implied, not as raunchy as a lot of people will expect. Mark Wahlberg, still in one of his best roles, plays the troubled street kid, who earns the name Dirk Diggler, with his discovered talent who's approached by Reynolds, a big time porn director, in one of his best ever acting parts. The two form a friendship, where Dirk becomes a friend among many other crew and cast, and becomes the next big thing. The period of late 70's to the breaking of the eighties is well captured and unhurried. Everyone is great where Wahlberg, competes well against some real acting heavy weights, (you'll know who I mean). Exceptionally good, was Julianne Moore, fantastic as a B porn actress fighting a lot of demons, only finding solace and happiness in what she's doing, while really she's floundering in despair, as fighting boldly to gain custody of her son. This film shows you what happens to retired porn stars, when seeking a new career or dream. One such instance threw me into a shockingly momentary disillusion. But this film is very inspirational, and how it tells you to "Never give up on your dream", especially in Dirk Diggler's case. There is a couple of coincidences in this film I didn't buy, and a little of repetition, hampering the great film, but the hampering really just becomes void, as we we don't have to forgive it, the films so good. One example involves a washed up Dirk Diggler getting pummelled by some gay hating punks, in a car park, while just after a limo just so happens to roll past with Burt and hot Heather Graham ( Rollergirl who never takes her skates off- EVER- I like that) getting it on with a high school jock who use to diss her. Shortly after, she in a much deserved revenge, as well as one I lapped up (You go girl) starts mashing the guy's face with her skates, after an offended Burt that is, tackles and punches him. There is some explosive violence, including one shock suicide scene, that's Wild Bill's doing, but like the sex, it's in the small number. My favorite scene is the one near the end, in an edgy, drug/money exchanged with a coked up Alfred Molina, as an young Asian kid, intermittently letting off firecrackers to intensify the nervousness, enwrapping Dirk Diggler and co (mo wearing Thomas Jane, you'll hardly recognize here, in still what I consider his best acting. BN is one hell of a movie ride and one of the best films of 1998. I have so much good stuff to write on this, but this is such a small offering. If you forgive the faults I mentioned, just sit back and watch what is a rewarding and insightful look into a industry was shunned, but it's how we see these shunned people lived, partied and boogied. The stick out hampering part is the ridiculous elongated penis, Marky Mark reveals at the end. Not only is it patently fake, it could do the Markster some mischief if tripping over it.

Mark Wahlberg, Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, William H. Macy and John C. Reilly star in this 1997 drama. This takes place from the late 70's to early 80's centering on young man, Eddie (Wahlberg) who rises to fame as a porn star, Dirk Diggler, but falls into the dark world of greed and drugs along with his friends & colleagues. Reynolds (Smokey & The Bandit) plays director, Jack, Moore (Hannibal) plays porn actress, Amber, Graham (License to Drive) plays waitress turned porn actress, Rollergirl, Macy (Fargo) plays Jack's assistant/producer, Bill and Reilly (Step-Brothers)
plays Dirk's pal & co-star, Reed. Don Cheadle (Out of Sight), Phillip Seymour Hoffman (Capote) and porn legends, Nina Hartley and Veronica Hart
also appear. This is a good drama and Wahlberg (Ted) & the cast are great in it. I recommend this.

I never saw this when it came out, so I didn't drink the P.T. Anderson Kool-aid. I haven't liked his other movies so there was no rush to rent this. Hard 8 while being miserable, bleak, and nothing I ever want to sit through again, was at least competent movie-making. This is Anderson's first big success and he's already gone Hollywood. It's an empty viewing experience. I'm not a prude by any standard, but is there any other place Hollywood movies about drugs, sex and porn go other than descent and misery? Gee, with such ignorant characters, I thought things would always be swell. The idea that somehow plots made porn more valuable before the industry moved to videotape is utterly ridiculous. Plot has always been in the way in porn movies. This didn't need to be 3 hours. It puts no ideas into play that do not issue directly from the mouths of one character or another. Long before Magnolia's contrived epiphany sequence Anderson was so uninterested in decent storytelling that he did it here too. All three characters have epiphanies compressed into a single day. I guess that was simpler for him to grasp. But hey, the "long movie must be respectable" gimmick worked and this garnered a bounty of nominations. So he's done it twice since.

"Boogie Nights" is an exhilarating, intriguing, well written and beautifully acted piece of cinema.  It gets my vote for the best movie of '97 (right behind "Afterglow").  Mr. Anderson is obviously the best new director/writer to emerge in recent years, and I am very anxious to see his upcoming films. This film was robbed of Oscars for its acting, writing and directing but it just goes to show how political and narrow-minded the Oscars and its voters are.  The best performance of the film was Julianne Moore's Amber Waves (at least she was nominated).  Her performance was funny, touching and particularly heart-wrenching at moments.  I can't believe Kim Basinger got the Oscar, when her performance showed no range or versatility. But anyway, don't listen to the Academy.  Listen to the critics.  Please see this wonderful film.

Young Eddie Adams, played by then relatively unknown Mark Wahlberg, is a dishwasher and a all-around dropout, who gets noticed by movie director and invited to shoot films with him. The movies just happen to be of the pornographic nature, which doesn't seem to faze Eddie all that much. He promptly changes his name to Dirk Diggler and the film follows his and his associates' career through the late 70s and early 80s. All the way from the golden age of porn right to the onset of video tape.For a film unabashedly about adult entertainment, the film is surprisingly non-raunchy in nature. Sure it's rated R, but there are very few sex scenes and it's more about the things that happen between the shoots. About the business itself and the kind of people it takes to undress in front of the cameras and do the naughty, as it were. It also has a great style and a lot of talent behind the camera. The soundtrack is well-crafted and contains a pleasingly huge amount of hits from those two decades. The costuming, the camera-work and the colours all harken right back to the 70s and it is one of the better period pieces about the decade I've yet seen.The acting is also superb. This is one of Wahlberg's earliest films and definitely one of the ones that put him on the map as someone with great acting chops. But the real star of the show has to be Burt Reynolds as the director Jack Horner, a man anguishing with the changes in his chosen medium, struggling to have his films seen as something worthwhile, perhaps even art.I'm sure this film has its critics solely because of its subject matter. But if you can get beyond that or if it doesn't bother you in the first place, Boogie Nights is a great film. Superbly crafted, well-acted and with a style of its own.

reviews.review_title: An amazing epic of a most unlikely group of individuals...
reviews.content: P.T. Anderson has created an incredible film about the rise and fall of an extended family of porn stars, and the individuals who supported them financially, during the late 70s-early 80s. During this time period, adult film-maker Jack Horner (played by Burt Reynolds in a Golden Globe winning performance) had a vision that his films could go "legitimate" in the mainstream film industry-- that is, be seen as more than pornography but as actual works of art. Many critics dismissed this film as pornography masquerading as bona fide movie-making.  Those who sat through the film, however, met a fascinating, albeit naive, group of characters. In a heart-breaking (and Oscar-nominated) performance, we meet Julianne Moore's beautiful "Amber Waves", an actress who seemingly has everything she desires but aches for the love of the son she has lost because of her chosen career path.  Amber readily channels this displaced love on her self-made family of actors, including Mark Wahlberg's "Dirk Diggler" and Heather Graham's "Rollergirl", who go through the motions of sex on screen but have no understanding of true love or intimacy due to prior rejection of family and/or society in general.Other note-worthy performances include Philip Seymour Hoffman's "Scotty", who spends the film smitten with and completely devoted to Dirk in a love that is painfully unrequited.  Also interesting are Don Cheadle's "Buck", the actor with loftier ambitions of owning a stereo store, and William H. Macy's "Little Bill", who is continually cuckolded by a wife who enjoys putting on sex shows with any willing man in public. This drama is played out with a wonderful soundtrack that revisits the glory days of disco and the "one-hit wonder" gems that peppered the early 80s. This was certainly one of the best films of 1997.

What was the point of this movie, other than for a young director to flex his Scorsese-muscle and practically remake Goodfellas.  What is the point of directing a coke-binge as a comic scene?  I've never tried cocaine, but it sure looks like fun when Heather Graham and Julianne Moore do it.  But what do we take away from this?  That porn is good?  Bad?  It is just what it is? That underaged boys in search of family should seek out porn?  That they shouldn't?  The only thing this film proved for sure is that Don Cheadle acts circles around anyone he is in any movie with.

Gripping, well-made, funny and insightful look at the evolution of the pornographic film industry beginning in late 1970s San Fernando Valley and centering around an ignorant but supremely "talented" teenager, who meets and connects with a prominent director (Reynolds) who turns him into an overnight sensation. The film's wild, steamy, and lurid content is at times unpleasant, but credible characters and situations, intriguing plot twists, and an array of strong performances make this a memorable, in-depth, and all-too-believable look at life among pornographers. Gets excessively dark in the latter half, but holds you with its hip and colorful look at the past decades. ***

** Thematic Spoilers **Since the debut of Boogie Nights, critics have observed P.T. Anderson's movies become more abstract and metaphorical.  Some would say that Boogie Nights is his only fully intact movie, in that it's main purpose isn't to reveal some other hidden meaning.In contrast, many casual viewers thought Boogie Nights was simply the story of a porn star. None of these people paid attention to the plot of the movie, and to whom the director is at the same time.  P.T. Anderson certainly didn't attain his joy for hidden meanings all of a sudden.  As anyone who has followed his career knows, it's in everything he makes. It's the kind of filmmaker he is.In short, just as several great movies before it, Boogie Nights is the story of America in the 70's through the 80's.  The climate in the movie follows that of the nation to a T.  The soft, fun and enjoyable 70's make way to the drugged, over-indulgent 80's with the striking image of, well, how's a double murder by and suicide of a jealous husband?Another P.T. Anderson trait, being coincidence of events, is overwhelmingly present in the movie.  A prime example being the night of 2 beatings and a very strange robbery, as well as the colonel's house being a magnet for Corvette's.Off the topic of the script itself, the acting is superb.  Rarely do you see so much acting talent in a movie.  The atmosphere of the movie fit the time it is set in perfectly.  The music fits well, and isn't over used (a trend that many 70's-80's movies were unable to resist).  It's very hard to find significant faults in the movie.I give it 4 stars (out of 4). The movie is extremely enjoyable. It's clever without being overbearing, it has all of the major cinematic elements, it succeeds in dissecting a delicate subject matter (pornography) without being overly vulgar, and the quality is exceptional.  To top it off, this is of a relatively amateur writer & director.See it.

Boogie Nights is the most complete and satisfying movie I've ever watched. It doesn't leave you wanting more, and overall the plot is flawless. The acting is impeccable, especially from Mark Wahlberg. Even though the topic is very X rated, they somehow managed to maintain innocence and sweetness throughout the movie. It's very touching, and an important movie to see. Highly recommend!

What did the 70's look like? Grime and brown looking at documentaries etc. But there was a sleazy glamour about the time which the 1980's clean look didn't have. Boogie Nights captures the feel for the era remarkably well its this which makes the film so good. Set in the 1970s porn industry at a time when employment rights in porn were are distant as any sense of rights in the decade of Watergate.Burt Reynolds as Director Jack Horner shows all the sleaziness and exploitation. Excellent casting as Reynolds fame as a hunk with a sense of danger in all the 70's macho action movies which had little sense of moral direction.The story of the film of a 1970's period piece has been revived by the like of Quentin Tarrantino in the form of homages and have failed because of their insistence on referencing the 1970's instead of the atmosphere. Boogie Nights instead uses full characterisation of the roles: Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Heather Grahame all that is essential to make a film good instead of just successful.A great film on a tacky subject from a gloriously tacky era.

A shocking, but honest film about the porn industry in the 1970's and the price people had to pay for drugs, stardom, infidelity. Wahlberg makes a new name for himself as a John Holmesian clone who becomes the biggest star in the history of adult films because of his "very effective machinery." Burt Reynolds gives the finest performance of his career as the director, mentor and father figure of the young star. He shows us a character. Not a parody or a joker. He's a true character. He steals the film! Julianne Moore and Heather Graham also star.

Boogie Nights was not Paul Thomas Anderon's first film--that was 1996's Hard Eight-- but it was the first one he had full artistic control over and the result is a real tour de force. Except for Citizen Kane I have probably never seen a movie so enthusiastically cinematic. He is not afraid to use split screens and other unfashionable film techniques, and because he is not afraid to use them they work. This is one of the most confident films I've ever seen. Anderson's camera moves through the scenes like a kid in a candy store, floating about gayly eying everything around it but never coming to a full stop because there is so much other stuff to see. And there is certainly a lot to see. Boogie Nights is a huge ensemble, but Anderson never really gets lost in the scope (there is admittedly one storyline that doesn't really go anywhere, but it serves to advance the other threads so it's fine). Take the opening scene of the movie. Faced with the problem of introducing such a huge cast, Anderson decides to "dive right in" and brings us to a nightclub where the entire cast is partying. We don't exactly meet anybody during this scene, as the camera just floats from booths to the dancefloor to the kitchen and back around, and we overhear out-of-context blurts from the characters as we pass them much as we would were we walking through the club ourselves. However, the blurts are revealing--Luis Guzman wants Burt Reynolds to put him in a film someday. Don Cheadle's fashion sense is questionable. Julianne Moore is like a mother to Heather Graham. William Macy is more concerned with business details than the carefree Reynolds. By the end of the scene we feel like we have a pretty reasonable grasp on the scene these people run in.This speaks to Anderson's other great strength as a filmmaker--his writing. People often talk about his camera and how it relates him to his idols like Scorsese and Ophüls, but rarely mentioned is his ability to create wonderful characters. Boogie Nights, like another great ensemble, Robert Altman's Nashville, is a movie that really feels lived-in. We do not for a second doubt that these are real people, and they occupy our imagination long after the runtime is up. The movie is bursting at the seams with life. Anderson is anything but a lazy filmmaker. He loads the characters with traits that might not seem "essential" to a lesser writer, but end up giving the characters the necessary human qualities to make the story really touching. Would Boogie Nights be as moving if Mark Wahlberg wasn't obsessed with karate, and didn't pump himself up by doing punching exercises in front of the mirror before porn shoots? Or if John C Reilly and Don Cheadle didn't have ambitions of becoming a magician and a stereo equipment salesman, respectively? I think not. Boogie Nights is a classic film in the same sense as The Godfather--the filmmaker takes us into a world unknown to most of us, one many of us might think unsavory, and creates a truly moving piece of human drama. And like Nashville, it being so full of life makes it truly life-affirming. Boogie Nights is one of the few movies that not only makes me feel like I've learned more about human beings, but also makes me truly happy to be one.

reviews.review_title: Requires multiple viewings to really get what this is about.
reviews.content: When I initially saw this movie in theaters I liked it a lot but really didn't appreciate the complexity of the film until many years later after seeing it a few more times on cable. After that it became clear that while this movie seems to be about the porn industry in the 70's and thru the 80's what its really about is lies. Lies we tell ourselves. Almost every character in the movie is under some self delusion and can't see themselves as they really are. Jack Horner tells himself he's a "film maker" and protests when he has to switch to using video tape, but quickly compromises failing to see that all he really is is a pornographer. Look at the line "Ever hear of that movie Star Wars? People tell me I look just like Han Solo" uttered by the highly under rated John C. Reilly (who looks nothing like Harrison Ford obviously). This hidden theme runs throughout the movie in all the characters. There are several great moments if you look for them. Buck, an African-American redneck/cowboy, the most redeeming character, lies to himself throughout the movie, hoping to be accepted for who he is without being judged for going against stereotype and being in porn (he's constantly stating "I'm an actor") is forced to compromise in the end to open up his stereo store with the hip-hop style commercial. What is great (and sad) about this movie is that no one really evolves. There is no character arc. Dirk comes back when he hits bottom but not out of any self realization. In the end, they are still self deluded. Hence the reason, in the final scene where Dirk is rehearsing his lines and stands up and unzips showing his rubber phallus repeating his mantra "I am a star, a star, a bright bright shining star" the camera doesn't pan up showing Dirks face and we hear the lines while looking at this 13" fake phallus. Dirk isn't the star and never was and never will be.

This is one of the best movies ever for many reasons.  Anderson is one of the most talented new directors in Hollywood and has an amazing cast that play off each other very well.  Every actor was cast perfectly for each role and all deliver great performances.  This movie's setting is the 70's pornography industry, so many people expect the movie to be close to soft porn.  Nothing could be further from the truth; there is very little nudity considering the setting. The movie is not about the pron industry, but instead on the lives of a few main characters, who happen to work in this business. This is one of my favorite movies ever and anyone who enjoys movies set in the 70's and 80's should see it.  I hope Anderson can keep delivering films like this and Magnolia.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant! Nothing short of a firework! **minor spoilers**
reviews.content: The cast is great, Anderson's direction is beautifully visual and character based. Boogie Nights has a real feel quality. That said, I think Alfred Molina almost steals the show. The fire cracker scene is brilliant. The guys have come to sell bad drugs and are already nervous and what is there waiting for them..? A rich yuppie on dope, bodyguard the size of Grand Canyon and a little asian fella throwing fire crackers all over the place. Humor at it's best. Boogie Nights is warm, but funny. On the edge, but still respectful. A masterpiece!***** / *****

Writer/Director Paul Thomas Anderson probes the adult film industry of the 1970s in this classy, but imperfect, fictional story that spans the disco years, beginning in 1977, when porn movies were actually shown in movie houses. Set in the San Fernando Valley of Southern California, the basic plot pivots around Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds), king of adult film-making, who eyes a nightclub busboy named Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg). Soon, Eddie morphs into "Dirk Diggler", hot-to-trot porn star whose got the goods.But the sprawling plot encompasses a vast array of colorful characters that orbit Horner and Diggler. And therein lies one of the film's problems. The plot is overdone. It's too epical. A lot of fat could have been trimmed from the 180 pages of script and the roughly eighty speaking parts. As is, the film exudes a sense of grandiose self-indulgence.Even so, the film clearly paints porn as a for-profit business, a rather grubby, cold-blooded one at that. Horner's detached perspective insures his product's financial success, if not his workers' emotional needs. Splashy disco music enlivens the entire production, though I could have wished for a better selection of 70s music.Casting is fine, except for Wahlberg. I've seen more convincing looking porn stars-to-be sacking groceries at the local Piggly-Wiggly. Burt Reynolds makes an ideal sleaze seller. And sweet Julianne Moore convinces as a 1970s liberated woman.As much a celebration of 1970s disco culture as a primer on cinematic erotica, "Boogie Nights" oozes all the glitter of that era, with colorful costumes and funky production design. As such, it reminds me of "54" (1998), a film that is to New York City what "Boogie Nights" is to Southern California.Energetic, expansive, and chaotic in tone and plot, "Boogie Nights" thematically cautions that 1970s porn "stars", though superficially attractive, took too seriously their star status, myopic to the reality that times change, and that youth is fleeting.

reviews.review_title: Simply put, one of the best films of the 1990's
reviews.content: "Boogie Nights" follows the lives of "film maker" Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) and his stable of porn stars over a six year period from 1977-1983. The story starts when Jack introduces himself to 17 year old high school drop-out Eddie Adams in San Fernando Valley nightclub after hearing rumors that Eddie is 14" long in the "Mr. Torpedo" area.At the same time we are introduced Rollergirl (Heather Graham), a high schooler already making a career as a porn star & Amber Waves (Julianne Moore), a 30 something cocaine addict who lost visitation rights to her young son because of her chosen career. Over the course of the next few days Eddie moves out of home after a fight with his mother and into Jack's house. Where we are introduced via a party to the rest of the characters including Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly) The Current king of Jack's stable, Buck (Don Cheadle), is the only character in the film who sees a life for himself outside of porn, Scotty J. (Phillip Seymour Hoffman) a young, overweight, gay man and Little Bill (William H. Macy) whose wife seems to be screwing anybody who isn't him.Before long Eddie has become Dirk Diggler, the biggest thing to have ever hit the porn industry, not suprisingly he quickly starts to falling into the trappings of his own success, introduced, via Amber to cocaine and becoming too big for his own boots, he falls, hard. The people around Eddie are falling too but they always stick by one another. All the performances in this film are stellar but it is Moore's Amber Waves and Cheadle's Buck that standout as truly stunning, P.T Anderson has written a brilliant screenplay complemented by his great direction. This movie has a invloving story that leaves you wanting more.

This is about a young man who is determined to make something of himself and become a star. Other people tell him he has "something special" and so does Jack Horner, a pornographic filmmaker who wants to make actual quality movies with the pornography still in it. This movie shows what the business was like in the 70s and it shows a star go through his rise to fame to his downfall in the 80s. Every one gives a great performance including a early role for Marky Mark himself. The writing is also a great thing in this movie with a little bit of comedy sprinkled in. Every character is interesting from Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, and Don Cheadle. If your a P.T. Anderson fan then I don't see why someone would dislike this, he carry's over a handful of the cast that was in Hard Eight and uses a lot from this film to Magnolia and so on. Every aspect about this movie I think is great from it really feeling like the 70s time period from the costume and set design to the really good soundtrack that sounds like one Tarantino would put together. Highly recommend and Don't get scared by the running time, it flys by for me at least

reviews.review_title: VIEWS ON FILM review of Boogie Nights
reviews.content: Boogie Nights remains to this day, my favorite film of all time. It's a firecracker of a movie and a kaleidoscope of colorful, 70's pop culture. Paul Thomas Anderson pays homage to a host of brilliant directors like Martin Scorsese, Stanley Kubrick, Robert Altman, and Quentin Tarantino to guide his camera and volt forward, his supreme storytelling style. With a plot that involves the trials and tribulations of everyone involved in the adult film world, Boogie Nights has a cast here that is full of interesting, quirky characters, it has a couple of enthralling (not to mention elaborate) steadicam shots, and it possesses a soundtrack that tracks gleefully, the rhythms of all the fabulous, energized jump cuts. Mark Wahlberg as the lead and well hung male adult actor (Dirk Diggler), gives a startling, breakthrough performance. But it's Burt Reynolds who bests him as his go-to porn director. Burt's star never shined so bright as it did here (and this is over a 50 plus year career). Look for a drug deal scene gone amuck, a donut shop scene posing as a Mexican standoff, and a disco dance sequence that gives you your Saturday Night Fever fix.Overall, this is what invigorating, epic, staunch film making is all about. A giddy masterpiece!

A first film in Paul Thomas Anderson's California Suite (all taking place in California). It shows that the director has studied Scorsese carefully: long tracking shots, period disco music, but the characters seem to come with the laid-back California lifestyle. More than that if conveys the mentality of the era.What could be more interesting than a film about the porn industry; but it's really about the film industry, with it's star behavior, drugs, bored, behind the camera people going through the motions and its share of misfits hoping for a bit of glamour. Its a comedy until toward the end it isn't, and the butchers bill comes for people who play meat on camera.The film skillfully evokes an era and a time (starting with the mid-seventies) when making porn was almost a family affair, and those who came to Hollywood seeking their fortunes find that paying the bills leads them to the productions of Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds in his best role) a pornographer. It'd a transitional period in which the standard sex scene are still played, not the hard core stuff that goes nowadays.One of the best scenes shows Jack Horner's girlfriend, a porn performer, gets it on with a boy she really wants to make love to, and does it on camera right before Horner, who thinks it's a wonderful 'performance'.Boogie Nights also interweaves the lives of dozens of characters, who try to communicate things they can't articulate, so that even the most obvious double-entendre is taken seriously. They're way over their heads, playing with fire, and don't know it.Unless your older, you won't remember eight-track tape, HI-FI systems, bell bottoms, disco, Corvettes as status symbols, coke on everyone's coffee tables, or a dozen other period artifacts.I think the film is great if you've not seen it before. I tried watching it a second time and fount it a bit confining, as almost all the action takes place at Jack Horner's home or a disco named 'Boogie Nights'. The few scenes that don't seem shoehorned in, and don't work.If the acting seems bad, remember that the film wants the characters to be stupid... like the characters in a porn movie. The length of the film (you won't be bored) promises larger ideas than the film finally delivers, and that is that. No big message, and maybe that's a good thing.I recommend it highly if you haven't seen it. Just remember this is deeply ironic and humorous film - don't take anything seriously and you'll have a good time.
It was about time to watch this movie. Second favorite of PTA after Magnolia. RIP Burt Reynolds- great acting and always funny,you will be missed.Great movie and performances.

This movie is memorable thanks to terrific performances, soundtrack and most of all atmosphere.  You can almost smell the cheap cologne Dirk would wear to go disco dancing.  The firecracker scene topped it all off.  Add the wonderful Julianne Moore, and it doesn't get any better than this.

reviews.review_title: Paul Thomas Anderson Struts His Stuff
reviews.content: Paul Thomas Anderson is amazing when it comes to bringing to life believable characters (I'd argue my three of his films are essentially character studies- "There Will Be Blood", "The Master", and "Phantom Thread"). He knows how to take a character and flesh them out so that they all seem to have urges, dreams, cares, and fears about the world that Anderson places them in, and in giving these characters more depth, the world feels far more tactile. The character relationships shift and change as things happen throughout the movie. Almost every character in this movie is dynamic- when we're introduced to them in the beginning, they're one way, and by the time we leave them, they're different. What's so impressive about this film is the way that Anderson works in all of the different character arcs without making the story feel overly complex, complicated, or an hour too long (there are some scenes in this movie that probably could've been trimmed, but for a two and a half hour film, it seems to move quickly). While the main story revolves around Eddie/Dirk's rise to fame, this movie is essentially an ensemble piece- we spend time getting to know each and every character in their own separate scenes, fleshing out the members of the adoptive family that Dirk joins. I do want to mention, that while I think this script is great, I'd say that Anderson's later scripts show a lot more complexity and depth.

reviews.review_title: Ninety minutes of fun material in a clunky two and a half hour movie
reviews.content: It is amazing how a movie can fall apart just as quickly as it comes together. For a while, Paul Thomas Andersson's Boogie Night's recalls Goodfellas; a subjective story about a nobody who becomes a big somebody. Unfortunately Andersson is not content with the movie being that simple. He wants to make it bigger and bolder, and about halfway in, it turns into an ensemble feature. The whole thing doesn't come together very well. The plot grows increasingly stagy, and the characters are given no room to grow. Where as Goodfellas grew tighter and more intense with each chapter, Boogie Nights grows tiresome. Its self-indulgence is frustrating because for a while I was really enjoying myself. But just when things are looking good, Boogie Nights ceases to commit to the direction it started with, so why should we stay committed?.

All most all the characters in `Boogie Nights' that are not involved in the porn industry call the industry just that (`porn', `porn star', etc.), while almost all the characters within the industry call their art film and themselves actors.  As accurately depicted in `Boogie Nights', this highlights one of the key reasons why a transaction from theater porn to video porn occurred in the late 70's and early 80's.  Unlike what the delusional directors of the time (Jack) believed, people pretty much only went to porno movies in theaters to do their business and then get out. The plot, though, never takes us to the theaters.  Rather, it follows the bigger-then-life lifestyle of porn industry insiders in the 70's through their tremendous fall from grace in the early and mid 80's, and finally into there initiation into normal society in the (presumably) late 80's and early 90's.  This gives `Boogie Nights' an epic quality; a peculiar occurrence considering it follows an `unclean' business.  Although an epic quality exists, no one scene is particularly breath taking (as compared to classical epics), but in reverse fashion, actually very bland.This leads to another key quality of PT Anderson's film, in that he takes sex, and depicts the mundane quality it has within the porn industry. Some of the sex scenes with Rollergirl seem to be so spontaneous and casual that it seems as if the porn films are just an extension of real life.  Of course when an outside influence (video) topples this `great society' everyone falls off the deep end.  This fall primarily takes the form of Cocaine (Dirk, Rollergirl, Amber, Reed, et al.), though, alternatively, Little Bill kills himself, and Jack just accepts the change despite the fact that he is obviously not as happy.  During the years between 1980 and 1984, the only characters who seems to gain or even maintain happiness are Buck and Jessie St. Vincent.  The fall culminates with the scene at Rahad Jackson's house. At the end, though, almost everyone is redeemed (i.e. Rollergirl gets her degree, Amber becomes a legitimate director, Reed goes on a magic card circuit, Buck opens his own sound performance store, there are parties once again at Jack's house, Maurice opens his own night club, and of course Eddie becomes a legitimate actor.).  The phoenix-like end crescendo's with the Eddies final monologue where he states, `I am a star. I'm a star, I'm a star, I'm a star. I am a big, bright, shining star.'The budget for this film was perfect.  If Anderson were given any more money, the studios would have been all over him demanding a `safer' film to protect their investment.  Although the film probably could have been done for less, it would have been impossible to do it for much less considering the elaborate set design and the (quasi) star studded cast (i.e. no Brad Pitts but plenty of high paid actors).   As it is, this movie was probably done on about the perfect budget.The film also hit the mark when it comes to the actual final product. Anderson stated on the DVD that he would have liked to expand the mother-son scenes a little further, which I agree would have been productive.  I would have also expanded Dirks fall from grace. In my version Dirk would be depicted as an isolated (not even Scotty J or Reed are there anymore) homeless, starving bum on a decrepit Hollywood Ave. (irony?), for 1 or 2 scenes before he finally get around to contacting Jack again.  With the movie already being 2 hours and 40 minuts, these additional scenes might begin to make the movie a little excessive. It is of my opinion that although a few scenes could have been added, there are really no scenes that could have been subtracted.  The film follows a number of different story lines, meaning that if one story line is deleted it won't ruin plot of the film.  This being said, I feel that all the story lines help add to the `feel' of the film and if any were deleted, the quality of the film would be lessened.All in all `Boogie Nights' is a great, epic film, which would be hard to re-edit for the purpose of improved changes.

The premise of the movie is not your conventional storyline filled with action,suspense and romance.The movie is one of it's kind and fast paced movie lovers may not like it but for the patient viewer it is quite a treat.Well this is one movie which you cannot see with your family and you don't have to as the movie is best appreciated by a single viewer.Mark Wahlberg plays the legendary porn star and is quite comfortable in the role and acts like a natural.Though the length of the movie may be debatable but it keeps you glued for the entire duration. You see the exploits of a down and out teenager has he struggles his way through his life and gets a opportunity to make it big as a porn star which he accepts without hesitation.From there the diggler mania catches on and the artistic treatment of the story makes it watchable.The supporting cast is pretty good and so is the use of the 1980's style camera-work.But the soul of the movie lies with dirk and his journey to which the director gives full support and his vision.It might be termed as a off track but watch it and be prepared to be a fan of Mark Wahlberg. And yes do watch it alone or you might get bored in company

Ahh the 1970's a time of jaded innocence. This is the era in which the movie 'Boogie Nights'is set in. A time when cocaine wasn't thought of as addictive, sex would not kill you, and god forbid disco was king. A story of a rise and fall and rise in the span of six year's (77 to 83) of a none to bright SoCal youth brought to prominence, discovered by chance and championed by a wily mentor played by Burt Reynold's in an Oscar nominated role. (lost out to Robin William's for Good Will Hunting) not to mention a prodigious member and an insurable sexual prolactivity makes this the best movie of the nineties. Told in an over the shoulder you are there film style and buoy'd by numerous top forty chart topper's of the 70's and 80's director and writer Paul Thomas Anderson second feature is a tour de force of nihilistic hedonism at it's wretched best. Brutal and thoughtful this is a film that through it's very arch the character's become the epitome of which they disdain be it the Reynold's characters resolution of resorting to the disavowed use of voyeur intrused videotape to the SoCal youth's (Mark Wahlberg) degradation of homo erotic act's for ten dollar's a pop the character's arc are on the same line yet still point's on the curve. This film is an echo of John Holme's rise and degradation in the same industry yet fictionalized and paralleled in spades.

This movie starts out with a feeling not unlike that of a pornographic film. It has a sort of anxious, low budget ambiance, exemplified through Paul Thomas Anderson's use of long camera shots. After Dirk leaves the porn industry in pursuit of a music career the film takes an amazing change in an almost Quentin Tarantinoish sort of way. People are being shot left and right, cocaine becomes a prominent crutch in the lives of the people involved in the film as they try to clean up and move on. Dirk's downfall almost reminds me of the film Citizen Kane where Kane's lust for power inevitably leads to his demise. I must say that this film left me amazed, and I believe it belongs on the top 250 of this website.

Set in the late 1970s and early 1980s, Boogie Nights is centred on Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg), a young man who is discovered by a porn director (Jack Horner, played by Burt Reynolds) and becomes a star in the adult film industry. The film follows the lives of Eddie (who soon adopts the screen name Dirk Diggler) and his fellow colleagues, as well as Jack's crew members.I had high expectations when I sat down to watch Boogie Nights, and I wasn't disappointed.Wahlberg delivers a stand-out performance as Dirk, whose most moving scenes see him slip into cocaine addiction, which gives him erection problems and causes him to lash out at his friends.Other memorable characters include Amber (Julianne Moore), whose involvement in the porn industry has cost her contact with her son, and Little Bill (William H. Macy), who is driven to commit murder-suicide as a result of his wife's serial (and extremely public) adultery.On a side note, the soundtrack is fantastic.

I saw Boogie Nights on IFC a few nights ago.I must say, this film is great.From the excellent acting, the characters to the soundtrack & plot, this is a great film.It has an all star cast featuring Mark Wahlberg, William H Macy, John C Reilly, Julianne Moore, Burt Reynolds, Luis Guzman and a few others.It's pretty graphic in terms of sex/nudity(it's about the porn industry).Also has quite a bit of drug use and some strong violence, but if you can look past that, you will see a brilliant film.It starts off in 1977, Mark Wahlberg is a dishwasher looking to earn a few extra bucks.A porn director then takes him under his wing and introduces him to the world of being a porn star.It starts off all glamorous and whatnot, however later on the consequences show up, just like in movies such as "Scarface", we see the consequences of the seemingly great lifestyle.The film spans from 1977-1984 and has an excellent soundtrack and some very good scenes! Boogie Nights is just a great movie! I recommend you watch it.

reviews.review_title: A smart, provocative piece of work by Paul Thomas Anderson
reviews.content: Paul Thomas Anderson isn't just any Hollywood director, he's a filmmaker with a provocative sense of style and writing, and this comedy-drama period piece effectively proves so. This film stars a brilliant ensemble cast in what may seem like a solid non- documentary examination of the pornographic industry during the 1970s but is actually an inside look at the characters' adventures through the controversial entertainment business. With the stylish script, direction, and realistic depiction of the social satire in the 70s by Anderson; this film comes be a sassy and powerfully clever picture. Set in San Fernando Valley, California in the late 70s, this film introduces Eddie Adams (played by Mark Wahlberg), a seventeen-year old high school dropout who spends his nights working as a bus boy at the Reseda Night Club. There he meets adult film director Jack Horner (played by Burt Reynolds) who sees talent in the young man. After a meeting with Horner, his star Amber Waves (played by Julianne Moore), and a young runaway named Brandy (played by Heather Graham) nicknamed "Rollergirl", Eddie is driven into the eccentric world of the porn industry where he meets actors Reed Rothchild (played by John C. Reilley), producer Little Bill (played by William H. Macy) who struggles with his wife's infidelity, and music executive Bucky Swope (played by Don Cheadle). Adopting his stage name Dirk Diggler, Eddie ventures through the highs and unexpected lows of the Californian porn industry.From the exhilarating screenplay by Paul Thomas Anderson, the sassy disco soundtrack and costume design to represent the 70s (and 80s) settings, and the ambitious performances by the cast; it is easy to consider this Anderson's career-defining entry. Venturing through the lives of the characters and their ups and downs in the adult film business including infidelity and troubled fame, this film delivers plenty of surprises and wit from the hands of director Anderson, and the story falls nothing short of engaging and sweet, though it feels somewhat uneven in the second half. Of course, as pornography serves as the central point of the story, there is a heavy amount of sexual activity, raucous dialogue, nudity, and abundance of cocaine abused throughout, let's not forget the unexpected violence that breaks out between certain scenes; all of which can be significantly uncomfortable for sensitive movie-goers to sit through. But thanks to the stylish cinematography by Robert Elswit and the sharply written dialogue, it's all done in a way not meant to be gratuitous. When the story suspends from it's emotional heft, viewers are granted with some hilarious (and vulgar) dialogue, slick social commentary, and light- hearted gags, mostly from the mouths of Mark Wahlberg and Burt Reynolds, both of whom are deeply engaging in their roles; standing out from the overcrowd of underdeveloped characters. Though Paul Thomas Anderson may suffer a bad case of "ensemble cast syndrome" that results in some characters that fall shallow, his stylish quality in filmmaking and writing are effective enough to shade over these flaws.Boogie Nights is a smart, provocative piece of work that can be called one of the best films made by the hands of Paul Thomas Anderson. This film is full or surprises and intelligence that scale high above its vulgarity and rawness. Though this doesn't pack the same kind of popular status as other 90s film like Quentin Tarantino's 'Pulp Fiction' or James Cameron 'Titanic', it makes an important piece of modern cinema.

Quite possibly the best movie to come out of the later 90's, a period rife with some truly stunning cinema. I can't be effusive enough about how much this film impacted me. PTA has one of the most creative directorial minds ever. His vision, tone, shots, and cast choices are the creme of the crop. This movie is just so LUSH. Every frame is so sumptuous. And the transition from the rolling 70's to the stark 80's is beyond brilliant. Also some of the best performances of almost every actors' careers chocked into this masterpiece. It's hilarious, heartbreaking and just gets in your belly and makes you wanna freaky deaky.

I really didn't want to see this movie with my friend, but he made me watch it. I'm glad he did. This movie is great. It has everything that makes a movie great. Sex, drugs, action, and pornagraphy. It's about a guy named Eddie who is working at a night club in the kitchen. A local porn director finds him and is astonished with his special thing. I give it a 10/10. I AM A STAR.

Boogie Nights is one of my favorite films.  I bought the DVD more than 2 years ago and it's remained a treasured piece of filmmaking that I will never forget.  The writing is superb.  Original characters and situations that come from an original filmmaker.  The drug deal at the end is one of THE best scenes in cinema history.  Alfred Molina prancing around with a crack pipe, singing along to "Jesse's Girl", while his Chinese friend throws firecrackers around the room, causing Dirk, Todd and Reed to jump out of their seats is just a pure movie moment and is worth the price of the DVD alone.  It doesn't happen often, but when it does, the music, the images, the acting, the subject matter... it all blends into the perfect movie experience and Boogie Nights has all that in spades.

Man, "Boogie Nights" must be like "The Breakfast Club" of the 90\s. Take a bunch of actors on the cusp of stardom, and put them into a multlayered complex movie. This movie just happens to be about the Porn industry in the late 70's-early 1980's. When I first saw this when the film just came out, the only person I recognized in the cast was of course, Burt Reynolds and that rapper-turned-actor, Mark Wahlberg. Nowadays, I can recognize everyone and just be agog at how much pre-starpower there is: Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, John C, Mcginley, Don Cheadle, William Maxy, Phillip Seymour Hoffman etc etc, This film just gets better and better with each viewing, and the firecracker scene at the ending becomes more hilarious then nerve wracking ( not that it doesn't lose it's power - After maybe 3-4 viewings, I always forget the conclusion of this scene, which increases it's brilliance because it's the firecrackers you remember, and it keeps you wondering.. what happens after this?

This may not be Paul Thomas Anderson's debut, but it's the film that really announced him as one of the most compelling talents of the last 30 years. In a sense, this film tells the story of the late 70's becoming the early 80's, and uses the porn industry to do so. It's closest point of comparison is "Nashville". Both films use a web of vividly drawn characters in an unlikely industry to paint a portrait of where America was in a specific time and place.Where it really doesn't feel like "Nashville" is in it's determination to dazzle the viewer. Anderson really lets loose with some amazing things ... long unbroken takes, dropping from a 4-way split screen into a dance number, homages to "I Am Cuba" and "Raging Bull". It all works.It's also meticulously cast. Mark Wahlberg and Burt Reynolds turn in career best performances. A huge supporting cast of character actors are all perfectly cast. Alfred Molina almost steals the whole film. Robert Downey, Sr. Even pops up.All of this could feel like an exercise if it wasn't grounded in a subtle and warm portrayal of an extended family of sometimes deeply flawed people that draws you in and makes care about them. This would be a career peak for most directors, but it's really just Anderson's first volley.

A film that suffers from lack of plot and the nagging sense that it is not going anywhere, but excels as a character sketch of a group of struggling young people involved in the porn film industry in the 1980s who all suffer from that famous California malady, "Low self esteem".  The movie generates a surprising amount of sympathy and even a kind of grudging respect for (some of) them.  My favorite line occurs in a scene where Burt Reynolds, who has always worked with "professional" actors to shoot his porn flicks on celluloid, decides reluctantly to explore the possibilities of the new video medium and takes his leading actress, "Rollergirl" a blond who never takes off her skates even when she takes everything else off, out in a stretch limo to film her having sex with random volunteers picked up off the streets.  This goes badly wrong when they pick up a snotty college boy who recognizes her as a high school classmate and tries to have sex with her without any of the usual (even in porn films) conversational preliminaries, and without paying any attention to suggestions from Mr Reynolds about taking his time and enjoying himself a bit.  After a final indignant expostulation from Reynolds, "Hey, show a little respect, this is Rollergirl!" the college snot is unceremoniously dumped out of the car. 
Well worth your time.

This was my second PT Anderson movie after "There Will Be Blood" - I loved it! The movie really is talking about hope and finding dreams among broken people through the lens of the pornography industry.Like my previous PTA movie, "Boogie Nights" presents the audience with effective establishment of characters right from the get go. Mark Wahlberg definitely stood out for this film and maybe many will consider this his best (unfortunately) because before this movie, I saw him as sort of B-list action movie star. Other performances from casts like Reynolds, Moore, Cheadle and Reilly were all strong. The movie gets even better towards the end. The scenes where the characters are shown hitting their rock bottom in sequence was terrific. The drug selling scene also kept me on my toes. The firecracker plot was honestly genius.In technical aspects, I thought the music choice was superb and the whole movie did really feel like a great homage to the 70s and the early 80s. There weren't a lot of fancy "wow" shots but the overall cinematography was just as smooth as butter.I didn't find the movie very comedic but it felt really special because I had never seen anything like it. The characters are bunch of broken people but endearing in many aspects. So as they go through the vanity of it all, the ups and downs of the seemingly glamorous industry, the audience can't help but follow their journey with observant eyes. In unexplainable ways, the movie tucks on the audiences' heartstring in a mature way because everyone has failed and gotten better at some point in their lives. Come to think of it, maybe the pornography industry is the best to showcase the inner struggles that these characters go through in contrast to their external glory.Overall, a beautiful PTA movie yet again. Perhaps I might fanboy him.

reviews.review_title: An episode of the sex industry in the 70's
reviews.content:
Theme: The success and failure of porn star Dirk Diggler in the 70's and 80's.Why you should see it: If you wonder how your life could be if you used your talent for sex instead of developing others, this is the movie you should watch. (What's your talent? Good at math?) It is exciting to see how ,somewhere, there is a whole world of happiness and misery surrounding the making of porn movies. The 70's atmosphere is simply great! The parties, the music, the drugs, the clothes and the people, they're all there. A lot of scenes have outstanding acting performances(see below)and some are very sexy. Also you will find many interesting little characters surrounding the main players.Why not: The movie is pretty long and not all scenes are acted that well. The 70's theme you've probably already seen a lot of times. The characters in the movie are (on purpose) mostly pretty simple minded, so don't expect many interesting thoughts.
Actors/actresses: In most scenes Mark Wahlberg does an excellent job playing Dirk Diggler that pursues a career as porn star trying to find some affection that he didn't even get from his own mom. He desperately wants to be popular. When the story gets more dramatic he's at his best. Heather Graham has the easy part of just being a sexy Rollergirl, which isn't hard to screw up. It probably worked out well for her career, as a lot of sexy roles do for actresses. Burt Reynolds is wonderful in his character of the director of the movies and being the patron of the "porn-family". He looks like Sean Connery and secretly you would like to be in his little porn world for a couple of days too. Julianne Moore completes this world. She brilliant in the short scene about the custody of her child. And ,of course,very sexy as the woman de la famille and performing porn star. Notice Philipp Seymour Hoffman's role as the crew member who's secretly in love with Dirk Diggler.Other observations: The story of Boogie Nights is like that of Casino or Goodfellas, but then for the sex industry.Conclusion: As I said, the 70's setting and the many small scenes that characterize this period are simply great! With often wonderful acting. (8)

reviews.review_title: Ranks Among My All Time Favorites
reviews.content: P.T Anderson hit the Hollywood scene in 1997 with "Hard Eight" and "Boogie Nights". But it was "Boogie Nights" that launched his career into the mainstream, and earned him several Oscar nominations. But it was robbed, BIG TIME, for at least a nomination for best picture. "Boogie Nights" is hands down one of the best American movies in the last 25 years. P.T Anderson is an undeniable master of drama, and he (really) should stand among the ranks of Tarentino and Scorsese. The way he weaved this tumultuous narrative was groundbreaking for any filmmaker of the time. The story is essentially a young man finally finding the love and affection he always needed from a new family. The only problem is, this family is in the smut business. It's a story as provocative as the centerfold of a Hustler magazine, but as thought provoking as "Citizen Kane". The performances are some of the best I've ever seen. Mark Wahlberg's screen debut as Dirk Diggler is arguably his best performance to date. Burt Reynolds is captivating as Jack Horner, the pornographer who dreams of making Oscar gold. Julianne Moore deserved her Oscar for her performance of Amber Waves, a former mother who finds her sense of family with the people she sleeps with, and not with the children she birthed. Also, you've got Heather Graham as Rollergirl, Don Cheadle, the always funny John C. Reilly, the even funnier Phillip Seymour Hoffman. Then, you have William H. Macy as Little Bill, or what can only be described as the ultimate cuckold. His shattering performance ranks with Steve Buscemi's Donny from "The Big Lebowski" as one of the funniest characters in all of film. Who else could forget the scene at the drug dealers house with the firecrackers and the.? OK for those of you who haven't seen the movie yet, I might be getting ahead of myself. I just get so excited talking about this film! Its scenes like that that make the entire film an unforgettable experience. This film clocks in at 155 minutes which is precisely one minute longer than Pulp Fiction, but like Pulp Fiction, every minute is enthralling. Its the greatest 2 and 1/2 hours you could possibly spend on Netflix. My love for this movie grows every time I think about it, and I want to share that love with all of you. Enjoy!
Based on an adult short documentary!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I put off watching this film for a while, and I'm not sure why. The film explores the golden age of pornography which went from the late 70's and into the 80's. The first half of the film is nice, vibrant, sexual, and just a great time. Paul Thomas Anderson has a bunch of actors that he uses in most of his work, and its a great bunch that don't fail. What starts off as a fun look at the porn industry, then turns into a dramatic and emotional tale that takes a look into the negatives of the industry. Won't give anything away, but you can see PTA's brilliance especially as the film winds down. Overall, its a very good film that is very much worth a look.8/10

Boogie Nights is an uncritical look behind the scenes of the porn industry as it moved from theatrical films to home video.  Burt Reynolds is outstanding as Jack Horner, film-maker and leader of an extended family of porn stars, technicians and gofers.  Julianne Moore stars as the porn veteran cum mother-figure to Dirk Diggler, teen-age discovery of Jack's whose god-given endowment leads him quickly to the top of the porn industry.Aided by an excellent ensemble cast, the film follows the entertwined lives of this little band over a seven year period, 1977 - 1984.  Some people make it, some are shattered, but Paul Thomas Anderson, director and writer, isn't judgemental one way or the other.  Movie-goers are just along for the ride, so get on board, this movie is a real treat.  Rent it at your neighborhood video store.

reviews.review_title: This life isn't all strawberries and champagne, in fact, at times it really sucks!
reviews.content: Thought provoking docu-drama, this could have been a really cheap sexploitation movie, but it just manages to avoid falling into that trap; emerging instead as quite a good movie.  The story claims to be based on true people, I can only assume this to be true, and as such, you have to feel sorry for them as the life portrayed here is far from glamorous.  I began to feel real pity for Rollergirl and Horner during the stretch-limo 'live' sequence, and Diggler had it far from easy towards the end.  Would I watch it again?...probably.  The quality of actors and acting was superb, even Reynolds put in a very straigt part, without any tongue-in-cheek at all.  Yes, definitely on the re-run list.

The camera work is amateurish (to the point of being comical in parts), half the acting is laughable (esp Wahlberg - his performance in the actual film is as stiff and unnatural as his performance in the adult films they're supposed to be shooting). It's basically a low budget film, trying to be an independent artistic film, but only succeeding in being so far up its own behind that (despite the number of truly talented actors like Julianne Moore), it manages to succeed only in patting itself of the back for bringing the shallow vision of a depraved pervert to life.
Don't get me wrong, I'm no prude, but there's zero artistic redemption here - just an excuse for "actors" to pretend they're making porn.
How this garnered any sort of accolades or attention beyond ironic laughter is beyond me.Literally, as I'm sitting here, re-watching it, every time Mark Wahlberg is on the screen, I'm taken out of the moment and reminded that he's just a horrible actor whom Hollywood is trying desperately for everyone to consider a star.Pure and utter tripe.
I can watch this movie so many times and not get sick of it. One of my faves of all time, great characters and character development.

So i was just reading about what new years eve movies to watch on holidays and this name poped up, coincidentally it had a pretty memorable sequence which was the turning point of the film on the new years eve party .
Paul Thomas Anderson did a fine job showing the rise and the fall of an adult movie star and the people around him working in that industry. The overall presentation was fantastic and it had a nice 70s and 80s feel to it . The character growth of the adult movie star Dirk Diggler was on to the point, Mark Wahlberg did a fine job playing the character .. In one of the sequences he got in his deep thinking about how far he has fallen which was one of the most memorable scenes of the movie. Burt Reynolds as Jack & Julian Moore were the acting stars who held the movie together and had great character development.Overall I would recommend it, for a good unconventional story and some good performances . Despite a lengthy screen time It doesn't bores you and you don't wish for it to just finish.

Paul Thomas Anderson's epic film about the origin, rise and fall of fictitious porn star Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg) is an incredible contribution to film, hands down.  While many of his `regular' actors (Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Phillip Baker Hall and Ricky Jay among them) are excellent actors in their own right, he squeezes hilarious, ironic and gut-wrenching performances from them. Probably the most effective performance of course is by Mark Wahlberg. While this was not his first film, it was his first starring role and when the film was over he was `Marky-Mark' no more.  A lot has been said about this film, and there are far too many reasons to mention to illustrate why this film has very solidly remained in my top 15 favorite films of all time, but one scene I would like to mention is the scene near the end of the film between Wahlberg, Reilly, Thomas Jane and Alfred Molina.  Set in Molina's living room and involving a drug deal, Anderson directs this scene with such incredible finesse that it goes down in history as one of the greatest moments in the last thirty years of film. Between the palpable tension, the brilliant choice of music and the unbelievable acting by the primaries, this scene is important to watch more than once to experience how a scene should be written and blocked to tell a story with both unflinching imagery and subtlety at the same time.  I will see a mediocre movie and then put on this scene after to renew my faith in *good* filmmaking.This is obviously not a film for everyone due to its subject matter, but it is such an incredible and important film, it should not be overlooked.--Shelly

But even when the film had a more leisurely pace, it was no less compelling, thanks to an intelligent script and an outstanding ensemble cast.  And of course, the best thing about this movie was Burt Reynolds, who finally got some well-deserved respect.

reviews.review_title: Another one of the new classics
reviews.content: This is a lengthy but well worth the time film that chronicles the careers of Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg), a popular young star of pornographic films during the 1970's. A veteran porno film director named Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) takes Eddie under his wing and quickly makes a star out of him. However, fame could come with a price as Eddie lets his celebrity status eventually get the best as well as the worst of him. A fine character study and an excellent showcase for all involved.

Paul Thomas Anderson is renowned for making weighty films filled with masterful directing, writing and acting. There Will Be Blood (my first taste of PTA) almost immediately became one of my top five favourites, resembling one of Stanley Kubrick's very best. I gave Magnolia a watch more recently and the whole thing astounded me with its emotional depth and richness. I'd been saving up Boogie Nights as many consider it Paul's greatest film. At a mere 26 years old, he created a critically-acclaimed masterpiece that blew his debut (which is still a pretty good film) out of the water. I couldn't wait to give Boogie Nights a watch and it didn't disappoint.I know it's not a popular opinion, but I still think There Will Be Blood and Magnolia are far better than Boogie Nights. However, that just shows how talented our Paul is as a filmmaker because Boogie Nights is a seriously terrific achievement right from the opening sombre music. We're then hit immediately by a blasting 70's pop track and a sweeping camera which takes us into the mind of Madonna when she was working on Confessions on a Dancefloor. A beautiful retro disco with all the main characters being introduced with perfect camera timing I don't know how Paul managed to do it but it's a fantastic piece of camera-work and it almost feels as though he's showing off a bit.The film is a rags to riches tale, with more than a touch of irony to it, of a young and naïve dishwasher who's whisked away by Burt Reynolds to become the biggest porn star there's ever been! The first half is the more entertaining and funny half. It's full of infectious energy and memorable characters who jump off the screen. For a film about the porn industry, there's surprisingly little smut aside from an extended sequence where Mark Whalberg films his first sex scene with Julianne Moore. It's extremely lively and full of fab scenes such as another impressive Steadicam move around a pool party and a fun montage showing Dirk Diggler's rise to pornographic stardom.The darker, second half is the more interesting one for me. We're suddenly plunged into the 80's and watch as everyone's lives go spiralling towards hell. The once friendly Dirk has turned into an egotistical cocaine-addict and Burt Reynolds has become a desperate director pimping his surrogate daughter out to strangers on the street. It's a sad chapter which adds weight and morality to the tale. The film could've been a terrific comedy in the vein of the Wolf of Wall Street, but the second half offers a lovely bleak balance and shows us that pornography is not an industry to aspire to get into. The seemingly fulfilled characters become much deeper and more tragic figures.There are some lovely scenes. One sequence which I really loved was a montage where all the characters are at their lowest. The music suited the scene so well and it felt very unsettling and intense. I also liked the moment where we're given a glimpse into Julianne Moore's life as she discusses getting custody of her child with her ex-husband. The film stops being fun and starts to become a much more serious beast set in a real world more closer to our own. Boogie Nights handles its many characters so expertly, kind of in the same way Magnolia did, although to a slightly lesser extent.Just when you think the film can't throw up any more brilliance, the best scene pops up towards the end. It involves Dirk's pathetic gang trying to orchestrate a drug deal at Alfred Molina's house. Everything about this scene is pretty much perfect from the acting to the music to the tense, unpredictable atmosphere. Even the firecrackers are a masterstroke! It erupts into a Quentin Tarantino styled shootout and the unpredictability of it all makes for a thrilling watch. In fact, the entire film is filled with so many terrific scenes that it makes for a very high rewatchability factor.My only complaint would be that, like Dirk's manhood, it's quite overlong. I think I would've preferred more of a focus on the 80's segment rather than the 70's. However, Boogie Nights is still a really great film. The thing that stands out the most is the masterful directing by the young Paul Thomas Anderson. Some argue that it's a Martin Scorsese rip-off but I'd argue that his style is even better than Martin Scorsese. It's a fantastic ride which leaves you with a lot to ponder about. So get your glad rags on and hit the dancefloor kids!

An excellent movie, its portrayal of the sex industry and of 70's and 80's life is interesting - you have to admire the fashions and general kitch of the era, which are captured extremely well. The sex is fairly explicit, so this may be hard film to watch in  mixed company but the overall effect is not cheesy and most of the sex scenes are erotic, funny or otherwise enjoyable. Overall a great watch, emotionally engaging if a little overlong  - this isn't a problem if you get involved with the characters however.

I saw this movie in the theater and enjoyed it, but didn't think it was that great.  I watched on cable last night and enjoyed it a lot more.  I caught a lot of things that I had missed the first time around.  I highly advise watching it twice and pay attention!

Mark Whalberg is incredible here in what must be the turning point of his acting career.This has one of the best ensemble casts ever.You really feel every characters story, Burt Reynolds and Juliane Moore, Heather Graham, John C Reily and an unrecognisable Phillip Seymour Hoffman are tremendous.Both William H Macy and Don Cheadle are excellent and nearly steal every scene they are in.This really builds up the characters so you then feel their despair when it happens.Tremendous Soundtrack too.This is probably the best film with pornography as its driving plot.

Boogie Nights can be divided into two halves: the rise and fall of a porn actor. In that it follows the same kind of structure as an archetypal gangster film. And, like with most gangster films, the first half of Boogie Nights is a feast for the eyes and ears. Anderson lets the camera swoop through one entertaining scene after the other, accompanied by a terrific soundtrack. All actors are in top form but it is Burt Reynolds that steals the show as a totally believable porn director. The second half of the film is less impressive. The story at times gets too far fetched (the Molina cameo although great, the scene is a bit too much), too Hollywoodesque and subplots (like Cheadle's) that are not interesting only distract from the main plot. First half an 8, second half a 5. So a 6,5 is my final verdict.

BOOGIE NIGHTSThis was a funny movie.The story is about the rise and fall of Dirk Diggler. A guy who washed glasses in a nightclub until he is spotted by a porn movie director. Dirk then goes into the porn industry and his life gets turned upside down.It is a very entertaining story and very easy to follow. I would say this movie was a comedy. There were a lot of funny moments in it, as well as other serious moments, which gave it an element of drama.The cast list was amazing. I knew a few of these people were in it, but I didn't realise this many famous people were acting in it. The film starred Mark Wahlberg, the legendary Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, John C. Reilly, Don Cheadle, William H. Macy & Phillip Seymour Hoffman.Everyone did an amazing job. It is not surprising that this film and the actors were nominated for so many awards, and even won a lot too.It felt like a bit or a roller coaster of a film. The emotions of the movie were all over the place. One minute I was laughing, then something would happen and it just shocked me. The drama kicked in... but then the comedy would come back.The film was set in the 70s and 80s... the clothes and hair was great. and the film also has a pretty good soundtrack.There was a lot of nudity in the film too. I don't know why I was surprised at this. After all, the film is about the porn industry... but for some reason I was shocked to see all these Hollywood actors and actresses flashing it all... and as for Mark Whalberg... he wishes his dong was that big! haha. Apparently, the fake willy that you saw at the end of the movie was given to Mark Wahlberg when filming was finished... he still owns it to this day... but it is not in the same condition anymore. haha.I will give this film 7 out of 10.I really liked it, and it really put me in a time machine and took me back to the 70s/80s. :)For more reviews, please like my Facebook page:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Ordinary-Person-Movie- Reviews/456572047728204?ref=hl

reviews.review_title: Some much has already been said...so I'll add these few thoughts...
reviews.content: This is a film so solid and well-crafted that I can't come up with (nor should come up with) a lengthy diatribe on why I liked it. So, here are five simple reasons why it's one of the greatest films of, if not simply the 90's, the last 40-50 years of cinema:1. Potentially the greatest ensemble cast put before a camera (Hoffman, Hall, Guzman, Moore, Macy, Reilly, Reynolds, Wahlberg, Cheadle, etc.)2. Absolutely the most danceable soundtrack that can double as a time capsule of the greatest dance hits of the 70's.3. You'd do best to ignore any review published by someone who knew there would be sex in this movie and didn't want to see the sex but watched it anyway for the sake of dismissing this movie as a trashy porno-flick.  You'd also want to disregard reviews done by horny people who "dug" this one because "there was nudity GALORE!!!  I LOVE PORN!!!"  Because not only is this movie NOT a porno,  it's not about SEX, SEX, SEX!!!  Granted this movie is set entirely within the shadowy culture of the adult-film industry of the 1970s, and there are a couple (no more) scenes of nudity and simulated sex acts, but this movie is not about that.  They are simply plot devices.  The movie is about people who have dreams...dreams,  goals,  desires to better their lives,  and appearing in adult movies is simply a pitstop on their road to "better-ness".  Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg---remarkable performance!!!) is an innocent (I mean just that) 17 year old from Torrance who commutes all the way to Hollywood every night to bus tables at Boogie Nights,  a disco club.  Why would he want to work miles from home when there are plenty of bus jobs in Torrance???  Because Eddie has dreams--to be a star,  to be rich,  to be loved,  to get away from Torrance and the mother who doesn't love him.  He meets Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) in the disco hot-spot,  and the company Jack keeps:  Beautiful Amber Waves,  a porn vet played by Julianne Moore;  Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly);  and a girl who is equally as young and innocent as Eddie,  The Rollergirl (Heather Graham).  Eddie sees a kinship in the fact that Jack,  Amber and Rollergirl have been tossed by the wayside by their families.  They have dreams too,  of money,  stardom and a better life up the road.  This movie is a portrait of this handful of throwaway refugees,  their humanity,  their frailness,  the raw open wounds that are exposed in their lives,  evident despite their ritzy homes and glitzy '70s disco attire.  You'd think such people who shed their clothes and perform sexual acts for money would be jaded to the point of zombie-like indifference,  but this movie presents the reality that the real person in all their painful soul is under the rubble somewhere,  and no amount of drugs or alcohol can keep it buried indefinitely.  Those people looking for the typical pointless porn-flick with close-up copulation,  augmented breasts,  blond wigs and zero personality in the characters will be let down by Boogie Nights.  Those looking for a great movie experience combining wan humor with extraordinary human drama should be more than satisfied with this movie.  I also loved the assortment of '70s rock and disco songs too!!! **** out of **** stars.  I also recommend Gia and The People Vs. Larry Flynt for character studies of misunderstood characters.
