reviews.review_title: An excellently delivered slice of amorality
reviews.content: Imagine if you bought a beautifully bound book with the right font-size and easy-to-read chapters to read to your children, but as you read a chapter each night it became clear that it raised more moral and ethical questions than it answered - would you be pleased? I dare say there's a few who will read this who will argue they would out of sheer ideological defiance; but the majority of parents wouldn't like their children to be exposed to moral filth.Boogie Nights is an amoral movie - by that, I mean that it is a semi-docudrama screenplay about a young man's entry into the porn-industry and the chaos and upheaval that lifestyle creates in both his and other peoples' lives without providing any moral perspective. Throughout the movie, the only people who object are narrow-minded bigots, and those who embrace it are intelligent and enlightened.Yet, it depicts a movie-making scene peopled by morally-ambiguous characters, who swing and sleep around despite being married, and are entangled in pornographic pursuits to one degree or another. This has got to be - yet again - another example of Hollywood money thrown at a movie to reinforce relativistic, amoral values and mock principles and anyone who lives by them.All the actors deliver utterly convincing roles, along with all their fetishes and sexual openness. The movie portrays victims of the porn-industry along with its winners. The only thing it fails to show is the absolute consequences, and those who suffer consequences do so only by virtue of being caught in the act.

BOOGIE NIGHTS tells a lie, a big fat whopper of a lie. You know it's lying and it probably knows its lying. But you listen to the lie and are mesmerized by it, because it is a sad, dreamy lie. It's like the uncle who talks about what coulda-shoulda-woulda happened had he not started drinking, or the cousin who wistfully tells of what she plans to do once she wins the lottery. It's a lie you come to believe in because, well, it's just nicer and easier that way.The big lie in BOOGIE NIGHTS is the whole concept of the story. The film is about making porn films in the 1970's. The film somewhat romantically suggests that the ragtag band of filmmakers involved at this one little studio are somehow a family. They also believe they are creating art as pa rt of a family business. The film almost makes you believe it too. The idea that the porn industry is basically opportunistic and exploitive is somehow tucked away in a corner somewhere, vaguely visible, but never pointed out or discussed. To do so would interfere with the sense of community that exists between the characters. And the characters need that feigned innocence in order to justify the way they survive.Don't get me wrong, I have no moral qualms about porn -- to each is own -- but I don't have any delusions either. Porn is a business as cold and impersonal as the sex it depicts. Some pornographic filmmakers may, indeed, take pride in their work and strive to make the best films possible, but that is like striving to make the best hotdog possible. Porn is a product, ground out for fast and easy consumption. And the people who work in porn do it for the money, or to satisfy their own particular sexual kink, or because, well, they haven't anything better to do with their lives. I just don't believe that a life in porn is something anyone aspires to, let alone turns to for social acceptance.But for a few hours watching BOOGIE NIGHTS, you simply accept the lie, just as the characters accept the little lies that make up their lives. You believe Mark Wahlberg's Dirk Diggler really believes the he has found his special place in life by using the special gift God as given him. You believe that Heather Graham's Rollergirl believes that she has attained true stardom. You believe that Julianne Moore's Amber Waves is convinced that you can be a drug using porn star and that shouldn't affect your right to have custody of your children. You believe that Burt Reynolds' Jack Horner truly feels he is making "art" films. Such is the magic web that Paul Thomas Anderson weaves in his long, meandering and amusing slice of the low life.
Alas, reality sets in and naturally things go awry. Everyone must face their lies and the film's characters have to pay. Ironically, the film itself replaces its central lie with an even bigger one: Anderson's Altmanesque epic of off beat reality suddenly gets sidetracked near the end and becomes a Tarantino-like mess of lurid plot twists. The dream world of casual sex becomes an unconvincing nightmare world of violence. The film gains its footing again at the end, but this large chunk of BOOGIE NIGHTS is just unbearably bad. Sex and violence become bedfellows. Anderson loses faith in his lie, just as his characters do.But when it is good -- in a sexually naughty sort of way -- the film is most endearing. Anderson explores a world rarely even acknowledged in polite circles and introduces an intriguing cast of characters. Reynolds possibly gives his best screen performance as the film's father figure and he is backed by a fine cast, especially Wahlberg in the role that moved him into the realm of stardom.A secondary, but relevant, theme in the story is the love of film as a medium. Like ED WOOD and BOWFINGER, BOOGIE NIGHTS celebrates the basic allure of making films, regardless of how questionable the finished movies might be. In a strange way, this is where the film's real honesty lies. A turning point in the film is the realization that film as a community event is fading. Tape and video are forever altering the way films are made and seen. Adult theatres, like the neighborhood movie house, are facing doom as video moves film from the public to the private sector. In wistfully mourning the passing of "classic porn," the film makes a statement about the way technology has demystified cinema: efficient multiplexes have shut down the movie palaces, VCR and DVD changed movie watching from something special to something banal, computer effects are passed off as drama, and anyone with a video camera can be a director.I guess one could be offended that Anderson uses pornography as a metaphor for all that film represents, but then again he wouldn't be the first. But in the end, he uses the alternate universe of the skin trade to make a profound and insightful observation about an art form. What begins as a lie becomes the truth.

reviews.review_title: Great film, with some added perks
reviews.content: This film is one of most entertaining films I have seen in a very long time. What Pulp Fiction did for John Travolta's career; this film did the same for Burt Reynolds sagging career.  Malk Walhberg makes a great transition from innocent teenager to drug-ravaged adult without missing a beat.In supporting roles, Don Cheadle is his usual excellent self, and Julianne Moore delivers a good performance as the "mother" of the porn industry. However, the best thing about this film is the appearance of the sultry Heather Graham naked.  This is the only time she appears nude in a film, so it might be worth buying just so you can see it.  I'm not going to tell you when it happens, but trust me, you won't be able to pull your eyes from the screen when it does.  She is truly a classic beauty. Overall, I give this film a 9 on a 1 to 10 scale, 1 being Battlefield Earth and 10 being Braveheart.  A definite must see!
Great production design, direction, editing, acting. Julianne Moore was robbed at the Academy Awards.

Interesting movie about a part of the movie industry that mostly lives in the shadow of the Big Boys (pun intended? I don't know, I'm not a Freudian). Unfortunately the screenplay carries quite a lot of dead weight. Too many characters, somewhat uniform individual destinies and, above all, a sickeningly moralistic message that really does great harm to the whole thing. All the main characters are flawed  as if there was a certain logic to it, which just isn't true. It is not true that because you participate in a porno movie you become a cocaine addict and ruin your family. The movie nearly suggests as much. There is a scene in which the character Don Cheadle plays steals money after a hold up. It is totally unnecessary for the story and stupid because the essential message of the incident is that he is an immoral guy anyway, so why should he care. The ending, when all return to Horner's "ashram", is puzzling and irritating. Are they all a big, loving family or what? Equally irritating are the contrived camera angles and movements which are not really motivated and don't provide additional viewing pleasure.So I think Boogie Nights is generally overrated. I regret that the director did not stick to the core of the story. Because it is a really good story  these people want to make something out of themselves, they want to be somebody. Not only do they want to make money, they dream of being true artists or at least accomplished craftsmen. The force of their apparent willpower causes some really funny scenes and the viewers can sympathize and identify with the characters. The set design is also very good, especially the pool zone of Horner's "ashram" is really beautifully filmed. Alfred Molina plays a completely crazy coke addict with a companion who continually throws crackers on the floor. I could recommend the movie for that over-the-top scene alone. All the acting is of the first order.

reviews.review_title: "Boogie Nights" - PT Anderson gives Porn the Goodfellas treatment
reviews.content: "Boogie Nights" is a classic Hollywood film of dreams and dreamers  the twist is its set in the porn business of the late seventies and early eighties. Writer director PT Anderson was just 25 when he made this homage - or should that be expose - and the movie shows him experimenting with techniques clearly borrowed from Scorsese and Altman amongst others. What's amazing is that it all comes off confirming his reputation as one of the most exciting young directors to emerge from the nineties.The film follows the life of the creatively named Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg) as he leaves home determined to make it by using the only asset he has  and it is quite a substantial asset. Along the way we meet the varied characters that inhabit the porn scene, most of whom are introduced in a stunning long take through a nightclub that opens the movie which is reminiscent of both Scorsese's "Goodfellas" and Altman's "The Player".At 156 minutes this film is very much an epic but Anderson wisely keeps the explicitness to a minimum, making this very much a piece of drama rather than erotica. What we are shown is a world where sex, drugs and money act as substitutes for artistic dreams and emotional need.The large cast produce uniformly excellent performances from Burt Reynolds porn director through cuckolded William H Macy to Jullianne Moore's drug addicted pornstar facing a child custody battle. Anderson handles his large cast with the assuredness of a seasoned veteran none of the characters get short changed by having their story lines abruptly abandoned.Both funny and disturbing in equal measures this is an excellent film, with bravura directing from Anderson and a style that perfectly evokes its setting. If there is a criticism to be made, and it's a harsh one, it's that Anderson occasionally seems too fond of his characters. Don't let the subject matter put you off, this is an excellent film that heralds the rise of a potential new auteur.9/10 - Excellent

When I think of "Boogie Nights" three other films come into my mind: Martin Scorcese´s "Goodfellas" and "Casino" as well as Abel Ferrera´s "King of New York": almost all movies happen in a period of one, two or three decades and tell the story of men who have it all - power, money, sex and drugs..."Boogie Nights" tells the story of a 17 year old country boy who becomes a celebrated porn star at the end of the 70s. But his downfall seems to be inevitable: with the beginning of the 80s and the glory of the videotape his star begins to sink, he becomes a junkie, a male prostitute and his career seems to be ended before it began...Paul Thomas Anderson´s film is an homage on the spirit of age of the 70s as well as a movie about idealism, about people who believe in their ideas, their visions and themselves. The film contains next to "Saturday Night Fever" one of the greatest 70s soundtracks I´ve ever heard. Only a short time after "Boogie Nights" was released a similar movie with nearly the same theme came out: "54" starring Ryan Phillipe and Neve Campbell tells the story about the 70s disco-era, glitter, glamour and cocaine. This film has almost the same plot that "Boogie Nights" has , but it never reaches the qualities of its predecessor in any way! It is also the great cast which makes Paul Thomas Anderson´s film being one of the definitely masterpieces of the 90s: especially the great performances of Burt Reynolds (a real surprise!!!), William H. Macy, John C. Reilly, Marky Mark Wahlberg who acts like a young de Niro and Julianne Moore are outstanding!!!A must-see for all those who think the real big cinema is already dead or only consists of soulless moneymakers like "Pearl Harbor" or "Titanic"!!!!!!10/10

reviews.review_title: A funny and engaging saga of dreams, debauchery, and the search for belongingness.
reviews.content: The very beginning of Boogie Nights sets the tone for the entire picture. A melancholy piece of sentimental music plays over a black screen before being quickly drowned out by an explosion of upbeat disco. It's almost as though PT Anderson wanted the audience to feel like they just snorted a line of cocaine. The brilliant tracking shot that follows does a fantastic job of introducing all the characters, but it is that first screen that sets the tone; Boogie Nights is not about the glitz and glamor of its time period, but rather the sadness and desperation that lies beneath the gilded surface.The film follows a well-endowed and starry-eyed teenager named Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg), who escapes the turmoil of his home life by immersing himself in the sex and drug-fueled world of disco-dancing and hardcore pornography. Porn mogul Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds)and the sexy yet maternal Amber Waves (Julianne Moore)take Eddie under their wing, adopting him into their own twisted 'family', which Eddie is eager to join. As Eddie changes his persona to Dirk Diggler, the line between his real self and his on screen persona begins to blur, and the humbleness of his Eddie Adams is replaced by the ego-crazed arrogance of Dirk Diggler.After watching Boogie Nights time and time again, I have come to realize how truly unique it is in that the tonal shifts of the plot seem natural rather than jarring. There is a lot of humor in this movie, and at the same time a lot of sadness. Like all great filmmakers, PT Anderson is a master at playing with the audience's emotions. Boogie Nights, as well as his next film Magnolia, are emotional roller coaster rides. The key to mastering this is good characterization and seamless tonal shifts, both of which Boogie Nights succeeds in getting right.Tone is hard to define, but it can make or break a film. If a comedy is too serious, then it doesn't work. If a drama isn't taking itself seriously enough, then it doesn't work. Boogie Nights somehow manages to find that balance throughout its many tonal shifts, and for that it is a unique film watching experience.Perhaps the biggest strength in PT Anderson's films is his attention to detail in regards to his characters. In this ensemble cast, almost all of the characters undergo an emotional journeys of some sort. The fact that even the most ancillary characters have a storyline makes the film seem more realistic, and this makes it easier for the audience to sympathize with their struggles.The acting in the film is mostly superb, although truthfully I found a few scenes a bit too melodramatic. Mark Wahlberg did a good job, but in some scenes I feel he has a tendency to overact. However this is a minor gripe, and in the overall scheme he does a fantastic job revealing the emotional nuances of his character. John C. Reilly plays my favorite character in the film, Reed Rothschild, Dirk Diggler's best friend and eternal man-child.Julianne Moore gives a highly emotional and affecting performance, and Burt Reynolds is, for once, not completely annoying.On the contrary, he gives another fantastic performance. Heather Graham is great eye candy for the film, but her character has a lot more depth than her 'rollergirl' persona might suggest. In some ways I find her storyline more interesting than Dirk's.As someone who is a big fan of the music, films, and culture of the late 70's and early 80's, the setting of Boogie Nights appeals to me a great deal. The soundtrack is phenomenal, and the film uses it in some very unique ways. For example, who could forget Dirk's rendition of 'The Touch'? If you haven't seen the film yet, its worth watching for that scene alone! The film seems to have an appreciation for the time period, but also uses the changes of the period to represent changes in the characters, such as when the primary medium of porn changed from film to tape. This is masterfully done and a unique way to tell the story.Boogie Nights is a finely crafted and emotionally engaging film that engrosses you not only in its story, but in its characters and setting as well. Its one of those films you can watch time and time again and never get tired because there is simply so much to appreciate. The only things holding it back from masterpiece status are some stilted performances, but for the most part it is a great achievement.

reviews.review_title: Glamorised, violent account of the porn industry of the 70's.
reviews.content: PT Anderson's docu-satire on the hardcore porn industry of the late 70's and its collapse over the conservative 80's is a bold and daring tale. It also establishes him as one of the greatest young directors around at the moment. Anderson creates a unique style in the visual aspect of the film. It maintains the look and feel of a low-budget porn movie, but also the un-graded look of a documentary and the over-lapping, interweaving narrative of a satire. Indeed, he really should pay his dues to Robert Altman as he creates a similar effect. `Boogie Nights' certainly isn't for the easily provoked. There's an awareness of explicit sex as well as an aberrant sexual content, throughout. It's actually surprising that the film didn't receive an X rating (i.e. the kiss of death) from the MPAA.But one thing that `Boogie Nights' may have missed out on- perhaps intentionally- was heart. All of the characters have such high degrees of bad attitudes, it's hard to really sympathise with them or understand what they're going through. The movie follows an unusual pattern. While it is ultimately compelling, it lacks the overall dramatic shape and comprehensiveness of what it sets out to be. It also may have benefited from a better- that is more audible- soundtrack.Much like the style of Altman, the movie creates large visual sweeps as it takes in a variety of events and talks. The sound emphasises on the key elements. The editing is done very seldom in each scene as the camera follows around the characters for long periods of time, adding to the authenticity of it all. These techniques are very impressive and appreciative, but with so many characters on screen at once and the rapid-rate plot, the supporting characters rarely develop. As soon as the camera settles on one character, it quickly moves on to the next, providing us with no new information or background. And in classic Altman sense, sub-plots are briefly glanced upon but rarely explored. All characters are taken at face value.Having said that, there are tremendous performances all round from a cast made up almost entirely of Anderson's best friends in showbiz. Mark Wahlberg is a suitable lead while Burt Reynolds' turn as porn director Jack Horner is probably his best performance to date, though he takes the back seat for most of the movie. Julianne Moore's Amber Waves is an excellent creation and she perfectly balances sex-goddess with vulnerable single mother. Other supporting parts, no matter how small, are all fine but the real stand-out is John C. Reilly. It's strange how someone can go from saintly nobody (`Chicago', `Magnolia') to egotistical, tyrannical porn-star so easily.Other technical credits are top-notch all round. The art direction and cinematography are so synthetic to the last detail; it's easy to forget that the film was made in 1997. Of course there have been many complaints about the shocking amount of violence towards the end. While they may have gotten a little carried away with themselves, I prefer to think of them as punctuation marks stressing how important the given scene, and the collapse of the porn industry is.In my humble opinion, `Magnolia' is the better film as it went into a little more depth with the characters (virtually played by the exact same actors) but `Boogie Nights' is a glistening, gritty and colossal satire on the change of attitudes as the 70's ended and the 80's began. My IMDb rating: 8.0/10.

reviews.review_title: Though it goes through a familiar plot line, you haven't seen anything like this before
reviews.content: Heard numerous references of this movie from different media sources and always had a confused look as to what they were talking about. It all makes sense now. One of the most star studded movies you will ever come across except that most of them were not stars yet.Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg) has an exceptional natural gift which is spotted by Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) who grooms him, gives him an opportunity to show the world of his gift and also help him achieve his dream. Can Eddie control his ego that came along with his newly successful life, is Horner just a man who exploited his talent or something more? Answering these questions form the rest of the story.Now let me rephrase my synopsis as it sounded more like a parallel story of Rambo 3. Horner is an adult film maker who spots Eddie with a large penis and an ability to go all day long. Their synergy builds a successful run for both along with the entire unit who treat each other like family. One fine day Eddie's ego gets the better of him and the entire unit crumbles with it. Their road to darkness and resurfacing to light forms the rest of the story.I hated Paul Thomas Anderson when I watched Magnolia. Though it had a moving story and filled with excellent performances, it was flat out depressing. I feared a similar approach in this movie too not minding the energetic title. There were quite a few movies that follows the exact same storyline, most of them has either dealt with musicians or athletes but none with porn stars which stands out here. It has its moments of being awkward, cheeky, innocent and informative. It has a number of lengthy purposeful cameos by talented actors, researched portrayal of how the business of adult film industry is run, an excellent background score especially when Eddie, Horner, Rollergirl (Heather Graham) and Buck (Don Cheadle) hit rock bottom. Unlike most of his other movies, Anderson managed to life the spirits at the end of the movie though he takes you through hell just before it.Though it goes through a familiar plot line, you haven't seen anything like this before.

reviews.review_title: They handled the subject matter very well with little exploitation.
reviews.content: This  was a very good movie that showed the late 70s and early 80s realistically.  They showed a human side to the  adult film industry.  The sound track was very good.

I love Paul Thomas Anderson.  I love BOOGIE NIGHTS. The humor in this film is incredible.  And, some of the scenes are true stealers in every essence of the word. I would also recommend the double set DVD.  The commentary from PTA is superb.  He's extremely insightful.

I don't get what made this movie a success. Number one, what was it supposed to prove to us? That people in the world of smut are carefree loving people who are often misunderstood? Number two, why the 70s for the era? Why not the 60s, 80s, or 90s? This is another "so what" film where you couldn't feel sympathy for the characters or even the plot in general. Every second of the movie is earpopping-loud disco music, which really makes you wonder whether you're watching a movie or a Pink Floyd rendition of mellow gold.Paul Thomas Anderson (who made a great movie called "Hard Eight" earlier that year) seems to display every cliche in sight. What other director has a fetish for the 70s? I could think of a list. (I'm sure you know of one right now which Hollywood is drooling all over.) Add those cliches, hollow characters, silly dialogue, and a faux penis which is enough to make the remains of the Funky Bunch puke boulders.Face it, a movie about a circus clown who sells balloons made out of condoms would be more interesting compared to this.

Second feature by Paul Thomas Anderson (`Hard Eight') centers around various characters at an adult movie industry in Disco era 70s and 80s.  Among these characters include  busboy Wahlberg who destines a career in a Bruce Lee movie, an estranged, drug addicted mother (Julianne Moore, who's  terrific in a nominated performance) and a girl whose only qualm is never removing the roller skates.  The supporting characters are  shallow, and Mark Wahlberg's one-tone character is tasteless and entirely unsympathetic. After nearly 3 hours, the movie itself never decides what it wants to be. A comedy, or drama? Certainly nothing dramatically affective, but it was too tongue and cheek to be taken seriously.This movie probably wasn't supposed to be taken seriously. But then again, who could take an overrated mess seriously?

This movie was very entertaining! I couldn't stop watching it!                              It was just so good directed and so great actors (he, he). No seriously everyone did a great job in this movie. William H Macy's trouble with his wife was a bit sarcastic but fun.

reviews.review_title: Redemption and forgiveness expressed beautifully through Porn
reviews.content: Everything about "Boggie Nights" is sincere and straightforward, and with an wide array of unforgettable characters, it is one of the most distinctive American films made in the late 1990's. Everyone's born with one special thing, and Eddie Adams (Marc Wahlberg) uses his "special gift" and is poised to take the world of porn by storm. Eddie Adams, (also known as Dirk Diggler), is discovered by porn director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) and soars to the top of the pornography industry. After achieving great success in the industry during the 1970's, the 80's did not fair so well for Dirk. A change of culture coupled with a drug addiction, he quickly hits rock bottom not knowing anything else to turn to. At the heart of the story is a group of eccentric, outlandish group of characters, an unorthodox "family" if you will. An incredible collection of actors and performances keep this lengthy film completely engaging throughout the 155 minutes. Despite of what you may think of these people and their profession, you can't help but be drawn into their lives and personal stories. Paul Anderson's attention to the fine details; decor, style, culture, and social attitudes of the era are spot on. It is heart-rendering and darkly humorous with an message of redemption and forgiveness.

reviews.review_title: Coming out film from one of the future greats in the industry
reviews.content: credit both anderson and the cast for making this one of the best films of the 90's...the ensemble cast is perfect, from mark wahlberg on down...for fans of dialogue-driven movies(i.e. Pulp Fiction), this is a must see...anderson uses the numerous characters not so much to drive the story, but rather to describe an era...

Were the late 70s the anomie that so many claim it to be?  I was in my adolesence so I missed out on the adult stuff, but it sure had a decadent feel to it that even I noticed at that age.  Anderson captures that atmosphere very well here by juxtaposing the shallow music of the era with the depraved actions of many of its lonley occupants.  The result is a compelling story told within a lurid cheapness.  All the actors are great, and the donut shop scene is absurdly entertaining.

with one of the best names for a film character outside a cameron crowe flick (lloyd dobbler, penny lane, etc.) julianne moore's amber waves was the perfect way for mainstream America to be introduced to ms moore. as someone who has made her mark embodying characters so convincingly one almost expects her to step of screen in this persona. unfortunately, this is the same reason why she never had a chance in hell of winning when she was nominated for an academy award for her work in boogie nights. let's face it, a large percentage of the academy's voting members are unlikely to find a cocaine addicted porn star deserving of their highest honour. what is so infuriating about this slight is the complexity of this character that was apparently ignored due to how gifted an actress played this role. few actresses could bring together the varying aspects of amber waves character in such a way that they were not so heavy-handed you were beat over the head with them. as evidence of this i remind you of the scene shown at the Oscars when her name was called as a nominee. instead of one showing the internal conflict she endures between being a mother and being a porn star we were treated to the part where amber and roller girl sit a room, get all coked up and freak out. perhaps the most unsophisticated scene for this character and yet it was the one chosen as best representative of how the academy saw amber waves.
Incredibly good, every detail thought through. Amazing story telling, amazing playing it all just leaves you mind blown.

reviews.review_title: A well done movie I didn't enjoy
reviews.content: This movie is very well done. Julianne Moore is great, and this is the best performance I've ever seen Burt Reynolds put forth.The subject matter is gritty and sleazy, but the characters (for the most part) are not. It's not often in a movie where the average viewer is rooting for someone to get back into the porn business! I found this movie down-right excruciating to watch in parts. Some of the more painful ones seemed to last forever.I can appreciate that this movie is well done. It obviously hit a nerve with me.I'm glad I saw it, I didn't enjoy it, and I don't want to see it again.I'm giving it a seven because the acting was good, and the movie was well made. I would give it a 4 for enjoyment.

Boogie Nights is a great movie, and gives a sugar coated insight into the late 70s subculture of the Californian porn industry, before vds became deadly and when porn was shot on film. This is very much a picture of a world after the sexual revolution of the late 60s, inhabited people who are all slightly eccentric, to varying degrees. There is Roller Girl (Heather Graham), who literally goes through life (and school) on roller skates, there is Eddy Adams/Dirk Diggler (Marc Wahlberg, who's character seems like a combination of John Holmes and Jeffrey Stryker) and who has "one special talent" (his humongous dong) and is obsessed with Bruce Lee (who isn't/wasn't), Maggie/Amber Waves (Julianne Moore) and Buck Swope (Don Cheadle, based roughly on the famous porn actor Johnny Keyes, from among many other films, "Behind The Green Door", and/or Jack Baker).I especially like Don Cheadle's character (a great actor), who in an epitome of the way all the characters don't fit in with society, is an almost perfect stereo salesman, who falls down because of insisting on playing the customers _HIS_ (rather than their) favorite music, Country & Western. Buck Swope is continually one style behind, insisting that "country will make a comeback" throughout the seventies, and at new year's eve party 1979/1980 being decked out in an afrocentric/outer space outfit that makes him look like one of the members of Earth, Wind & Fire. He finally finds his style, though, in early eighties Hip-Hop.Rather than being simply a showcase of seventies culture, all of the characters are amalgams of several porn characters, and many of the situations are similar to actual events.For instance, the drug situation at the end of the movie is similar to what happened to John Holmes (he was interviewed by homicide detectives - see the movie "Wonderland" with Val Kilmer). John Holmes, though, in the end died if AIDS, caught in a gay video shoot, rather than just being beaten up by a gang of homophobes (without ill effects).Which is where the sugar coating comes in. In this movie, most of the characters in the end find their places in society, whereas in real life, several ended up dead. Another example, in this movie, the drug of choice seems to be cocaine, but in reality, it was heroine, probably so we don't have scenes of people shooting up. So, you have the situation of several characters overdosing on coke, which is a rare event, whereas od'ing on heroine is quite common. Also, no one ever catches any std.Anyway, the structure of the movie is almost very similar to Oliver Stone's Vietnam movies - the viewer is swept along with the progress of history and time, rather than depending on intricate plotting. The characters do develop, though, but predictably.Either way, this is a unique movie. Go and see it if you haven't already.

reviews.review_title: I'll say two things: Don Cheadle
reviews.content: With an older and more seasoned eye, this really is a very well-put together film. It has just enough entertainment, just enough great acting, just enough of everything. As a younger person, in the 1990's it was shocking, now it is mild in subject matter, but the subject matter is why I took off one star -- there were too many nude scenes. The other star is taken off, because, for all of its grit, the movie was a happy one, with a happy ending. That's not how it usually goes in life. The most wonderful aspect of the movie was the performance by Don Cheadle. His character was just sweet. I loved the scene where he changed his look, and met his new love. I wish that he had more starring roles with comedic value. He is a human heart!

reviews.review_title: Add this to my list of favorites
reviews.content: Boogie Nights is definitely "re-watchable". The characters, the story lines and even the soundtrack are all great. The time line in which everything occurs is all within my late childhood to early teen years and the movie leaves you with a feeling of nostalgia. I recommend this to anyone that was a child of the 70's or 80's.

reviews.review_title: if it weren't soft porn it would a made-for-prime time TV movie.
reviews.content: Made me feel like a sucker. All those good reviews over at Rotten Tomatoes, and such a boring, nondescript, stupid movie. Now when I think of it, I think of Maverick. Probably the combination of the fancy house, Burt Reynold's dark hair and average good looks, and the sweet charms of lovable Julian Moore.What I expected- some sort of exploration of what it is really like to be required to perform sexually in front of a production crew. What is it like to be a wealthy well-known but despised outcast? What consequences for personal relationships come with the territory? These things are hinted at, but either just glanced over or dealt with according to stereotype.Bored!!!

reviews.review_title: I really wanted to like this movie
reviews.content:
I like P.T. Anderson a LOT (_Magnolia_ is one of my favorite films of all time), so it hurts to admit this: _Boogie Nights_ is not a very good movie. This is a mystery, in light of an excellent director, an excellent cast, and excellent camerawork.  In fact, nearly everything about this movie is perfect, EXCEPT the script.  To put it nicely, the script just plain stinks. While I can see that the film is supposed to make some sort of point about loneliness and interpersonal relationships, the story is completely jumbled and just doesn't make very much sense.  Characters never really develop as well as they should and are not very interesting.I'm not really sure why anyone does anything in this movie; motivations are never an issue.  Although the film certainly succeeds in evoking certain moods, I was never sure why I felt the way I did about a particular scene and ended up getting annoyed.  Finally, the ending, which could have saved the entire film, kind of petered out and left me feeling disappointed.
I can see why this film made money.  It contains excessive drugs, sex, and pornography.  It's not that these ruin the film for me; it's just that the film never really gets beyond these into any meaningful story. 
In summary, this is a nice technical film.  However, _Magnolia_ is superior in every way (incidentally, not only to this film, but to many others as well.)

reviews.review_title: Tells the story as it was, back in the day
reviews.content:
a huge hit in my books - the storylines instantly fell into place right from the opening scene - it also uncovers the coruptity of the adult film industry as you see later on in the movie when Dirk/Eddie starts doing drugs, gets violent when he sees a new kid who he thinks might threaten him out of the business, etcby the end of the movie, i sat awed at the screen - a masterpiece, told as exactly as is had been from the late 70's and 80's - an excellent story that was daring to direct and produce
8 / 10 starsdaros

reviews.review_title: This is a long drawn out movie
reviews.content: I was told over and over that I had to watch this movie. I would have been better off watching an ant wander around a sandbox. It was on IFC, and it stole 3 hours of my life. There just doesn't seem to be a plot. Nothing in the film seems to get resolved. The acting is OK, but the directing is awful. There are several instances where you're just looking at someone staring off into space for perhaps a whole minute or longer. You don't get to see what they're looking at, or what they're thinking about, you just see the blank look on their face and that's it. At the end of the movie, I'm sure that's how I looked. The only good thing I can say about it is that I got my nails painted while I watched it.

Having eagerly awaited this film, now I've finally got to see it I am very disappointed.  Some of the acting is decent, but the film as a whole just seems so pointless.  We just get to watch as the lives of a bunch of self-obsessed and insecure people fall apart along with porn industry.  So what!  Apart from Julianne Moore part none of the characters are remotely engaging and having endured the whole film I frankly couldn't give a fig what happened to any of them.

reviews.review_title: Repressed view on the porno biz - highly overrated.
reviews.content: First I thought BOOGIE NIGHTS was supposed to be a satirical view on 70s porn film business. But slowly it dawned me that this overly long movie was a morale tale. Everyone of the characters, who all work in the blue movie biz, end up in the gutter. No-one seems to make a fortune, earn respect, or even have fun. No, they are all junkies, coke-heads, losers, and even dumb. The only world they can make it in is their sinful trade. What a hypocritical way to look at things. I assure you there are plenty of careers in Hollywood based on some involvement in the adult film market. This film tries to get the reputation of a "daring and groundbreaking film". Nonsense! Is it daring? Nope. Just take the scene in which Julianne Moore and Mark Wahlberg are filmed on 16mm. We can see the footage they shoot. It's supposed to be a hardcore flick, right? So why does the director only shoot from the waist up? Repressed. And this infamous shot of Wahlbergs Willy - it only shocked the uptight American critics. There was no need to show it that late in the film. It just wanted to gain attention in a cheap way at the end of a very long film. It is a shameful film, in more than one way. And it's another example how you can screw up a great idea.

Yes, this movie is about the pornographic industry. If you are not a fan of such an industry, the movie might not "grab you" as much as it should. But, think about it: it is interesting to know how this kind of "world" works around. This movie didn't get a 10 from me because it reminds me of lemonade. Let me make this clearer: the plot is interesting, but the story line is too light. This is not necessarily a bad thing. Sometimes, movies turn out better when they are more "light weight". Due to the volatile natures of the characters, this lightness fitted in quite well. It's almost perfect. A certain heaviness of the story is embedded into this lightness with a very "merry" soundtrack following it around throughout the entire movie. However, it was not embedded enough. I mentioned the soundtrack. Before I comment on that, I must say that I think that soundtracks are VERY IMPORTANT in a movie. If the soundtrack does not fit into the movie, it is very possible that I will dislike the entire thing, even though the movie itself without the music might be good enough. The OST of this movie is: TERRIFIC. The music goes along with the characters and especially the story, but in some instances: the music was too happy, when it should have been more solemn.It would be a shame not to watch this movie. It's a good movie. Perhaps not perfect, but it still can be charted in "a movie you must see before you die". I hope you enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: A REALISTIC PORTRAYAL OF THE ADULT FILM INDUSTRY?
reviews.content: Since having seen this film and in a previous review where I thought it "realistic," I have made a study of the adult film industry. As a result, I have found that this highly regarded and most entertaining film conveys some misconceptions about that industry. Firstly, if you look at the films in that period (the late seventies), you'll find that much of the acting is quite good and the production values were quite high (it was not unusual for a porno film to be budgeted at $200,000).  Sex scenes and nonsex dialogue or plot scenes ran about 50/50, unlike todays films which are almost all sex and have very few accomplished actors in them. Often foreign locales such as London were used as settings (see Marylin Chambers in "Insatiable," for example)., and the sets could be quite elaborate.  "Boogie Nights" suggests that only the cheapest of sets were used and the performers were a pack of semi retarded dolts, and that was just not true.Secondly, for the most part the performers did not congregate in well-knit groups, although some of that was done.  Most went their separate lives after a scene or a film was shot.  Some just went home to the wife or husband and the kids.  Christine Fugat, in her recent documentary "The Girl Next Door," tells of how much she was impressed by how "normal" these people seemed to her.Next, generally the women were not  dumb and forced  to work for menial wages; many of them were quite intelligent and just chose to work in that industry and aspired (unsuccessfully for the most part) to get into mainstream films, mainly for the money.  Today, it is taken for granted that women rule that industry often setting the conditions under which they will work, the things they will and will not do, etc.Probably the most accurate depiction in the film was the debilitating effects video tape had on the quality of the films produced. There was a period in the 70's were "porno chic" was prominent.  Even Roger Ebert gave a favorable review to "The Devil and Miss Jones," as I recall.  People, often prominent ones, would wait in line to see such productions as"Deep Throat" and "Behind the Green Door."  Marylin Chambers was treated as a true star and stayed at the best hotels and appeared at grand openings, searchlights and all.Next, although cocaine use was widespread, that tended to be true of many professions in that era, including mainstream. Hollywood. The adult film industry was not a glaring exception.If the director "researched" the porn film industry, as he claims, I would suggest that he did a poor and one sided job of it. I still say his commentary track is one of the worst I have heard on a DVD.

reviews.review_title: Emperors New Clothes, aka the Woody Allen syndrome
reviews.content: A worse film I don't think I will ever see. I just found it hard to care about any of the characters...and it didn't really tell me anything I didn't expect about a sordid industry. I am no prude, far from it, I have watched the films that this film portrays on many occasions. But to make a whole film about the making of them was scraping the barrel. All the characters were shallow, despicable, two faced and that was their good points and the plot went nowhere fast. At the end I said to myself "Did I miss something here?" But then I realised that I had been through it all before with every Woody Allen film that is ever released.

Boogie Nights is a movie about family, not intended for families. While the source material may ruffle some feathers, it's certainly handled with compassion.Seems only fitting that Paul Thomas Anderson, an untamed 26-year-old from San Fernando Valley, was able to run with this project. His creativity and audiovisual artistry is on full display here.I can't praise the floating camera movement enough. Long take, steadicam tracking shots are littered thoughout, creating an engaging, immersive experience. They never feel gratuitous either, but rather necessary to carry out scenes and connect with the characters.With so much to commend, it's hard not to 'Digg' this.

I enjoyed Boogie Nights, but it seemed to be a less successful precursor to the 1999 film 'Magnolia', recounting the stories of various characters that we're supposed to fall in love with and then marvel at, shaking our heads at their respective ill-gotten fates by the end. Most of the characters were wholly likable but far too shallow to really care about - worrying about superficial values, appearances or how many lines of coke they can snort at a time.Initially I was wary of the impact of Boogie Nights, expecting a sordid, dark, sinister type of experience, instead of a frivolous tale with tongue-in-cheek humour throughout. I new I was going to like it right from the start, with it's star-studded cast, excellent soundtrack and visual style, but it started to lose steam after an hour because of the non-discernible plot progression and novelty level that had worn off.The film has lots of swearing, epic amounts of cocaine abuse but not that much nudity or pornography, surprisingly. It's also graphically violent in places, but didn't shock or affect me in the way I expected. In fact, Boogie Nights is a film about gullible, often charming, not very sensible people that ultimately lose their way in life, later trying to redeem themselves, accepting that they're ultimately pretty f**ked up as a whole.But somehow it didn't gel together well enough, emotionally, by the end.Definitely worth a watch, but not as shocking or ground-breaking as you might think.

I don't know, I'm kind of on the fence with this one.  I enjoyed the movie, but like everyone says it was very long.  I very much liked Mark Wahlberg in this movie.  I thought his Dirk Diggler character was excellent.  Very sensitive and sweet at times, and also used to the very end.  I grew up with Mark in Boston and this, I have to say is a great improvement.  A lot of reviews I've read were downing the graphic sex and drug use, well duh, that's what this movie was suppose to be about.  The rise and fall of the pron industry, get a clue.  You don't go and watch a film called "Boogie Nights" and expect to see The Congress in session or to hear the Benny Goodman band.  It was a story about the 70's and early 80's when drugs and sex were the why things happened.  Everyone did it, so stop trying to act all goody-two-shoes.  Sit back and enjoy, and stop complaining.

reviews.review_title: Epic masterpiece of the low road
reviews.content: This movie was the product of a newcomer, who proved that he would be one of the most important young film-makers with this and Magnolia.  Paul Thomas Anderson is a little of a show-off with his camera movements, but the scenes impress us so much, that we ignore such hubris.  Imagine a combination of Robert Altman, Oliver Stone, and Martin Scorsese, and you would get Anderson.  Though it is about pornography, it really limits the nudity in the film.  The performances are also something to watch.  Julianne Moore as the 'mother' of the film 'family' gives a performance that deserved the oscar. Burt Reynolds, Mark Wahlberg, and Don Cheadle also give memorable performances.  This film was overlooked at the oscars, and certainly deserved more awards than it received.

There are few movies that can take a song and marry it to a scene in a movie as well as boogie nights did. Making it so that when you hear that song the scene automatically pops into your head. This movie was very entertaining! I could'nt stop watching it!It was just so good directed and so great actors (he, he). No seriously everyone did a great job in this movie. William H Macys trouble with his wife was a bit sarcastic but fun.

this is a highly over-rated film.  i'm not conservative right-winger, nor am i unfamiliar with the "anti-hero" theme, but this film failed to grab my interest or pity.  i've sat through films twice as long as this and didn't get as bored as i did with this film.  none of the characters go unpunished for their hedonistic lifestyle, nor does anyone change (i.e. julian moore's character never re-establishes a relationship with her son).  and when did "marky-mark" become such a stud?  finally, the final scene is a strait rip-off of "raging bull".  "boogie nights" sucked!

reviews.review_title: A realistic movie that shows how the 70's and 80's were.
reviews.content: This movie had a good plot, but I don't think it's excellent. I really didn't like the ending since it wasn't what I expected to see. The ending was incredible and very unexpected, besides we realize about how bad and strange the people are. If you like the 70's and 80's you should see it to know about the reality that they lived during those years. Paul Anderson was great, he really knows how to make good films that entertain a lot. This is an interesting movie in which you could see the way some people during 70's and 80's were. Things were very bad during those years and what about this year?? I think we still have problems like drugs, sex, money, etc. This movie shows it and more. Watch it and find out some more about the 70's and the beginning of 80's. On the other hand Julianne Moore was incredible, she is really a great actress, she got a nomination for best actress. This movie won a lot of awards because of its plot, camera work and the way they show how bad life is. It's worth watching only to know what's bad and good. 7/10

Despite being one of Paul Thomas Anderson's first directorial efforts, this film still holds up to this day. The film is beautifully illustrated by the grooviness of the '70s with a classic song constantly playing in the background or unique camera movements to immerse the audience into the drug-infused trip the characters go through. The film has a premise that feels original and emotional, tacking the adult pocket of cinema when it was at its peak of popularity, transitioning to the aftermath of its slow decline. This is brilliantly inhabited by characters that are written with such emotion and humanity, accompanied by performances that breathe life into the characters, giving them genuine character and personality. The directing in the film is also noteworthy, bringing an earlier version of Anderson's style to the masterful filmmaking that will come later in his career. However, despite the many positives this film has, it is not entirely perfect. The film at times feels a little all over the place, focusing on characters that don't really have a purpose to the overall story. The film also goes on a little longer than it ultimately should. Although it may have minor flaws, Boogie Nights is a groovy experience filled with a brilliant character study, an amazing story, and immaculate directing that will shock and awe the audience with every viewing.

Despite the high ratings in Meta Critic and on this website, I thoroughly did not enjoy watching this film.Firstly, it's too long, and the plot is very simple about a man who is a college dropout and picked up by an Adult Movie director whilst working in the kitchen of a nightclub. He is blessed with a large penis and being very good in bed.The movie sees this man rise to the top, then his addiction to Class A narcotics and fall from grace. As the 4 main porn stars get addicted to the drugs, their characters change a lot which is indicative of real life however the film portrays in a very annoying, egotistical way which is frustrating to watch.As a movie, this is not particularly thought-provoking or meaningful, and the final scene is thoroughly confusing where they attempt to rob someone and then it fails.Then the movie all seems to correct itself, magically, in the end with just an apology, which is not indicative of real life drug abuse.

What if a person thinks they are talented but they are not? What if this person has a burning desire to be in the movie business and it is the the 70's before independent film took off? One answer, porno movies.
Boogie Nights gives a glimpse into the world of skin flicks in their hey day in the San Fernando Valley. Writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson is masterful in capturing the energy of this time with disco scenes, parties with the right clothes and music. But better than this are the quirky characters. They believe that they are terrific actors, artists and musicians. What they will not admit is that they make poorly made porno films. The pain of life is too strong for them but it can only be held off for so long. Time and again the facts come crashing in finally leading to an ending which feels like a bad hang over. Paul Thomas Anderson's style is impressive. It sometimes looks like Scorsese with the long tracking shots and a great Raging Bull dressing room scene. There is a little bit of Tarantino also. But better than this is how well the actors perform under Anderson's direction. This is Burt Reynolds' best work since Deliverance. Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, Don Cheadle are great portraying people who have turned their back on much of the world, trying to create their own. These characters grow on you after a while. They are there for each other including taking in Mark Wahlberg's Dirk Digler who is the most convinced of his "greatness". I can't help but think of Ed Wood when I see this film. He also brought together a group of misfits that struggled to create movies. When the B movie business died, he went on to make porno films which was the only place where a person with his "talent" could go.Boogie Nights wrestles with the question about how people express themselves. And more than that, it is about dealing with life. It does it with rare humor, style and heart and how often can you say that about a movie?

Knowing this was a movie about the porn industry, I was persuaded to watch it by people who saw it and liked it. But I was appalled. This was the grossest movie I have ever seen. For all the bru-ha ha about how wonderful this movie is, I found it to be nothing more than a more glorified porn movie. Shame on Julianne Moore and Mark Wahlberg for participating in this movie. The porno scenes were graphic and disgusting. The end scene was the grossest thing I have ever seen. I know Hollywood is constantly into pushing the envelope but why does it feel it necessary to venture into a genre that already has more movies than we need. Yuck!

Mark Wahlberg is obviously going to turn out like other 'one hit wonders' e.g.Ray Liotta and Goodfellas. He stars in one good movie and the remainder of his career is dedicated to crappy low budget mush that no one cares about. Wahlberg wasn't born an actor, he was born a rapper, so naturally, he hasn't any talent what so ever. But, despite all this, Boogie Nights is entertaining enough. Its shows the lives of various porn stars. From alcoholic Julianne Moore(Assassins) and dazed William H Macy(Fargo) to likeable Don Cheadle(Hamburger Hill). Also student Heather Grahem(Austin Powers 2), fun loving star John C Reilly(Nightwatch)and director Burt Rehnolds(100 Rifles).The story is clever and some of the lines are funny enough. The acting is brilliant, and Macy, Moore and Cheadle deserve the most credit for their performances. It is not just a movie for perverts. Some of the material is actually moving. Rating=3/5

When this film was released there was a lot of viewers who didn't understand what the purpose was. Instead of purpose , the viewer is advised to just watch the story unfold because there is stellar deliverance from many of the actors here e.g. Julianne Moore as an aging B movie actress, William H. Macy as the obsessed husband , Burt Reynolds as the sleazy producer. As a 70s child, I have a deep acceptance that the rules were not that defined and there's this transition from the flower power to the hippie era where the borders of sex are oftentimes too open and too easy to abuse. There is escapism to easy money but at the same time aspiration to make it better. Philip Seymour Hoffman is true to form as member of the film crew who lusts after Dirk Diggler ( Mark Wahlberg) . An entertaining film with sublime life lessons and heart-poking moments.

The most sheerly dazzling breakthrough movie by an American director since MEAN STREETS. Paul Thomas Anderson directed this tragicomic epic about a Valley porn maker's extended family at a heartbreaking 27 years of age. His flabbergasting synthesis of GOODFELLAS, NASHVILLE and early, satirical DePalma made the careers of everybody in it: Mark Wahlberg, Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, John C. Reilly and an amazing Heather Graham as the obscene pixie Rollergirl constitute the greatest ensemble cast of the decade. No movie experience in the nineties (and certainly not the now obviously overblown PULP FICTION) matched the shock of seeing this picture upon its release; overnight, Anderson was elevated to the front rank of American filmmakers--a feat unaccomplished at such an early age since JAWS.

reviews.review_title: An authentic period piece on the '70s porn industry in a film that's overhyped and disengaging at times
reviews.content: The sets, costume, hair styling, makeup, cinematography, and editing were all top notch. Paul Thomas Anderson certainly has a distinct directing flair throughout all his films, which suits the subject matter and plot of Boogie Nights well. As an ensemble cast, all the performances were fantastic across the board but there wasn't enough depth and focus on each character (such as Rollergirl), so that's the downfall trade off.However... I feel like the conflict and interesting drama arrived too late towards the end of the film, and the beginning was a chill, meandering vibe of exposition which I'm sure was intentional. Recommended if you like ensemble cast period piece films focusing on the '70s decade. Just not a film that has that rewatchable quality to it.

I loved this movie. It was a character study as well as a documentary all contained within the two plus hours it ran. All the characters were rich and defined. The camera shots,the direction, the editing, the script, the actors and the score all wove together perfectly. And it focused on the turbulent consequences of living a life in the porn industry during the late 70's and early 80's. I appreciate this film for a variety of reasons. I'll narrow it down to four.1) It de-glorified pornography. It wasn't glamorized rather interpreted as a character study of the individuals involved.2) It was real. The dialogue matched its characters. These people I could have known personally as my next door neighbor or a regular at the grocery store. They had feelings and they all enjoyed and suffered the benefits as well as the liabilities they allowed in this type of work. We as the audience got to witness this.3) I am a big fan of dark humor. This film knew when to be funny and not take itself too seriously.4) I like directors/writers with guts.It dragged a bit in the last act, but who cares. It didn't hurt anything.

Guess I was being terribly naive, but I thought this film was supposed to be something on the order of Saturday Night Live. Was I ever wrong! However, once into the film I couldn't stop watching. Oh, yes, the sleaziness was there, but so was the heartbreak, the fragile egos, the fears, the dangers, etc.Some of the most memorable scenes: Dirk's confrontation with his vicious mother at the beginning of the film. The coke fest with Amber and Rollergirl; Amber's interviewing Dirk and Dirk talking about Napoleon and getting the history all wrong; Dirk's final reconciliation with Jack and Amber. There's more: actually some very funny stuff, some very dark humor -be on the lookout for it.

Paul Thomas Anderson brings to life the porn industry, during its most triumphant moments.  Set in the late seventies and early eighties, Boogie Nights is the story of Jack Horner, a director of adult films who, with his cast of characters, dreams of creating the first legitimate porn film. 
Horner's cast of players each brings to the story their own unique baggage, suggesting that their past is what brought them into the sex trade.  Juliane Moore is a coke addicted mother who mourns for a child that was taken from her.  Heather Graham is a roller skating teen who could never fit in with kids her own age.  And Thomas Jane is Todd Parker, in his own mind the studio stud.And of course, the crew have their own dramas.  William H. Macey is the lighting director who can't control his sex starved wife.  Phillip Seymour Hoffman is the sound guy, a social misfit who hides his lustful thoughts. And Robert Ridgley is Colonel Parker, the financier for all of Jack Horner's films, who is just as much a victim in the vile world that he creates, as he is a villain.And naturally, while the porn industry becomes a haven for all of these tragic figures, it eventually becomes their downfall.  Their lives are first impacted by the discovery of Dirk Diggler.  Dirk, played by Mark Wahlburg, is a keen, but troubled kid, blessed with an extra special endowment.  It's this endowment that makes him an instant hit in the porn industry, taking him right to the top, eventually setting him up for the biggest downfall of all.Anderson directs a brilliant picture, ironically creating the kind of film that his character Jack Horner could only dream of; a pornographic film with top notch acting and a compelling story line.  While Boogie Nights never delivers the money shot, there are graphic sexual depictions that suggest that this one was made for (not just about) the porn industry.  Scenes with characters having casual sex, taking obscene amounts of drugs and basically throwing their dignity away serve to make this one of the most shocking films of the decade.   Burt Reynolds stands out in an Oscar nominated performance, playing a pervert with a heart of gold.  While Reynolds sometimes gets caught up in his own mannerisms he does manage to  pull it off.  I suspect that this part tailor made itself for Burt, more so than Burt for the part.  In fact it has become Hollywood folklore, and perhaps proof that Reynolds is himself trapped in the seventies, the fact that he fired his agent when he saw the finished product.  It's funny he couldn't even see that this was his best work in an otherwise dopey career.Mark Wahlburg is good as Dirk Diggler.  Again, Anderson makes a natural casting choice.  The performances that truly stand out in my mind were those of Juliane Moore and Phillip Seymour Hoffman.  As Amber, den mother to the cast, Moore is dead on.  I found her most brilliant work to be when her character is actually required to act.  Anyone who has ever seen a pornographic film will recognize this card board performance and probably laugh out loud.  Hoffman, on the other hand, lusting after Dirk, is wonderfully pathetic.  In a sea of low life characters, here is the one we least want to be.The direction in this film is often overwhelming, and for me that is a good thing.  Anderson uses the camera to his advantage, sometimes allowing it to float through the crowd at various parties, and at other times providing quick flashes of truth.Boogie Nights does not condemn the porn industry, nor does it praise it.  At the time when sex films were transferred from 8 millimeter film and onto video tape, they somehow became legitimate.  This film simply documents that time.

Curiosity drew me to this picture and I was not disappointed. It was very well casted and entertaining. Burt Reynolds, like fine wine, gets better with age. He has gone far beyond his Smokey and the Bandit days and keeps the focus of the film. The music was a big part of the 70's and is a big part of the movie as well. Don't expect Shakespeare, but overall, this is THE definitive disco era porn industry picture.

reviews.review_title: Step back to the adult film industry of the 70's
reviews.content: Set back in the 70's when 'Deepthroat' caused a cinematical revolution, John Holmes Johnny Wadd character led people to line up in cinema's, Ron Jeremy was rising and Aunt Peg was the 'older woman' of the adult film industry. This movie outlines the detailes of a rising porn star- Dirk Diggler played by Mark Wahlberg, and all the loopholes of fame, sex and drugs.Having Mark Wahlberg as the protagonist may have not been the best idea, as he gives a rather weak performance, but his weak performance is blanketed by the supporting cast. Julianne Moore gives an Oscar nominated performance as Amber Waves- a rising porn star, trying to battle motherhood, while making a living in the adult film industry- powerfully portrayed and impressively handled, Moore should have received the award. Burt Reynolds also gives an Oscar nominated performance- however though this performance didn't have any Oscar potential, it did have wit and personality. The beginning of the movie, outlined the nightlife, and the joys of being in the Adult film industry, but as the movie goes on, the joys end and the problems begin. I remember when initially wanting to watch this film I thought it would be very juvenile and risqué for the sake of being risqué, but in the end I found something different: a great film that was entertaining and at times fairly meaningful. It was very well-written, well-filmed, and a sad, dark portrayal of how the world can be as a place. Although this film is undeniably for mature audiences, it is the sort of film that has enough meaning built into the shock to really justify the shocking nature of it. Not to mention that, but it is the sort of film that satisfies the curiosity into the world in which Dirk lived. Throughout the whole film the acting is exceptionally well, being such an easy film to get sucked into. I think that the wide appeal for the film comes from its' thoroughness in character portrayal as well as the depth that each character has when it is cultivated in such a short amount of time; each person who appears in the film is more than just an image on the screen, but with the passage of time, you really see them as actual people. It is a movie that, while watching it, you simply forget it is a movie due to the perfection that Paul Thomas Anderson achieves in his realistic, no-holds barred film. I especially enjoy how Dirk Diggler is portrayed with his beaming innocence and simple mind: it makes one see nothing sinister about him, but it lends to the viewer an air of a certain objectivity and lack of judgmental sentiment as they watch the entirety of the porn world unfold around this character.Overall, I recommend this film to everyone who can appreciate good film and has the stomach for sometimes rather edgy and racy material.

reviews.review_title: a movie about a porn star, that isn't about a porn star.
reviews.content: Starting against a black screen with fade in credits, Michael Penn scores broken circus music that whistles triumph and failure of the grandest scale. The warped tones and drowned out laughter provides a foreshadowing of the gradual downfall of a man we all see ourselves in. This score leads into the epic one-shot opening of Boogie Nights, set to Best of My Love, which shoots us into the glamorous world of the social circle we will eventually join.Paul Thomas Anderson makes his mark by direction in every front. Sporting Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly, Phillip Seymour Hoffman as an incredible ensemble as is, PTA directs these actors to preform their roles as simple-minded humans who are just trying to find self-assurance of their own worth in a complex world. All characters seem to have a heart of gold, but lead themselves into disaster by no fault but their own human mistakes. PTA refuses to let us find their job as machines in the porn industry as an excuse to pass them as lesser human, as he sets them in scenes with one another that establish their puppy-dog-like loyalty to one another in hope to feel and be loved, to feel a sense of belonging, to find a home which can celebrate them for their own achievements and be proud in one another alongside themselves.Beyond the raw emotive scenes of ones darkened past and fuzzy future, we are drawn in by all stylistic choices that make this epic feel incredibly intimate. PTA directs cinematographer Robert Elswit to capture the story a very distinct way. Seeing influences such as Marty Scorsese in his quick zooms, stylistic incoming vignettes, heavy steady cam and dolly shots between drawn out nearly theatrical drawn out scenes with complex blocking, challenge traditional film making standards of quality, in that it draws sever attention to the audience of the film being in fact, a film, and fictional. However, his direction to his cast and writing which previously mentioned, is impeccably human, seems to cancel this heavily orchestrated style to challenge the viewer to choose what is in fact real or unreal, to suspend disbelief and yet honor the film as a film in a rather superficial and frankly dumbed-down manner that puts us in the same position as the characters.In addition to all external direction PTA approached for this movie, we see heavily influence and reflection from PTA himself. Besides being set in the 70s in San Fernando Valley around the protagonist as a 17 year old, we have several other moments and key features that we see PTA projecting from himself. Early on we have a glimpse into the life of Eddie Edams (Wahlberg) in his dysfunctional relationship wit his mother through a heated, raw exchange that ends in his estrangement. In commentary of this film, PTA shares this is merely a glimpse into a real-life exchange between his mother and himself. He has admitted on other occasions to being estranged from his mother. As we as an audience question the reasoning to the anger, accusatory sense, and aggression the mother has for her son, PTA is there with us, questioning the motives of his own mother, of questions he himself could not answer.The real word that emerges to describe this movie is "momentum". From literal camera styles of quick pace pull ins, to a blossoming storyline that illuminates us with the wonders and woes of ambiguous characters who we don't think to question their origin but accept their presence in the most intimate nature, this movie has an unexpected "edge-of-your-seat" nature that keeps your heart in an emotional roller-coaster. In the end, we are left to feel a sense of home as we learn, with the characters, that it shall be wherever you strive to make it.

Except for a few bright spots, Boogie Nights was a total bust. Mark Wahlberg proved his total lack of talent in this film by completely over-acting most of his scenes. Julianne Moore and John C. Other than Reynolds' performance, and for the guys, Heather Graham's presence, this film is not worth the trouble.

Paul Thomas Anderson's Boogie Nights is a bold and accurate representation of the adult film scene in Los Angeles during the late 70's and early 80's. While it primarily chronicles one man's rise and fall within the industry and is base on the expolits of real-life porn star John Holmes, the story is so much more, juxtaposing the similar fates of several principal characters during a six year time period. Anderson's fascinating and brutally honest character studies allows the viewer to overcome reservations toward watching a movie about pornography. The result is a truly outstanding film on every level.Seventeen year old Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg) has a chance meeting in a nightclub with porn film maker Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds). Disenchanted with his life and spurred by a violent argument with his abusive and alcoholic mother, Adams moves into Horner's home and joins his stable of adult film actors which include veteran porn queen Maggie/a.k.a. Amber Waves (Julianne Moore) Horner's daughter and aspiring starlet Rollergirl (Heather Graham) and fellow actor Reed Rothschild (John C. Reilly). As a well-endowed new face in the industry, he achieves quick stardom. However, Adams (now "Dirk Diggler"), eventually falls victim to the temptations of fame and becomes addicted to cocaine. As newer actors emerge and the medium changes from film to videotape, he becomes a bitter, drug-addled liability. After a heated confrontation with Horner, Diggler gets kicked off the compound and spirals out of control. Unable to "perform" due to his drug use, he is reduced to turning tricks to support his habit. After a brush with death during a botched robbery of local drug dealer Rahad Jackson (Alfred Molina), Diggler tearfully reconciles with Horner and cleans up his act but clearly faces an uphill battle in reaching the heights he once climbed within the industry.Anderson clearly shows us the devastating consequences many of these "actors" suffer as a result of their career choice without beating us over the head with a morality play. This is a sad story about sad people: Diggler bottoms out. Jack Horner, who fancies himself a film maker is reduced to churning out low-quality garbage on video. Amber's career choice and prior drug arrest force her into role playing instead of true motherhood, as she unsuccessfully seeks custody of her child. Porn star Buck (Don Cheadle) cannot secure a business loan due to his affiliation with adult films. A film director (William H. Macy), humiliated by his wife's public infidelities, kills her, her lover and himself at a New Year's Eve party. And Financier The Colonel James (Robert Ridgely), who fronts the money for Horner's productions is jailed on a child pornography charge. What was once hedonistic bliss is now an unmitigated disaster. There is no happy ending.The styles, fashion and music create a mood that successfully transforms the viewer into a 1970's time warp. And excellent characterization of the drug dependent and open-sex lifestyle popularized by many in the entertainment industry lend the movie authenticity. There are so many subtleties and great scenes- the (purposely) bad performances in the "Brock Landers" feature films, the cheesy interviews, the awful recording sessions by Diggler and Rothschild, the delusions and self-deceptions by the many characters who are not very smart, totally insecure, largely uneducated yet fancy themselves as much more than they really are.The acting is first rate. Burt Reynolds, whose career stagnated for years after a decade of box office stardom in the 70's, returns to greatness as film producer Jack Horner. Mark Wahlberg, under-appreciated by many who remember the "Marky Mark" nonsense is totally believable in the title role. Julianne Moore, as good an actress as there is, doesn't disappoint as a popular yet tormented porn queen. John C. Reilly, the late Philip Seymour Hoffman (as a shy, gay crew member), Heather Graham and the wonderful Phillip Baker Hall all shine in support roles. And Robert Ridgely does a great job in a bit role as The Colonel- a film producer with an affinity for young women and a perversion for underage photos.One of the best movies of the 1990's and in my personal top ten films.

One of the greatest portrayals of the American dream and its falsehoods. A shockingly accurate depiction of Suburban life and the inferiority felt by many adolescents. even if you're not into porn (which i am not) this is an interesting glimpse into the industry as the 70s turn into the 80s ... lots of drugs and lots of bad craziness but the film portrays it all right out in the open ... it doesn't try and glamorize it in any way, shape or form ...perhaps the best and certainly the most intense scene is when William H. Macy's character has finally had enough of being publicly cuckolded by his wife (played by real life porn star Nina Hartley) ... this all comes to a head (no pun intended) on new year's eve as everyone at the party is counting down the new year and he is walking with pistol in hand to the back bedroom to kill his wife, her current lover, and finally standing in front of the party-goers, himself ... the soundtrack builds and builds the closer he gets and doesn't climax with his first two murders but with his suicide ... one of the best sequences i've seen in many movies truth be told ...perhaps the finest accomplishment of the movie is how these real actors capture the bad acting of these porn stars in front of the camera and their nearly universal cluelessness as people behind the camera ... except for the ones who run the show, such as Burt Reynold's character, and the money-men who finance the whole show ... they are the ones who have the brains and know how to handle the people without many brains ...certainly not for a younger audience but for mature audiences this is a fine film that accurately captures an industry within the era

reviews.review_title: Some of the best storytelling I've ever seen on film.
reviews.content: This is a great film. It has a great story, a great cast, a great director, great dialog. Everything about this movie is great.In my opinion, this is Paul Thomas Anderson's best work. I'm a fan of his, although I have yet to see Hard Eight a.k.a. Sydney or The Master. There are three living directors today (or directing teams) who write their own screenplays that can really tell the best stories on film. Quentin Tarantino, Joel and Ethan Coen, and last, but most definitely not least, Paul Thomas Anderson. (I'd like to give Martin Scorsese honorable mention for Goodfellas and Mean Streets, though he doesn't write his own screenplays very often). Boogie Nights is one of my favorite films. I'd place it in my top 20, if not, top 15. And I've seen a lot of movies. So, watch Boogie Nights. Please. I doubt you'll be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: A great film about the porn business...but in a Scorsese-type of fashion...score: 8 (out of 10)
reviews.content: The first time that I saw this film, I thought to myself...Burt Reynolds' acting was superb (most deserving of his Golden Globe and why he never got the Oscar is beyond me.)
